PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987 seeks to control the distribution or laundering of criminal profits by imposing checks on large cash transactions and facilitating the monitoring of financial accounts with financial institutions. The principal object of the Bill is to prevent tax evasion, but the Bill is also intended to support the enforcement of Commonwealth and State laws generally-for example, the offence of money laundering recently created by the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987. Mr Costigan, Queen's Counsel, during his Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, encountered a difficulty in following what he called the `money trail'. Among other things, he criticised his inability to gain access to financial records, both domestic and international, and the length of time for which records were kept. He made recommendations regarding these matters and recommended the introduction of reporting requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill, in part, is a belated response to some of Mr Costigan's recommendations. It will be remembered that Mr Costigan's recommendations were made some years ago. The Proceeds of Crime Bill, debated in this place last week, contains other provisions in dealing with financial records. The Cash Transaction Reports Bill sets up the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, to which cash dealers are to report cash transactions involving more than $10,000. Where such transactions are not conducted in cash, the theory is that they will be detected through the improved access to financial records given to law enforcement agencies through the Proceeds of Crime Bill. So on the one hand, the Proceeds of Crime Bill provides access to non-cash records-that is, records of transactions not made in cash-and, on the other hand, we have this Bill.

The information collected by the Agency set up under this Bill is to be made directly available to the Australian Taxation Office and, with the permission of the Director of the Agency, to the Australian Federal Police, the State or Northern Territory Police, the National Crime Authority and the Australian Customs Service. In addition, the Bill requires financial institutions to obtain from prospective account holders statements containing identification details. This information must also be obtained over a period of time from all existing account holders and also when signatories to an account are changed. Failure to comply with the provisions of the Bill attracts a number of penalties provided therein.

The Bill itself is based on the American system which operates under banks secrecy legislation. Whilst there are conflicting accounts as to what has been achieved under that legislation, which came into being some years ago, in the report of 12 June 1986 to the Committee on Governmental Affairs Permanent Sub-committee on Investigations of the United States Senate, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Enforcement, Mr Francis Keating, said:

The Bank Secrecy Act has proven beyond all doubt its effectiveness as a law enforcement tool against drug trafficking, organised crime, and the illicit financial activity that supports it. The investigations that the Departments of Justice and Treasury have conducted, particularly those under the President's Organised Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force Program, have relied on the Bank Secrecy Act data and the analysis of this data that Treasury has prepared. In approximately three years of full operation, these task forces have initiated 1,350 cases and resulted in the indictments of 8,649 individuals, 3,678 of which have been convicted.

The Opposition welcomes the Government's final Bill before this Parliament, in its belated attempt to deal with organised crime. The package is certainly not perfect, and significant recommendations by royal commissions still remain in the too-hard basket or have been ignored. However, we have had some action, and some of the recent legislation is supported by the Opposition. There are particular problems with this Bill in relation to its regulatory impact. In saying that I do not in any way qualify the Opposition's determination to root out organised and serious crime, but when legislation is presented to this House we must understand what it does.

The Australian Bankers Association and the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies have provided estimates of what they calculate to be the costs involved in complying with the Bill, especially the requirements for opening accounts. Officers from the Attorney-General's Department have informed me that there has been some consultation, but it is obvious that the financial institutions still disagree with what the Government proposes. I have received representations from the financial institutions and, no doubt, the Attorney-General has also receive them. The major spread of financial institutions through the Australian Bankers Association, the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies, and the Australian Federation of Credit Union Leagues claim that some 60 million accounts will be affected at a cost of $180m, and that more than 15 million new accounts being opened each year will be affected at a cost of $75m. They also claim that the Bill will be ineffective in combating organised crime.

In its submission to me, the Australian Bankers Association recommended that the Bill be referred to a parliamentary committee for consideration of its cost effectiveness, the determination of alternative strategies for inhibiting criminal use of legitimate financial intermediaries and the detection of money launderers. Alternatively, it recommended that a provision for the reporting of cash transactions over $10,000 be passed and the issue of personal identification be deferred until resolution of the broader issues of the Australia Card and other personal identification systems.

It is plain that I am not in a position, the Opposition is not in a position and, without a full inquiry, the Government is not in a position, to reach a conclusion one way or the other on the claims made by the financial institutions about the cost involved. On any reading of the Bill, however, it is obvious that it imposes a substantial regulatory burden. Where that is imposed, the sensible course-and one that we understand to be in accordance with the Government's policy-is to refer the proposal to the Business Regulation Review Unit for an assessment of the cost involved. That applies not only to legislation of this nature, but to all legislation, unless we are dealing with something that has obvious urgency and where, for reasons beyond the Government's control, it cannot be referred to the Business Regulation Review Unit. But, whilst this is an important piece of legislation, and in principle we wish to see legislation of this kind in place as soon as possible, there seems to be no good reason why after all these years there should not be a speedy examination of the way in which the Bill will work, the costs involved in implementing it and whether there is a better way of going about things.

It is very difficult to understand the Government's persistent failure to have the Business Regulation Review Unit check out the cost effectiveness of its legislation. I understand that the Attorney-General's Department takes the view that in the case of legislation of this kind, which is directed to stamping out or curbing evasion and cash transactions involving the proceeds of crime-we entirely support that objective, as I have made clear-it is thought to be unnecessary to refer it to the Business Regulation Review Unit. I make the point that, regardless of the kind of legislation with which we are dealing in this House, we need to know the costs involved. While supporting the legislation in principle, I propose an amendment to the motion for the second reading to the effect that the Bill be referred to a parliamentary committee for detailed examination of its cost effectiveness. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`the Bill be referred to a select committee of both Houses to report to Parliament as soon as possible'.

The Parliament is about to rise. We will resume some time after 11 July and we could have a speedy examination of the way in which the Bill will operate. If there is a better way of achieving the objectives, we need to know what it is. If the costs are as high as the financial institutions claim, we want to know. Let us get the financial institutions to substantiate their costs. I certainly do not assume that their claims as to the order of magnitude of those costs are correct. But certainly it is a matter that should go to the Business Regulation Review Unit. The institutions could put their proposal to that Unit; if the Bill is sent to a committee as we propose, the same could be done. It may be that we could have a proposal which was very much better one for the purposes of achieving the laudable objectives that this Bill is designed to achieve.

I do not think it necessary to say much more about the detail of the Bill. As I have said before in this House, organised crime and serious crime are major threats to our society. They continue to increase. The law enforcement authorities have been given some new tools, slowly, by this Government. But they still labour under problems of resources, personnel and a failure to implement, or to bring out for public examination in a statement of the Government's position, a whole host of recommendations that have been made, for example, in relation to the taxation system and the way in which the taxation system could be used to pursue organised crime. While these problems remain-problems of law enforcement will always remain with us-organised crime will flourish. We all believe that, if there were an opportunity to float on the Sydney Stock Exchange an organised crime company, people would be killed in the rush to take up shares. The truth is, as everyone who looks at the figures knows, that crime does pay. Serious crime pays very well, and the most serious of crimes pay extraordinarily well. Drug trafficking is an investment for criminals conducting the business of drug trafficking, and for a relatively small amount of money they can reap huge fortunes. We all have a common interest in stamping that out.

This is the last occasion on which I shall be facing the Attorney-General from this side of the table before the next election. Whilst we have had our disagreements from time to time, we have managed to maintain a sense of humour. I wish him happy campaigning but only the success that the Hawke Government deserves. That means that he will be either taking up a new occupation or addressing Parliament from this side of the House. As the new Attorney-General I will look forward to the kind of co-operation that can be expected from a shadow Attorney-General of a party that has been thrown out of power by the decision of the Australian people, which will be given by them on 11 July. So happy campaigning, Mr Attorney. I look forward to the times when, in the very near future, we can once more gaze at each other but from different positions in the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I say firstly that I do not like the chances of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). The reality is that the consistency and the stability that this Government has given the Australian people as well as the economic control and the economic and financial responsibility, will ensure that the honourable gentleman will remain on the other side, and that his Party, which has done so much damage to this country in the past, will not get that chance again.

SPEECH.PARA: The Cash Transaction Reports Bill is an important Bill. It does not need to be referred to a committee as that would simply waste time, and the proposal to do that is pretty typical of the attitude of the Liberal Party generally. It did little in government and now, when in opposition, it still wants to waste time and not pass this necessary legislation. I think it is important in speaking to the Bill that we refresh our memories as to exactly what Mr Costigan, QC, said in his report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I will refer fairly consistently to the words that he used, because they will explain the great necessity for the Bill, why it should not be delayed and why it should be passed into law as soon as possible. He said:

Criminal organisations profit in large amounts of money. Criminals engaged in petty crime use cash. Some of their bolder colleagues use a lot of cash. Criminal organisations also employ large quantities of cash. But additionally, the amounts being so large, they make use of the banking system in the country. Even the active sole criminal tends to do so. It is all very well to use cash for the daily necessities, for shouting all to a drink, to sport the generous bank roll. Criminals associate with other criminals and the latter are only too ready to take for themselves the ill-gotten gains of others. The cash concealed in a wall, under a mattress, or in a car, is as susceptible to theft as any honest citizen's possessions, and is perhaps more so. Thus financial institutions such as banks are resorted to for much the same reason as any businessman finds their facilities convenient.

Banks are not the only institutions preferred by criminals. There is considerable evidence of building societies being employed to meet their ends; and there is no doubt that gambling institutions such as the TAB are employed in the unfamiliar role of banker. An account is opened and over a period of time money is paid in so that it is in substantial credit. Some of the money may be employed in gambling but the greater percentage is simply left there. After some months it is all withdrawn by a cheque drawn by the TAB. Should any question arise about the source of funds the criminal refers to the cheque and, if he does not say so explicitly, allows the inference to be drawn that he won the money on one or more races.

Nor is this type of dealing limited to financial institutions. There is no doubt, on a great deal of the evidence before Mr Costigan, that certain solicitors have allowed their trust accounts, if not their strong rooms, to be employed as repositories for moneys the source of which, on any rational view, could only be illegal enterprises. By depositing moneys with such solicitors, some hope or expectation is held that law enforcement agencies will have difficulty in locating the funds and in seeking explanations for them.

In all of these cases the criminal employs false identities. A bank manager or other custodian willing to accommodate such preference attracts criminals to him like flowers attract bees. From my investigations it seem that such corrupt managers-they are not limited to banks; they are to be found in branches of building societies and so on-are more likely to be encountered in small branches rather than large. This facilitates investigation, for once such a person is identified in respect of one criminal, there is every prospect of other criminals being found employing him.

The operation of false accounts muddies the waters for an investigator. It makes difficult the tracing of moneys if the starting point is a criminal activity. The criminal, conscious of the need to cover his tracks, takes every precaution to ensure that the proceeds of the crime cannot be traced to him. But if the starting point is different, if it is at the point where the criminal commences to enjoy the possession of the money, the tracing exercise is far easier.

Criminals, and their organisations, are no less, and may be far more, fond of the usual manifestations of wealth than any other rich person. They seek to possess wealthy homes, land, expensive cars, and yachts, and they incur high living expenses. In all of these cases they use money in large quantities. They may pay for much by cash; but ultimately, and especially as the detection-free years pass by, they find the normal financial institutions far more convenient and seemingly no less safe to use. What is more, the ill-gotten gains tend to be employed fully in satisfaction of their lust for the good life. This often leaves little to finance further criminal ventures.

By their nature, though not universally so, criminals show little self-restraint and have little financial ability. With their success in crime they plan bigger and more expensive criminal ventures. These require capital. There is little doubt that as a result, they seek out loans to provide the moneys required. Sometimes the loans are on the fringe money market involving financiers who well know that some illegal enterprise is planned and who exact their return accordingly. Yet on other occasions the financiers are legitimate, being persuaded to advance the money for seemingly honest ventures. This has the advantage from the criminal's point of view in that the return to the financier is more modest. However, in such cases the criminal must employ apparently legitimate business techniques, and this means using the normal banking system.

For all of these reasons criminals in organised or large scale crime do make use of the banking system. This leads to the creation of large accounts with many taxation vouchers. Once located, those vouchers provide a fertile source of intelligence to the investigator. They permit accurate assessments of cash flow and allow comparison with suspected but unsolved crimes. They facilitate investigation for the purposes of recovering tax and assist in identifying the other parties in the criminal organisation. However, as any investigator in the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Customs Service, or any office of the Corporate Affairs Commission will confirm, the seizure of a large account poses difficulties in handling it in the investigation. Costigan refers to one account seized by the Task Force Zebra of the Victoria Police Force in the early days of the Commission. It was a large account operated by a well known starting price bookmaker. Its analysis revealed the identities of most major bookmakers in Australia. Yet the resources of the Victoria Police Task Force allowed the analysis of no more than one year of that account. It was simply too big to handle by manual means. The data could not be readily manipulated so as to extract its full value.

Problems of size beset other law enforcement agencies. Investigators in the corporate affairs offices and in the Australian Taxation Office are confronted daily with immense tasks. It is not generally appreciated that upon it being announced that an investigation will be undertaken, the number of people allocated is sometimes merely two and often only one person. In the case of a major corporate investigation where a special investigator is appointed, the most significant impact is the imposing title rather than the allocation of substantial resources.

Often a special investigator is on his own or is supported by merely one or two officers. The result is a grossly deficient investigation. The investigators do their best but they are constrained by time and the pressures of new investigations requiring their attention. Consequently, they do that which little time allows and no more. The most vulnerable area to such restrictions is the analysis of cash flow. Yet that is the very area where the principals behind the sophisticated criminal activity are likely to be discovered. It is also the place where the most telling remedial steps may be taken. The effect of hamstringing the investigators by inadequate allotment of resources is to permit the more serious offenders to escape and to limit the effectiveness of legal recourse.

The Opposition, by moving its amendment today, is simply saying that it wants to hamstring the effective passage of this legislation; it wants to slow down the processes by which laws may be passed by this Parliament which will tackle this very serious problem of the cash resources of criminals and the use of legitimate financial institutions in depositing those cash resources. Most honourable members who have had professional experience in other areas know full well that occurs. From my experience as a solicitor, I know of a bank manager in Victoria who was well known for approving mortgages in cases in which the lender was certainly very doubtful when most other bank managers would refuse a mortgage on rational and reasonable grounds. The particular bank manager I had dealings with was well known for the ease with which he would lend money. Consequently, he built up a small branch to a very substantial branch. No doubt he was patted on the back by his employers because of the increased business at that small branch. Of course, the result was that many people who borrowed money ended up in bankruptcy or foreclosure, because they should have been refused the loans in the first place.

The same branch was well known for the ease with which accounts could be opened in false names there. People I know and clients of mine in the criminal area I know full well had large accounts and large numbers of accounts with this branch all in bodgie or false names. By delaying the passage of the Bill and referring it to a committee we are simply saying that that sort of dubious practice, that sort of straight illegal activity, will be continued while the politicians in this place sit back and in their usual forthright manner spend many months, and probably years, trying to resolve the problem.

There is a cost attached to the prevention and investigation of crime. The cost of crime is a cost to the entire community. People suffer as a result of crime. Lives are lost, murders are committed, large sums are made, but ultimately the cost is to the community at large. We all pay individually the cost of crime. If there is a cost to prevent the use of banks in the manners described by Costigan, that cost surely must be borne by the entire Australian community, as rightly it should be. The banks for years have known that they have been the means by which criminals have operated large cash transactions. The banks have known for years that the tax frauds which occurred in this country under the Opposition when it government were possible only by the use of the banking system.

The banks have known for years that round robin cheques were being used simply to mask the real nature of a transaction. The banks have known for years that their facilities were used to create dubious and false loans-simple paper transactions-for the purposes of tax fraud. The banks have done nothing about that. They have no rules and regulations even today to scrutinise those sorts of transactions. The banks today in Australia do not require evidence of the name of a person opening an account. The banks are there to make money, and I do not criticise them for that. That is their legitimate role. They have shareholders and their main aim is to get money in, to run commercial accounts and their normal commercial transactions, and to make a profit. I suppose it is fair to say: `Why should the banks worry if people are using facilities'. The use of those facilities will enable the banks to make a greater profit in the long run, so why should they care?'. Provided there is no obvious discrepancy or criminal activity by the use of bank facilities, of course the banks will allow it. I do not criticise them for that, but this Parliament should not be taken in and should not, by referring this Bill to a committee, allow, that situation to continue.

I listened with interest to the honourable member for North Sydney. He intimated that it was about time this Government took action; it was about time this Government introduced such a Bill. Good heavens! For the last 30-odd years, who has been in government in this country? For the last 30-odd years what has the Opposition done to tackle serious crime in this country?

I invite the next speaker from the other side-no doubt the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman)-to tell this House and the Australian people what legislation passed in the Liberal Party's years of government seriously tackled crime. Perhaps he could remind the House of what legislation members of his Party produced. Perhaps he could remind the Australian people of what they did about tax fraud, about extradition treaties, about the proceeds of crime, about mutual assistance and about cash transactions and the use of banks for criminal and dubious purposes. He might tell the Australian people what his Government did over 30 years. He knows and I know that the answer is nothing. The honourable member cannot point to one piece of legislation in that long term of government that represented a serious attempt by the Liberal Party or the National Party to tackle organised crime in this country.

They were dragged screaming into the public arena by the Costigan inquiry-and let us face it they set that up to have a go at unions; it was not to find tax fraud; it was not to find criminal fraud; they set it up strictly speaking so that they could kick a union to death. It backfired on them as Costigan disclosed for the first time the massive tax frauds and rorts which were going on under their Government and which anyone in private practice, as I then was, knew about. I still have in my home, my old filing cabinet from practice-a four-drawer filing cabinet, fully indexed, of published tax schemes. I have them still and one of these days I will bring them into the House. Some of the honourable members opposite should look at them, because they were operating publicly when they were in government. Any person who practiced in the areas of tax, accounting or law was on a mailing list and could sell these schemes to their clients. They were the most dubious schemes. In fact, some of them were just outright shameful and criminal. Yet the Opposition, in government, did nothing. They were published all over the place but the former Government did nothing.

It has taken this Government, in the four short years that it has been in office, to tackle in a most serious range of legislation this enormously difficult problem. I remind the House of just some of the things that the Attorney-General has done in the four short years he has been in the chair. The Proceeds of Crime Bill, which has now passed this House, will prevent the continued enjoyment by a criminal or his family or associates of assets that result from crime. Those proceeds will be taken back from the criminal and be put into the Treasury, and the criminal and his family and associates will not be able to enjoy the fruits of crime.

Under the Mutual Assistance Bill, Australia, for the first time, is agreeing to provide mutual assistance to neighbouring countries that are also concerned about organised crime. We will have mutual assistance with other countries to tackle the international criminal. That is an enormously important Bill. This Bill, the Cash Transactions Reports Bill, will enable the tracing of cash to ensure that full identification procedures are adopted by Australian banks so the criminal cannot use false identities or use a financial institution and profit from his crime.

The Telecommunications (Interceptions) Amendment Bill is also a very important Bill. Under very strict guidelines and regulations Australian police forces, State and Federal, now will have the chance to tap into the private conversations of criminals and bring them to heel more quickly and maybe prevent serious crime. The reform of the extradition laws is also a most important reform. When we came into office we did not have extradition treaties with most of the major countries of the world. The extradition laws had not been brought up to date and again the Attorney-General quite properly and rapidly brought the extradition laws to account. The Government has reformed the taxation laws to prevent the taxation rorts that have been occurring, and we have stopped them all.

We have made changes to the Crimes Act. There is no doubt, Madam Deputy Speaker, that no other government in Australia's history, in such a short time, has passed in such quantity legislation to tackle crime in the way that this Government has done. I have said it before and I will say it again: The Attorney-General rightly deserves the title of the Eliot Ness of Australian crime. In the time he has been here he has done more as an individual than any other Attorney-General has done in the long history of this Parliament to tackle the major crime, the major tax frauds and the major commercial frauds, and he has done it very promptly.

So I reject the concept put forward by the honourable member for North Sydney that this Bill should not get a speedy passage through the House. If the banking association does not like the cost involved, so be it. Let its members stand up and say what they will do about it. Let them stand up and say today what they will do to prevent the use of bodgie accounts, false names and the use of banks for cash transactions to facilitate criminal activities.

Of course, there is a cost, but quite frankly I do not accept the figures that have been put up. I think they are blown out of all proportion, as they usually are. But the cost is a proper cost for the Australian community to bear, because crime costs us all. It costs each and every one of us large sums of money and, if we are to have the proper laws to stop it, we, as a community, must pay that cost. It is the only way we will stop crime. It is the only way we will bring the criminal to justice and it is the only way we will make sure that criminals do not profit from the proceeds of crime through use of our standard financial institutions.

It is very sad that the Opposition is, as one of its usual tactics, moving to defer the legislation. That is just a way of opposing it. They can say it is deferral, but if the Bill does not pass today, it simply means that there will be a continuation of the matters that Costigan raised and other criminals will now be able to use the financial institutions. If the Opposition defers the Bill, it will allow that to happen. It is a typical Liberal way of opposing, to support their rich mates, to support their friends in the white-shoe brigade in Queensland. That is what it is all about and I think that proposal should be totally thrown out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating here today the Cash Transaction Reports Bill. I wish to pay tribute to the great work done in our Party by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) who, unfortunately, because of electoral duties, cannot be here today to deliver this speech.
—His job is in this chamber. What is he doing at home?

—We will have many more members in this chamber after the next election and we will be sitting on the Government benches. In conjunction with the Proceeds of Crime Bill and the Mutual Assistance Bill, this legislation seeks to counter the underground cash economy, tax evasion and money laundering. The Bill will set up a Cash Transaction Reports Agency which will make information available on a direct and unrestricted basis to the Commissioner of Taxation. Other law enforcement agencies, including the Australian Customs Service, the National Crime Authority and State police could seek access to the cash transactions reports information, which could be used as evidence in courts and for investigations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill takes into account recommendations by a number of royal commissions in recent years for stronger measures to deal with the widespread abuse of the facilities of financial institutions in relation to tax fraud and other criminal activities. The legislation is based, in part, on the recent United States legislation which has opened for four or five years.
The Bill has four major purposes: Firstly, to require the reporting of certain domestic currency transactions in excess of $10,000 to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you say about that?

—The honourable member will hear in a minute if he listens. Secondly, to require the reporting of certain currency transfers to and from Australia in excess of $5,000 to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency; thirdly, to establish a Cash Transactions Reports Agency to collect, compile, analyse and disseminate information relating to transaction reports and to perform other functions under the legislation in consultation with the Commissioner of Taxation; and, fourthly, to impose obligations on financial institutions in relation to the verification of identity of persons seeking to open accounts with financial institutions and of signatories to existing accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the financial impact on the public sector, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has estimated annual agency running costs of approximately $2m with an extra $1m for establishing computer facilities. According to the Australian Taxation Office, this cost will be offset by a projected increase in tax revenue of $30m per annum. The financial impact in the private sector is a little more vague. The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, states that the Bill will have only `a modest impact' on cash dealers required to report cash transaction information as there is sufficient flexibility in the legislation to enable the Director of the Agency to develop the most cost-effective measure for cash dealers to record and communicate information to the Agency. The Australian Bankers Association, which is opposed to the legislation on a number of grounds, has estimated that the costs involved in the identification process will, conservatively be, in excess of $60m-that is way above `a modest impact', as the Attorney-General said-and that the inclusion of building societies and credit unions will raise the figure to about $180m. Those costs would be passed on to the customer.

The legislation will require the reporting of certain domestic currency transactions in excess of $10,000 to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. The figure of $10,000 is based on a similar figure in the United States and it is estimated that approximately 200,000 transactions per annum would be involved in Australia. The Australian Bankers Association expresses its concern at moves in the United States to reduce the threshold to $3,000 and envisages a similar reduction here at some time in the future with consequences for both the right to privacy of ordinary citizens and the cost of it. The Association has further added that information from the American Bankers Association has indicated that the United States legislation is ineffective as a means of combating organised crime; in other words, it is not doing the job that everybody intended or envisaged. The Government's response to such a statement is that this legislation is seen as a trigger or merely another tool which, taken in conjunction with other sources of information, will assist in following the money trail of tax evasion and laundering.

Clause 7 (1) of the Bill requires a cash dealer who is a party to a significant cash transaction to prepare a report and submit it to the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency unless an exemption applies. Exemptions under clause 8 may be made to certain high cash flow businesses, to employers for payroll withdrawals and to government agencies. There is also an exemption where the amount of currency in the transaction does not exceed an amount that is reasonably commensurate with the lawful business activities of the customer. Financial institutions will be required to maintain an exemption register to which the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency will have access and will be able to direct a financial institution to remove or amend an entry. The Agency is also given a monitoring role in relation to the export of foreign currency and the import of any currency. This provision is in addition to the currency restriction of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations.

An important requirement of the legislation provides for the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to make the information available to the Commissioner of Taxation on a direct and unrestricted basis. In addition, the Australian Customs Service, the National Crime Authority and State law enforcement agencies may also seek access to this information. Provisions exist in the Bill for the verification of the identity of persons opening and operating accounts with financial institutions. The Australian Bankers Association is again opposed to this aspect of the legislation and argues that the planned requirements will cause widespread inconvenience and cost to customers. The Association further contends that the practical effects and community resentment that will be generated have been underestimated by the Government. The information so obtained will need to be manually recorded by the banks and other financial institutions. The Bankers Association feels that the present guidelines issued by banks in opening accounts already meet the needs of the legislation in terms of effectiveness.

Enforcement provisions attract a series of fines. Failure to provide information can result in a fine not exceeding $1,000 for a person and not exceeding $5,000 for a body corporate. Further provisions exist for providing false or misleading information, incomplete information or the conducting of transactions so as to avoid reporting requirements. The maximum penalty for a person is a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding five years, or both, or if the offender is a body corporate, a fine not exceeding $50,000.

When this Bill goes to the other place, the National Party of Australia will move to have the matter referred to a Senate committee to determine the cost, effectiveness and practicality of the proposals. The National Party is not satisfied that, firstly, the identification system will be either successful or worth the cost to consumers-bearing in mind the estimate of $180m that I mentioned earlier-and, secondly, the Cash Transaction Reports Agency will operate effectively. Quite frankly, very little is explained in the Bill as to how the Agency will operate. The National Party is at the forefront of the fight against tax evaders and organised crime. In principle, naturally we support legislation of this kind. However, too many questions as to cost effectiveness are left unanswered. In these circumstances, having regard to the need for certainty in the law, the National Party foreshadows an amendment to be moved in the Senate referring the Bill to a committee to report as a matter of urgency. This is the only responsible course of action to adopt. Otherwise, we are left taking legislation on faith only and not certainty. The many questions of the ABA, the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies and the Australian Federation of Credit Unions, on behalf of their millions of clients, deserve to be answered. The National Party has adopted the only responsible stance possible-that is, to refer the Bill to a parliamentary committee for report quickly so that the fight against tax evasion and crime can continue in the most effective way possible.

If the Bill becomes law, ordinary people will become subject not only to the scrutiny of the Taxation Office but also the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and the National Crime Authority. All cash dealers will be bogged down with reporting cash transactions. This includes not only banks, building societies and credit unions, as I have mentioned, but also insurers, cash management trusts, property trusts, unit trusts, securities and futures dealers, bullion dealers and so on. The list is never-ending. Each must prepare a report of the transaction, sign the report, have it signed by the other party to the transaction and forward a copy to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency within 15 days or, if it is to do with a foreign currency, within 24 hours. One wonders whether the Government has any idea of the number of reports that it will receive. It could easily run into hundreds of thousands. If every report is to be followed up by the Agency, it will need a veritable army of public servants to check on what is going on. Under the guise of hitting the criminal and the tax evader, which we would all support, I fear that many of the rights which we take for granted are being stripped away. The legislation has been prepared in far too hasty a manner and should be rewritten, after proper consideration by a Senate committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, in moving an amendment that would effectively delay the implementation of the legislation, is swimming against the tide of its public contributions in this chamber since the election of the Hawke Labor Government. I refer to the chronic inability of the Opposition, when it is forced to support the substance of legislation, to do anything other than to continue its time worn refrain that the Government has not done its job quickly enough. It seems somewhat ironic that on the occasions when it has to look desperately for points of disagreement with the Government, the avenue by which it embraces its responsibilities as an opposition is to delay very important legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case, this legislation has gone through the normal processes of the Government. The Government Caucus was involved in the Bill; there was long and quite vigorous debate about its implications and the effectiveness of it. It has gone through a very difficult process, and it is very important that we acknowledge that, now it is before the House, it is important legislation and it certainly ought not to be delayed. Were one to embrace the view of the Opposition that it should be slipped off to a parliamentary committee, then that course, given the fact that we are facing an election on 11 July and considering the normal delays inherent in the Labor Party's return to government, would constitute a substantial delay. The reality is that such a committee could not be put in place on an urgent basis and, to that extent, we must accept that the Opposition's amendment is a mechanism which would constitute a severe delay in the passing of the legislation. The Opposition would have to bring into this House more substantive criticisms of the substance of the legislation before the Government would even consider that delaying tactic. I do not believe it is intended to be anything other than an effort by the Opposition-a fairly lame effort-to be seen to be having a point of disagreement with the Government. The Opposition is in substantive agreement with a whole raft of government legislation, and that has been indicated in this House on a number of occasions. The Opposition is looking for a feather to fly with in opposing this legislation.

The cost involved has been a matter of some controversy. I will make a couple of points in relation to that matter. Figures of $180m and yearly administrative costs of $75m, I think, have been bandied around. If financial institutions are going to bandy around those figures, it is encumbent upon them to provide a proper and detailed analysis of how those figures come to pass. It is simply not good enough for those institutions to throw their figures around in a wild and uncorroborated way and expect a government to significantly delay legislation that is very much part of the whole raft of legislation, to which I have referred, which constitutes this Government's organised crime fighting armoury. As to costs, the first point I make is that the blocking of the Australia Card Bill by the Opposition is, of course, implicated in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is outrageous.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur has pointed out, it is outrageous. It is an outrageous position for the Opposition to have adopted. It is based on a very weak foundation of outrage. The reality is-as the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) well knows-that most members of the Opposition privately support the Australia Card Bill.
—Rubbish! It is a Moscow card.

—I am not so sure about the honourable member for Denison. I am glad he has come back into the chamber, because I make this prediction: The honourable member for Denison has the ability to attract publicity. His sensitivity to the need for publicity directly increases as the election date comes a little closer. I hope I am mistaken, but I think the honourable member for Denison is in this chamber not to discuss the merits or otherwise of the legislation but to interweave into his contribution, under the protection of the Parliament, slanderous and cowardly observations on other individuals in this chamber, as he has done on a number of occasions. I hope he does not do that.
—Order! I point out to the honourable member for Maribyrnong that he must not make any personal reflections upon members of this House.
—I will certainly be guided by you, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—Particularly in your last speech in the House!

—I add that the honourable member for Denison and I have been involved in many debates together. I have had a close look at his margin and his contribution to Denison over a period, and a maelstrom from the north will descend upon the honourable member for Denison on 11 July. However, that is of little import. As to the issues before the House, I have reflected on the Opposition's attitude to the Australia Card, and that is a matter of public record and a position that is totally inconsistent with the Opposition's alleged sensitivity towards issues of fighting organised crime. I have already indicated that it is incumbent upon those financial institutions that bandy around figures to provide a more detailed analysis of the alleged figures that they have proposed to date. In any event, as I understand it, the financial institutions have implemented voluntary procedures, or at least recommended them, such voluntary procedures being subject to relevant administrative costs. To some extent at least, their suggested costs must be offset against the normal voluntary code. If the voluntary code is not being adhered to, in my view, that constitutes a lack of public duty on behalf of those institutions. A strong case can be made for this legislation; a strong case can be made for not delaying the legislation on the basis or excuse of criticisms by those financial institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: One could talk about a range of issues in the context of this legislation. I would like to raise the genesis of it. In the United States of America, the Bank Secrecy Act came into public prominence quite recently when the extent to which it had impacted upon organised crime in the United States was indicated. I will give some indication of that. In an operation referred to earlier in this chamber, called Operation Greenback, the United States Treasury, on a major drug trafficking investigation, targeted a whole range of individuals. It is worth running through the type of people involved in this very significant drug trafficking organisation: Attorneys-lawyers and solicitors, in our terminology- accountants, money brokers, money couriers, bankers, and major banks. They were directly involved in the laundering of illicitly obtained moneys. It is not only the fact that they were involved in a major criminal transaction, but also that these bastions of decency-as they seek to describe themselves-were involved in some $2.6 billion of documented laundered funds. I ask the House to reflect on the enormity of that sum of money-$2.6 billion in one related criminal transaction. That gives some indication of the extent to which this legislation, while not a direct corollary, should, in the future, have a major impact in Australia. It ought to be another reason why the Opposition's suggestion that this legislation be effectively delayed ought not to be embraced by this House.

The legislation before the House today constitutes the last piece of the armoury that the Government has brought to bear for this session of Parliament to fight organised crime. I shall briefly run through the others. The establishment of the National Crime Authority-I have the honour and duty to be chairman of the parliamentary committee overseeing that body-is a significant contribution of the Government and one which is, I think, acknowledged even by members of the Opposition, even having regard to the fact that it is very close to an election. Other pieces of the armoury are: The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill that was recently brought into this House; and the Proceeds of Crime Bill, which will effectively attack the very motivation for people being involved in criminal activity-the accumulation of large amounts of private moneys, and other resources and assets. I also refer to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, the finalisation of extradition arrangements with a significantly increased number of countries, the expansion in the role of the Australian Federal Police and, as a corollary, the making available of significantly increased resources to the Australian Federal Police. It is a matter of some degree of consensus in the community that the reorganisation of the Australian Federal Police has made it a significantly more potent organisation. A rudimentary overview of the record of the Australian Federal Police in recent times would tend to support my view that it is much more effective in fighting crime than it was when we came to government.

An increase in resources has been made available to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Investigation. The Australian Customs Service also has been restructured. That organisation has not received much attention in the past, but obviously it is at the forefront in the prevention of the importation of illicit narcotics. It is a very important link in the chain in opposing organised crime. Of lesser moment in some ways-it is certainly not known or acknowledged widely-is the institutionalisation within government processes of a higher responsibility on organised crime issues. My colleague the honourable member for Denison, who probably has another appointment, is asking me to wind up my speech, which I will do shortly. I will give the House an example of this higher responsibility. Because of the higher profile taken by the Attorney-General's Department, because of the bureaucratic changes, we now have institutionalised a section which has the prime responsibility of fighting organised crime. Hopefully, over time and over parliaments, that will keep organised crime at the forefront of government consideration.

My colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) has had a distinguished role in regard to much of this legislation as chairman of the Caucus legal and administrative committee. He raised the issue of a whole range of criminal tax avoidance schemes that had come to his attention when he was working as a solicitor. We ought not forget that this Government has gone a very long way towards preventing those sorts of schemes from operating. It is a sad indictment on some members of the Opposition parties that our tax avoidance measures-our bottom of the harbour legislation-that we introduced a considerable time ago were blocked in the Senate. As the Australian people know, the result of the blocking of that legislation is that criminals in this community are now very much richer. The effective opposition to such legislation really goes some way towards minimising the impact of the Opposition's criticism of the whole gamut of our legislation. It is on record not only as trying to delay the legislation as in this case but also as blocking legislation such as the Australia Card legislation. It failed to support a mechanism which would have gone a considerable way towards addressing the problems within financial institutions. Sadly, the Opposition's attitude to issues such as our bottom of the harbour legislation has allowed criminals to retain many hundreds of millions of dollars that rightly is the property of the Australian taxpayer.

I conclude my comments by making some very brief points. The genesis not only of this legislation but also of a whole range of other Government legislation was in the outcome of the Costigan and Stewart commissions and reports by Gyles, Redlich and others. It would be churlish of anyone in this chamber not to acknowledge the significant contribution of those people who brought these very important issues before the eyes of the public. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who, in the whole scheme of things, has had a relatively brief tenure in that office, has managed to bring in the greatest range of very potent organised crime fighting legislation this country has seen not just in the last few years but since Federation. For the first 83 years of Federation, this Parliament effectively did nothing in this area; but in the four years we have been in government we have brought in some very important and very effective legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say from the outset that the Opposition rejects the claim by the Government that the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill moved by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), is a move to defeat the legislation. That is not so. The Opposition believes that it is better to get it right than to get it soon. The Opposition believes that the only way in which the Parliament can be properly informed on a number of crucial issues relating to this important legislation is by referring the Bill to a select committee of both Houses and asking it to report to Parliament as soon as possible. Why on earth would the Hawke socialist Government so violently oppose a move for a parliamentary inquiry? The point made by the honourable member for North Sydney is fundamental; that is to say, we have to be assured in our own minds, and the community needs to be assured, that the Bill will do that which it has been brought to this Parliament to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put the record straight. It can be fairly said that on both sides of this House all honourable members are totally committed to the fight against crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I thank the honourable member who made that interjection. I believe it is correct to say that on both sides of the Parliament every single member is committed to the fight against organised crime.
—Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for Franklin. The difference is in the way in which one goes about it. I would not for one moment believe that even the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), who has just resumed his seat, is in any way impugning the integrity of the honourable member for North Sydney. But there is an argument about whether this is the proper course of action to take.

SPEECH.PARA: I am speaking to the amendment to emphasise this point: It is not to defeat the legislation; it is to ensure that before the legislation passes through the Parliament we are properly advised by a select committee representing members from this House and from the Senate, from both sides of the political scene, as to the most efficacious way in which this legislation can be implemented. That it is far reaching legislation is, I think, accepted by all. It will impact on cash transactions domestically-that is, within Australia-in excess of $10,000. It will impact on cash transactions outside Australia of amounts in excess of $5,000. Those amounts are big to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, and to me, but in the world of business and in particular in the world of legitimate business they are not regarded as large amounts.

The impact in cost to the Australian economy, particularly to the private sector, will be very substantial indeed. I do not quibble with the estimate of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that the cost to the public sector, namely, the cost of establishing the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and of providing for running costs, will be of the order of $2m per annum, with an extra $1m for establishing computer facilities. I agree with the assessment that it will be cost effective in that the revenues that are recovered in taxation may well be of the order of $30m. So, on a straight mathematical analysis, an outlay of $3m to recover $30m-if those figures are approximately correct-is good. There is no argument about the public sector aspect and, in an annual expenditure of $90 billion plus, the expenditure of $3m is minuscule.

It is the impact on the private sector which concerns this side of the House and, I can say from discussions I have had, a number of members of the Government. The impact on the private sector, according to the Australian Bankers Association, will be in excess of $60m. That is not just a once-only cost. That is a continuing expenditure; again, a cost imposed on private enterprise by the Hawke socialist Government. If one were to include the building societies and the credit unions, that annual cost would become $180m. That might not mean much to those who occupy the Hawke socialist Government bench, but I assure them that a private enterprise sector that is already overtaxed by their Government, that is already overregulated by their Government, is getting pretty fed up. It is starting to watch every extra dollar and every extra cent that is imposed upon it, because the dollars and cents that they put on the backs of Australian enterprises are making it harder for them to continue, making it almost impossible for them to profit, and placing in jeopardy the jobs of hundreds of thousands of Australians. We on this side of the House, totally committed as we are to the fight against crime, say to Government members that they seem to want to rush through this legislation in a manner which raises my suspicion as to why they do not want it to be the subject of an inquiry by a joint select committee.

This legislation, as the honourable member for Maribyrnong and the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) said, is part of a continuing package of legislation which has been brought in by the Attorney-General. I have made it clear in the past, and I repeat today, that I do not quibble about the Attorney-General's integrity, honesty or ability. Let me put that on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wish him the best.

—I do wish the Attorney-General-he is also our Deputy Prime Minister-all the best. But I must say that I get rankled at the lecturing we get from the other side of the House about our alleged immorality. I am sick and tired of people such as the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) and others repeatedly claiming that members on this side of the House are the friends of tax cheats, criminals and people who rip off the system. It is an unworthy and disgraceful allegation. The fact is that even today the suggestion has been made by innuendo that because we propose that this matter should be considered by a joint select committee, in some way we are shielding the white shoe brigade, or whatever. I do not know members of the white shoe brigade. I have nothing to do with them. I would not shield any person-I never have, during 20 years in parliament, State and Federal-in the commissioning of any crime.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members have double standards because of the way in which they put this argument. It is almost as if the State of New South Wales never existed. It is almost as if the crime and corruption in New South Wales under Australian Labor Party governments never occurred. I would like to have seen the looks on the faces of some Australian Labor Party members if this legislation had been in place at the time of the inquiry into the Nugan Hand financial transactions, involving the coffers of the bag men of the ALP. I would like to see what the reaction would have been, because in that case we were dealing with much more than $10,000. I would like to see what would have been the impact of this legislation in relation to the running of illegal casinos in New South Wales and the payment to a Government that has been in power since 1976 in that State and which is not of our political persuasion.

I will not take the matter much further because the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) is to make a statement in a moment. But Government members should not preach morality. The State of New South Wales has been under a stench of corruption for over a decade. That has occurred in the mother State of Australia at a time when it has been under Labor administration. The Labor Party was the party which killed the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union; no ifs and no buts. Mr Costigan QC asked for an extension of six months. That extension was granted by Premier Cain and the Victorian Government-a Labor government-but was refused by this Government. It killed the Costigan inquiry when he was on the brink of possibly the greatest breakthrough in major crime investigation that this country has ever seen. It has never explained why it did it. People have a suspicion as to why it did it. Perhaps Mr Costigan was getting too close for comfort.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think you even believe that.

—I do believe it. I say to the Minister that I did not meet Mr Costigan during his inquiry, but I met him afterwards, and I spoke to him. I have reason to believe that this Government killed the Costigan inquiry at a crucial time when a six months extension may well have enabled him to complete the net which would have ensnared and brought to public light, trial and conviction, some of the major figures in Australian crime. I say to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) that I do believe it. I look him right in the eye and tell him that one of the great question marks of the history of his Government is this: Why did it kill the Costigan Royal Commission when Premier Cain gave it a six months extension?
—You would not table the report.

—One day the secrets will be open to all. One day we will find out. I put it on the line. I do not endorse and embrace Costigan chapter and verse in every respect, but what the Government did then was something for which I think it will never be forgiven.

SPEECH.PARA: We have undertaken to keep to a time limit. I would like to table details of a case dealing with a cash transaction relating to crime. I refer to a New South Wales police department report 82/1104 into the robbery at the Boulevard Hotel--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I indicated in my contribution that the honourable member for Denison was most likely, having regard to past practice, to use the opportunity of this coward's castle in some respects to cast improper imputations. Madam Deputy Speaker, I ask you to rule under standing order 76 whether it is not an abuse of the procedures of this House for him to continue along this slanderous line of imputation. Let him go outside this chamber and put it before the public if he thinks there is any merit in it. Let him do it outside.

— Order! The Chair wishes to rule on that point of order. I uphold the point of order, as I did during the contribution of the honourable member for Maribyrnong, that one should not make imputations or personal reflections. As the honourable member for Maribyrnong ceased to do so, I also ask the honourable member for Denison to cease.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I will talk about a hypothetical situation on which this legislation would impact. I will make the point and then sit down. If a sum of $3,600 in Commonwealth bank notes, along with the sum of $1,000 in United States currency and a quantity of travellers cheques-bank and number unknown, but said later to be $1,000-were stolen, that gives a total of $5,600. If the proceeds of that crime were then taken out of the country--

—On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker: With the greatest respect I find the honourable member's cowardly way of trying to avoid the Standing Orders of this House grossly offensive. Prior to the honourable member getting up to speak, I predicted-accurately, as it turned out-that he would use the veil of this legislation once again to use this chamber to make what constitutes a most outrageous attack on another member of this House. I think it is outrageous, and he knows that it is.

—Order! I was not aware that the honourable member was referring to a member of this House. If this is an attack on a member of this House, I rule that the honourable member for Denison is out of order. I ask him to change the subject.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, can I reply to the point of order? There is no coward's castle. I will release this document, which is a New South Wales police report, outside this Parliament. The honourable member for Maribyrnong should not make comments about a coward's castle. I say nothing in this House that I am not prepared to repeat outside it. What I did say-it got very close to the honourable member for Maribyrnong-is that I have referred specifically to a particular robbery which took place on 21 February 1982. I said that if this legislation was introduced it would apply.
—You're a liar.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison is referring to a member of this House. He is ruled out of order and I warn him not to repeat any further points of accusation about a member of this House.
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker: The honourable member for Prospect called the honourable member for Denison a liar. I hope that he will be asked to withdraw.
—I ask the honourable member for Prospect to withdraw the unparliamentary language.
—I withdraw.

—In conclusion, I note that once again I have got under the Government's skin. If a domestic transaction involves more than $10,000, it comes under the provisions of this legislation; and if more than $5,000 is sent outside Australia, it comes under the provisions of this legislation. I leave the honourable member for Maribyrnong with this thought: If a robbery occurs involving $5,600, as I indicated, made up of various currencies and it is sent out of Australia, it would be subject to the provisions of this legislation. If the honourable member disputes that, let him stand up and say so. I conclude by saying that there are many in this Parliament and many outside who would wish that this legislation had been on the statute books on 21 February 1982. I will now go outside the House and publicly release the New South Wales police report which I have in my possession. Everyone will then see what it relates to. I thank the House.
