SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Local government forms part of the system of representative democracy in Australia and part of the public sector of the nation. Local government undertakes a range of significant functions in response to local needs. It also shares responsibility with the Commonwealth and the States for a diversity of programs. We need competent local government, participating as a partner with the Commonwealth and the States, contributing to national development from the grassroots up. We will not only get more value for the public dollar by taking advantage of the attributes of local government, but also achieve integration of government efforts at the local level. The development of local government is important in improving the responsiveness and effectiveness of public administration and in strengthening democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the election of the Hawke Labor Government in March 1983 I have had the privilege of serving as the first Federal Minister for Local Government-initially as Minister for Territories and Local Government and, following the 1984 election, as Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. My involvement and interest in the development of local government goes back many years. In the course of my experience with local government I have seen it grow in sophistication, evolving into a multi-functional level of community government, contributing in various ways to the social and economic development of our nation. I have worked with a diverse range of elected representatives and officials at the Federal, State and local government levels. I have generally been able to work with them co-operatively across the political spectrum; and for that I am grateful. I am proud to report on some of the achievements we have made; and I say `we' because it has been a collective effort. What I have to report is a product of co-operation and a process of gradual evolution. I am confident that we have built an enduring foundation for the continuation of local government development in this country.

There are five broad areas of achievement on which I can report. The first is the creation of a local government portfolio at the Federal level and the strengthening of the Office of Local Government. I know that local government values having a focal point of contact at the Federal level-listen to its concerns and understand its needs and capacities, to argue its case within the Federal bureaucracy, and to promote co-ordination of policies affecting local government. This has also proven valuable to the Commonwealth in improving programs and in developing more sensitive and effective inter-government relations.

The second area of achievement has been the continuation and improvement of the program of general purpose financial assistance for local government. In 1984 the Government Commissioned the first national inquiry into local government finance under the chairmanship of Professor Peter Self. The purpose of the inquiry was to review the operations of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 which had been introduced by the Fraser Government. I have stressed time and time again that I congratulated the Fraser Government on continuing that role and that legislation after the Whitlam Government developed the Local Government Act in 1974. As honourable members would know, the Whitlam Labor Government gave local government direct access to untied grants from the Commonwealth.

The Self Committee recommended continuation of general purpose assistance for local government, and proposed ways of improving the allocation of grants, so that the equalisation objective of the program could be more effectively realised. Following consultations with the States and local government, the Government adopted the thrust of the Committee's recommendations and introduced the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986. The new Act provides for a more stable, more predictable, more accountable and more equitable allocation of funds for local government. The Act is significant in treating local government no less favourably than the States in terms of annual changes in funding levels. In fact for 1986-87 and 1987-88, the Act provides local government the benefit of a real terms guarantee. Some $590m is being made available this financial year under the program and the projected level of funding in 1987-88 is of the order of $640m. I think that that is some progress since the first year of the program, when the Whitlam Government made $56m available. The Act is also significant in that it is the first piece of Commonwealth legislation requiring local Government to be consulted on the principles governing the allocation of funds. And, with the inclusion of the Northern Territory in the program, eligibility for funds has been opened to local governing bodies of Aboriginal communities. I believe that the breakthrough in the Northern Territory will occur in the States in following years. The Act represents another step forward in the development of local government.

The third area of achievement concerns the success of the local government development program. Some $13.5m has been provided since 1983 for more than 500 projects involving more than 350 local councils and other local government bodies. That program is an important investment in research and development for the local government sector. It contributes to improved practices, inter-governmental co-operation and the spread of cost-effective innovations. It is a responsible role for the Commonwealth to seed local innovation and to disseminate positive results. And the results achieved through that program reflect well on the capacity of local government. The program has aided and improved resource management practices, more effective planning, new models for the co-ordination and delivery of human services, new approaches to infrastructure maintenance and the development of local economic strategies. Participating councils have been willing to share their experiences, and the office of the Local Government has provided access to documentation through an extensive publishing program throughout local government all over Australia. The local government development program has also supported the national awards for innovation in local government which were inaugurated in 1986. These awards have captured the imagination of local government, given recognition to excellence in local government, helped to inspire and spread improved practices, and helped broaden community understanding of what local government can do. The 1986 awards were presented by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Adelaide. Entries for the 1987 awards are now open and the winners will be announced later this year in Perth.

Another important contribution of the local government development program has been its support for the work conducted by the Local Government Ministers Conference. This has included major documentation of trends and issues related to the roles of local government in community development, and economic development. The reports emerging are now the subject of consultation between Federal, State and local governments with a view to clarifying functional responsibilities.

Yet another initiative, commenced this year, is the national review of local government labour markets, designed to ensure that local government has available to it an adequate supply of skilled personnel for its future tasks. The review is examining ways of reducing rigidities which prevent staff mobility, and of matching training programs to emerging requirements. I have been particularly pleased to see the increasing participation of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations in the Local Government Ministers Conference and its servicing committees. This represents a further extension of the local government voice into national decision-making and consultative forums. It builds upon the recognition given by the Hawke Government to ACLGA, in inviting that body to the economic and taxation summits, and including it in the membership of the Economic Planning Advisory Council.

The fourth area of achievement concerns the success of innovative programs involving local government. There are two programs which I would like to mention briefly. The first is the natural areas enhancement scheme which formed part of the community employment program, and to which local government throughout Australia made a magnificent contribution. Some $17.6m has been provided since 1984, for 78 projects, to create jobs and improve passive recreation amenity, beautifying the foreshores along the waterways of capital cities. Social facilities of enduring benefit to local communities have been established, and new environmental landscaping and management techniques have been developed.

Second, the country centres project, undertaken in 11 rural areas, has been a successful and exciting pilot program. The project has helped local communities to improve their organisational capability, to identify realistic development opportunities and to formulate their own strategic plans for managing change. Some 58 export opportunities have been identified, some of which are now at the business planning stage. Even more importantly, the participating communities are working together more effectively, pursuing a direction for development in which they have had a say, and to which they are committed. Federal and State agencies are listening to what the local communities know about their own areas, and are providing information and technical assistance to them.

The fifth area of achievement concerns the momentum for constitutional recognition of local government. I recall the Whitlam Government initiating a referendum on this matter in 1974. The referendum proposal was defeated. In fact, it was defeated only narrowly-47 per cent of Australian people voted to support the proposal. The strange thing was that the worst enemy was local government itself-it was against what it then thought was a centralisation of power in Canberra. Since then, local government itself has pushed from the bottom up for constitutional recognition and the Hawke Government has responded to that grass roots pressure and encouraged that approach.

At the Constitutional Convention in Brisbane in 1986, I was pleased to be able to second, on behalf of the Australian Government, a motion moved by a representative of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations in support of constitutional recognition of local government. That motion gained the support of the majority of delegates to the convention. Since then, the Constitutional Commission has been formed by my colleague the Attorney-General, and its terms of reference include the matter of recognition of local government. The Office of Local Government has made a submission to the Constitutional Commission, arguing the case for recognition of local government in the Australian Constitution. I commend the submission to the House, and seek leave to incorporate a summary in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The Commonwealth Office of Local Government (OLG) prepared a submission to the Constitutional Commission putting the case for constitutional recognition of Local Government from a Commonwealth point of view.
This brochure summarises OLG's submission.
Why is constitutional recognition of Local Government important?
Two facts make constitutional recognition vital:
(1) Local Government is an elected and publicly accountable sector of government; and
(2) Local Government is an integral part of the Federal system of public administration.
These facts have not been adequately understood in the past.
Formal acknowledgment of these facts through constitutional recognition is not only desirable but essential.
Having the status and functions of Local Government go unrecognised has meant that:
the Commonwealth and the States have tended to ignore its rights and responsibilities;
its capacities have been neither sufficiently developed nor utilised; and
its distinctive attributes of representativeness and responsiveness have not been fully exploited.
The absence of constitutional recognition has meant that Local Government has been unable to make its full contribution to the public benefit. The main impediments have been:
negative attitudes towards Local Government by other governments and the public; and
institutional procedures of other governments excluding Local Government participation.
Constitutional recognition must be more than `symbolic'-it must have the practical effect of overcoming the difficulties arising out of these perceptions and practices.
The basis of Commonwealth support for Local Government
The Commonwealth wants to help Local Government strengthen its ability to respond to local community needs and provide effective services.
The Commonwealth also wants to raise the status of Local Government to make it a genuine partner within the Federal system of Government.
The Prime Minister, the Hon. R. J. L. Hawke, AC MP, emphasised this in his speech to the Institute of Municipal Management in May 1984:

The Government has a strong commitment to raising the status and strengthening the capacity of Local Government. Our aim is a genuine partnership of the Commonwealth, States and Local Governments . . .

We want Local Government as a genuine partner in our three sphere system of government, co-operating in a broad range of functions to build a vigorous Australian community and economy from the grass roots up.

It is Commonwealth policy to achieve national economic and social objectives through developing effective and productive relations with Local Government. These relations should be developed in co-operation with the State and Territory Governments.
Such relations are essential to effective public sector administration. They also enable public benefit to be pursued with responsiveness and accountability.
To achieve this, OLG believes that these relations:
ought to be based upon mutual respect for the authority and responsibility each sector of government derives from the communities which elect them to govern; and

need to be characterised by consultative decision-making where the powers exercised by one sector of government impact upon another. Governments also need to work together where functional responsibilities interact or overlap.
Commonwealth support for constitutional recognition
Within the broad policy of support for Local Government, the Commonwealth is committed to achieving constitutional recognition of Local Government.
In his speech at the August 1986 presentation of the National Awards for Innovation in Local Government the Prime Minister said:

We have also encouraged and assisted Local Government in its rightful claim to be included in the Australian Constitution, supporting your representatives at the Brisbane meeting last year and ensuring that Local Government is adequately represented on the Constitutional Commission we established recently. We were heartened by the outcome for Local Government of the Brisbane convention. I am hopeful that firm recommendations will now come from the Constitutional Commission, enabling us to proceed to changes to the Constitution which will give Local Government proper recognition. There is no doubt in my mind that such recognition is long overdue.
Arguments for constitutional recognition
OLG's argument is based on two inter-related purposes. Constitutional recognition is needed:
to help strengthen the democratic potential of Local Government and to strengthen the system of representative government in Australia; and
to help clarify the roles and responsibilities of the different sectors of government so as to develop a more integrated, flexible and effective public sector.
Acknowledging democratic rights and responsibilities
Local Government bodies are distinguished from other authorities and agencies established under State or Territory legislation because they have the power to levy taxes and make by-laws.
More importantly they are democratically elected, while other bodies are appointed.
These characteristics define them as a sector of government.
The need for the Constitution to acknowledge Local Government's rights and responsibilities stems from its status as a sector of government.

Such a status has an important implication. While Local Government bodies have powers devolved to them by State and Territory legislatures, they also derive authority from the communities that elect them, to whom they are accountable, and whom they represent.
As a result, they have rights and responsibilities, which deserve special recognition within a democracy.

Constitutional recognition would authorise Local Government as a sector of government and establish its status as a party with which Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments ought to consult and negotiate.

Inclusion in the Constitution would obligate Local Government to adhere to the same democratic principles and practices governing elections of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments. In a democracy with interlocking legislative structures, all sectors of government should have a common democratic base regarding the value of each person's vote, each person's voting eligibility, and each person's voting obligation.
This would mean changing the Local Government electoral system in some States.

Acknowledging Local Government in the Constitution would give it more involvement in designing, co-ordinating and delivering government policies and programs. Recognition would ensure that Local Government's distinctive attributes could be used to the benefit of all sectors of government and the nation as a whole.
These attributes, which stem from Local Government's democratic base, are its ability to:
be flexible, and use its discretion in local decision making;
be responsive, both in providing services and in representing local conditions, needs and opinions; and
integrate and target public services locally, thereby increasing their effectiveness.
Enabling improved effectiveness in Government administration

Local Government has a significant role in the public administration of the nation. It accounts for about 6 per cent of total government outlays, collects about 4 per cent of total taxation revenue and employs about 9 per cent of the total government civilian work force.

Local Government has traditionally provided local property-related services. Increasingly, Local Government has been expanding into a broader range of social and economic functions, partly through its own initiatives and partly in response to State and Commonwealth initiatives.

Local Government presently shares responsibility with the Commonwealth and the States for a diversity of programs. It receives direct and indirect funding for these, including Commonwealth funds passed through the States under section 96 of the Constitution. These funds currently exceed $1000m per annum, including general purpose assistance and specific purpose payments for roads, child care, aged persons care, employment generation and other activities.

Changing social and economic conditions will continue to place pressure on Local Government to become involved in a wider range of social and economic functions. These pressures are likely to result from several factors:
governments are looking to cut public spending. At the same time economic and social infrastructure backlogs continue to increase;
community groups which perceive that other sectors of governments are not meeting their needs for services and facilities, are making more vocal claims for Local Government support; and
economic change is compelling Local Government to take initiatives to protect local communities.

Local Governments' responses to local community demands may conflict with State or Commonwealth objectives or programs. In addition, inter-government relationships are often characterised by overlaps and unclear responsibilities for program delivery, planning and administration. Commonwealth programs frequently fail to acknowledge the capacities and responsibilities of Local Government. Such difficulties in relationships harm overall effectiveness.
The functional responsibilities of the different sectors of government are changing, yet there is little, if any, co-ordination of local efforts with State and Commonwealth efforts.
It is vital that the nation's system of government administration takes advantage of the attributes of Local Government.
This would improve effectiveness, responsiveness and accountability, i.e. provide cost effective and better targeted programs.
Constitutional recognition of Local Government would enable the public sector to integrate its administrative effort by harnessing the contribution Local Government can make.
Suggested changes to the Constitution
OLG has recommended that the Constitution should recognise Local Government along the following lines:
(1) a requirement that Local Government be democratically elected should form part of any democratic rights provisions to be incorporated into the Constitution.
(2) a new clause be inserted into the Constitution in the following terms:

Subject to such terms and conditions as the Parliament of a State or the Northern Territory or in respect of any other Territory the Parliament of the Commonwealth may from time to time determine, every State and Territory of the Commonwealth shall provide for the establishment and continuance of Local Government bodies elected in accordance with such laws and empowered to administer and to make by-laws for their respective areas, to the extent and in accordance with the laws prescribed by the respective Parliaments in that behalf.
In effect this would:
acknowledge that Local Government's structure and powers should be matters for the State, Northern Territory and Commonwealth (in the case of other Territories) Parliaments to provide;
potentially allow Local Government wide ranging executive powers incidental to undertaking their statutory duties; and
by implication, provide Local Government with a degree of protection against arbitrary dismissal.
(3) a new clause be added to the Constitution which specifically defines the nature of Commonwealth-Local Government financial relationships in the following terms:
The Parliament may, after consultation with the relevant State or Territory Government, grant financial assistance to any Local Government body on such terms and conditions as Parliament thinks fit.
Such a clause would be additional to the current section 96.
In effect this would:
give the Commonwealth power to make financial grants to Local Government after consultation with the States, and
potentially allow the Commonwealth to consult with Local Government over providing such financial grants.
It is considered desirable that the preceding two clauses be inserted into a new Chapter of the Constitution dealing with Local Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to conclude with a few personal remarks. I have been a Minister in four Governments-two under Whitlam and two under Hawke. I have had an opportunity that few Ministers have had, namely, to create two new bureaucracies. The first was the Department of Urban and Regional Development in the 1970s. It was a magnificent body, even though it was destroyed by the Fraser Government. At least 15 of that Department's officers have been or are now permanent heads either in the Federal or the State bureaucracies, and they are carrying out progressive urban and regional development programs. The second bureaucracy was developed under the Hawke Government, and it is the local government and regional section within the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. It is a body which will survive and its officers are efficient, dedicated, committed public servants and I have no doubt that they will go far in the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984, the Prime Minister gave me the responsibility of Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. I was quite surprised, but delighted. It was the second time that, as a Minister, I had the administrative authority over Commonwealth properties. It is an important weapon which if properly used can be a catalyst in the development of our urban and regional communities. I tried to use that opportunity when I was the Minister responsible for the Commonwealth urban land use program. The permanent head was Ken Jones, who was a great public servant. It was a privilege to work with him. When he retired, I appointed Graham Glenn, who I believe will also become a great public servant. I have had the loyalty and commitment of the staff of DOLGAS right across the board-and it has been a great delight-from the top executives through to the Commonwealth drivers. It is interesting to note that I have been driven by Commonwealth drivers for 29 years, and I have had a blue with only one driver during that period. I am pleased to say that in the 2 1/2 years that I have been their Minister, there have been no strikes by Commonwealth drivers. They have always been able to consult with me and we have worked together in a progressive manner.

In all the years that I have been a Minister, my personal staff have been a strength and have worked with me. If a Minister is to make any impact in the administration or is to be briefed to go to Cabinet to make a real contribution, he needs a good Department and a good staff behind him in his struggle for what he believes to be justice for his Department. The staff can also assist to give him a broader overall vision. I have always been lucky to have good personal staff.

In a personal vein, I wish to place on record the contribution of the Prime Minister in his commitment to local government. He was the first Prime Minister to decide that there should be a local government department. However, it goes beyond that. The House knows that I am not pretending that the Prime Minister and I have not had our differences over the years, but in the matter of local government nobody in the Cabinet has been a stronger supporter of my local government portfolio. He has been able to understand and support our philosophical position and has supported the broadening of the base of local government-to give it greater breadth, to help its evolution and development and to strengthen it as part of the democratic process that is needed if we are to have a healthy society.

I speak to the elected representatives of local government whether they be Liberals, Nationals or independents; whether they be town clerks, engineers or people employed by local government-while Bob Hawke remains Prime Minister, local government will have a great supporter and will know that local government will progress under his leadership.

My last point is very personal. I am stepping down as a Minister. I made that decision more than two years ago. I was not pushed; I made the decision myself. I made the decision because I thought it was the right time for me to step aside. There are younger-I stress the word `younger'-people on the back bench who deserve a go, an opportunity to work as a Minister in the third Hawke Ministry. I believe that these younger members will inspire the third Hawke government after the election. They will make a fresher, more driving, more inspiring government. The third Hawke government will be a more progressive government.

I will go on to the back bench-but not to have a holiday. I have been a part of the leadership of our Party, the Australian Labor Party, for nearly 20 years. Being part of that leadership does inhibit one in some ways. I am not saying that when I am on the back bench I will take excessive liberties or freedoms. I have too much respect for the collectivism of the struggle of our Party and our movement. The labour movement has been good to me in all the years that I have been in politics. For the next three years in Parliament, and for the rest of my life, I will commit myself to the people. I believe the issue of nuclear disarmament is the most important struggle for the human race. That will be my important struggle. I will use the back bench and the forums open to me to fight for nuclear disarmament and peace in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not wish to respond to the statement but just to make a short statement in response to the latter part of the statement from the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren). In due course the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) will respond to the statement. As one of those who came into the House not long after the Minister, and one who is probably as diametrically opposed to him as anybody in this House in the areas of philosophy and politics, I would like to pay credit to the Minister for the remarks that he has made and for the contribution he has made for those people he represents. The Minister has made a valedictory with a difference. As he has just asserted, he is not leaving the Parliament; he is leaving the Ministry. While I suggest to him that all of his colleagues in the Hawke Ministry are about to do that, he at least has the decency, honesty and openness to acknowledge that he is now saying farewell to the front bench in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Tom Uren is a remarkable Australian. He is one of the members of a generation who served their country during World War II. Having been imprisoned as a prisoner of war and having been through all the horrors of the Burma railroad and all the horrors of the four years of his life that he gave to the service of this country, he then came as a returned serviceman to stand for the Australian Labor Party. Of course, he has been successful as a Federal member for so many years since then.

There was quite a generation of people who came here after World War II and made their contribution. Tom Uren from this place and Senator Sir John Carrick, who is about to retire from the Senate, are the two who remain in Parliament from that generation of Australians who were prisoners of war, who came to this place and who not only gave their service during wartime but have significantly made a contribution during peacetime. On behalf of the National Party of Australia, and I believe of all members on this side of the House, I pay credit to you, Minister, for the way in which you have committed your life to Australia's cause. Whilst we might disagree with you on so many issues, we respect the fact that you have done so much in the exercise and towards the fulfilment of your beliefs. Obviously, we wish you well, albeit that we hope that it will not even be on the back bench as I would far prefer to see one of the coalition parties represent your seat. But, even in your seat, I rather doubt it. I wish you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I endorse the remarks of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) on behalf of all my colleagues in the Liberal Party of Australia. Today the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) has brought down a statement on local government. I will say something about the detail of that in a moment. But the Minister started by talking about the importance of local government. In his last address as a Minister, he talked about an important institution in Australia and, by putting that emphasis in his last remarks, he places on record the fact that he has been concerned about Australia, its institutions and where we are going in the future. Of course, as we go into an election campaign, there will be many arguments about what we all want for Australia. We can debate those issues. But there are times such as this when we can recognise that there is much that joins all of us together as Australians. I conclude my introductory remarks by paying our respects to the Minister and acknowledging the service that he has given as a Minister of the Crown. Those people listening today should be pleased to know that so many members of the House have been present to hear the Minister's remarks and the responses.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning specifically to the statement, it paints a fairly rosy picture of local government. I want to address some remarks to some of the issues raised by the Minister because, whilst we may both emphasise the importance of local government, there are matters of considerable disagreement between us about how we should proceed on that course. The Minister talked about constitutional reform. In that regard, I have to say that in Victoria, the State from which I come, no amount of constitutional reform would have stood in the way of the proposals of the Cain Government to amalgamate local councils against their will. When we talk about local councils, we are talking about participatory democracy at the grass roots level. I know that that is a cliche in some senses but, as one who has participated as a councillor for a number of years in a small rural municipality, I know the importance of local government and I know what great significance it can have and be to the people residing in the respective municipalities.

The attitude of the Australian Labor Party to local government has had some considerable deficiencies. As an example of that, I cite Victoria, where small municipalities were to be done away with by a government determined on amalgamation against the wishes of the people. It was only the great campaign run by the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, Mr Kennett, and the shadow Minister for Local Government, Mr Cooper, that finally brought the Victorian Cain Government to its senses and to back down on its proposals to amalgamate local government.

The Minister referred to a number of other policy areas of which this Government claims to be proud as it goes into the next election. Honourable members will not believe it, but the first achievement for which this Government claims pride is that it established another Federal bureaucracy. That is nothing to be proud of. Under this Government, we have seen nothing but more bureaucrats in the Federal bureaucracy, all paid for by the taxpayers. We have seen much too much in the way of extra commissions, sporting commissions, health commissions and all of those things with functions which had not been the responsibility of Federal government and which have led only to massive duplication and additional bureaucracy in Canberra. So, I do not welcome that statement and it does not have any support from the Liberal Party.

The Minister also said that this Government would provide stability and predictability in funding for local government. Well, I nearly fell off my chair when I heard that one. It was this Government that introduced legislation to abandon the commitment of 2 per cent of income tax receipts for local government. Where is the stability and predictability in that? This Government left local government high and dry, not knowing what the commitment would be from the Federal Government. This Government cannot get away with statements about predictability and stability. But it is not just a question of the 2 per cent commitment. Even in the last few weeks, with the May economic statement, the Government has saved a few dollars for itself at the expense of local government. Twenty-seven million dollars is required to finance the costs that the Commonwealth has passed on to local government. As we move into this election campaign, local government councillors around Australia will not sit down and accept easily, this Federal Government talking about predictability of funding, after they have just had this slap from it in pulling back its cash.

In the May economic statement this Government withdrew not just the financing costs but a whole range of other activities in which local government plays an important role. We saw a cutback in the forward Estimates for the home and community care program. People who have been in local government will know of its important role in some help. That role is now being cut back by this Government.

Roads are also an important part of local government. My grandfather was a councillor, a municipal engineer and the first Shire President on Phillip Island. In those days, of course, local government had a primary responsibility, as it still does, for road funding. What have we seen from this Federal Government? Nothing but cutbacks in road funding. This is not the sort of issue that might go on the front pages of the local papers, but the people who drive on our roads, and that is most people in Australia, will know, recognise and even feel, as they drive on unsealed roads or on roads that have not been repaired, that this Government has been cutting back on road funding. In the May economic statement $180m was sliced off the Forward Estimates for road funding. That was just a continuation in the drop in real funds for roads. In 1983-84, $1,359m was spent on roads in real terms, and in 1986-87 only $1,152m was spent in real terms; a big drop. No wonder we are having an early election. Where is the Government's Budget? Why are we going to an election early? Is it to avoid revealing the Budget? Of course it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your tax policy?
—The Government will see our tax policy but we will never see its Budget. The one good thing about its next Budget is--
—Order! The honourable member will address the Chair and be less provocative in his speech.

—The one good thing about Labor's 1987-88 Budget is that the Australian people will never see it, because on 11 July they will cast their votes to throw the Government out of office. There is no question about that whatsoever. Who started the bicentennial road development program? It was not the Australian Labor Party. It is not interested in roads. It was started by the Fraser Government with a 2 cents per litre levy. Labor indexed it, but what did it do with the money? Did it go towards roads? No, Labor pinched that and it went into general revenue to establish the bureaucracies which the Minister has been talking about. In fact, with the indexed amount we have seen another $192m pinched from vital road funding projects around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister also talked about the need for skilled labour. That is another issue in this election, because one of the major issues in Australia today is the extent of union power. One of the problems we have with this Government is the extent to which the Australian Council of Trade Unions controls everything that it does. I am surprised that the Minister pulled that one up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did Joh tell you to say that?

—Joh has not spoken to me. I do not believe there will be a Joh candidate in Flinders, but if there is a National Party of Australia candidate I will welcome him, because we work very much hand in hand with the National Party. We have a great record of working in co-operation with it and I took forward to a coalition with the National Party after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister talked about funding for foreshore developments and the beautification of recreational areas on our foreshores. That is a sore point in my electorate of Flinders because of a proposal concerning an area of Point Nepean, which was supposedly to be transferred from the Commonwealth Government to the State Government. That proposal is not floating around in the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services but in the Department of Finance. The proposal is to chop up an area, which is to be part of a national park, and to flog it off as a subdivision. The Minister will hear more about that from the people of Flinders because they will not sit back and see this Government attempt to fix its deficit problems, caused by its own massive spending, by flogging off pieces of real estate in their electorate.

There are many other issues where the impact of Federal Government decisions on local government has not been advantageous to the ratepayers of Australia. I mention as an example interest rates. In the last election campaign the Government promised that there would be a reduction in interest rates and they have gone up ever since. Interest rates are a major component in the costs of many councils. I remember the classic statement of the Minister that he would do something about the fringe benefits tax for disadvantaged councils. This is another area where decisions of the Federal Labor Government have impacted adversely on local government.

Lastly, I mention the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. That important body was established by the Fraser Government in 1977 as a result of an election promise which we kept. It provided a forum for the three levels of government, local, State and Federal, to get together and talk about joint problems on an equal footing. In fact, the Minister was a member of that council. It was a sad day when this Government scrapped the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations.

I conclude by saying this: Local government is important. We on this side of the House genuinely believe in its development. We strongly believe in providing decent, reliable and predictable support for local government. It may not be a big issue in the forthcoming Federal election, but we on this side of the House will continue to stand strongly by local government and to give it the support and recognition that it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-May I first of all say how very much we-and by `we' I mean the members of the Canberra Committee on Local Government-have appreciated the fact that we could always approach the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) and his departmental officers. We realise that there was a genuine acceptance of the fact that we had a fairly heavy responsibility. The Canberra Committee was appointed by the local government movement in each State. It has been in existence for many years and I have had the privilege of chairing it for the last 12, as the Minister would know. We feel that it has been a fairly valuable means of liaison on a strictly non-political basis, and I say that in all sincerity, between the local government movement and this place and all that happens at a senior government level.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pay tribute to two successive directors of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations, Andy Walls and the present director, Llois Cutts. She is a highly dedicated person. I think her staff and her research officer have done a really splendid job. I also want to pass on my thanks to the people who are out on the hustings; that is those in local government, particularly those who constantly attend regional conferences and who do everything possible to establish a meaningful decentralisation of government. I do not think we ever pause long enough on this. I am sometimes very distressed to find that in all parties there seems to be not so much a lack of appreciation but a lack of understanding of the huge contribution that people in local government make to their own communities, to their own regions and, more particularly, to the nation, because in the aggregate they do a fantastically wonderful job.

I would like to dwell briefly on a matter mentioned by the Minister in his statement, and that is the constitutional recognition of local government. Just how long are we going to have to wait for this? Surely to goodness if we are sincere, if any party is sincere, in our desire to have genuine decentralisation and to keep our fingers on the pulse of what is really happening in this nation, we should realise that recognition should flow to the people who are responsible for that activity. The activity I refer to is the decentralisation of government. We who have been in local government-I have spent my entire life in local government in one capacity or another-realise that local government representatives are like firemen or politicians; they are on the job 24 hours a day.

I conclude by mentioning one or two other points. I get very concerned when I see promulgated policies which would have outside contractors come into an area in which the local work force is so dependent on the local authority for work. The argument has always been that one gets much more efficiency from some great contractor than from the local work force. I will argue against that till the end of my days. I could quote local authority after local authority-honourable members should keep in mind that my finger is on the pulse of the local government movement throughout Australia-which is highly efficient and gets the best day's work for a day's pay from its employees. When outside contractors come in to do the job they bring in strangers and displace half the local work force. If a little place such as Barcaldine lost its work force it would almost close the town down. I could mention other specific cases also. I stand very firmly by the principle that local government should employ local people and not go for outside contractors. We should not listen to the argument about efficiency; it is nonsense.

The local government movement throughout Australia is distressed by the May economic statement not only because of the $27m reduction in funds for local authorities but also because of the flow-over of other measures. We are all very curious to know how this $1 billion that the States must save will affect local authorities. I must say to the Minister that our Canberra committee that liaises between government and the local government movement appreciates the fact that there has not been a great rush to bring in the requirements of the report of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance. The committee expressed to the Minister a wish that any action on various recommendations of the Self report be steady as you go because it is very necessary to assess how the regions and individual local authorities feel. It is working out that way and we hope it continues.

May I express a personal view, as did the Minister. It has been my great privilege to serve as chairman of that committee for the last 10, 12 or 14 years. I am very happy to have contributed to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—He may proceed.

That is not my understanding. In discussion with the Minister's office this morning, it was my understanding that the Minister was disposed not to allow debate on those amendments. In view of the legislative program for today and the fact that the Government has the numbers, I saw no point in contesting the matter and, subsequently, confirmed this in a brief discussion with the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—He may proceed.

—In relation to the matters raised by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), I would like briefly to make some points. Firstly, agreement was reached on the way the amendments were to be handled. There were two conversations this morning, not one.
