SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the fact that honourable members had already debated their views on these matters at some length and would have been going over them again, and except for considerations of time, it was not of concern to the Government whether or not the matter was debated. I accept that the honourable member for Deakin may well have misunderstood the position. He has given his version of what happened, but I must say that, as far as I am concerned, it is a misrepresentation of the position. There were two conversations and members of the Opposition agreed to debate not proceeding. In fact, it was a matter for them at that stage and not for the Government.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cash Transaction Reports Bill that is before the Parliament today is one of a series of Bills that the Government has sought to introduce in its continued attack and fight against organised crime in Australia. The honourable member for Maribynong (Mr Griffiths) detailed a number of initiatives which the Government has taken in the fight against organised crime. I do not propose to go into any of those initiatives in any detail. Suffice it to say, however that as recently as a couple of days ago the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill was introduced for debate in this place. The Proceeds of Crime Bill has also been debated in this place. We have been well aware of the contribution that has been made by the National Crime Authority. I mention also the legislation for extradition proceedings. We have seen an increase in resources for the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Customs Service. All of this is directed towards improving the facilities of Australian Public Service authorities, police forces and so on to fight against organised crime in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I find myself in absolutely no disagreement with the comments made in this debate so far by honourable members on both sides of the House. There is a great desire and willingness by all members of this place to ensure that legislative framework and mechanisms are put in place to fight against organised crime in Australia. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) went to some pains to point out that that was certainly his personal view and the view on his side of the House. I appreciate that.

The Cash Transaction Reports Bill does a number of things. Initially, and most importantly, it requires that financial institutions verify the identity of persons opening and operating accounts. That, in itself, is a very important factor. It will make it more difficult for persons to open accounts in fictitious names or to use accounts in a company or a business name to disguise their connection with the account and, therefore, to cloud the money trail. Over a number of years we have seen the difficulty that police forces, the Australian Taxation Office and other institutions responsible for taxation gathering and revenue raising on behalf of the Australian people have in following money trails. This legislation goes part of the way to overcoming those difficulties. It has to be remembered that cash transactions are very difficult to follow.

This Bill seeks to provide an opportunity-through having to identify persons opening and operating accounts-for a legislative framework and facilities to be put in place so that verification becomes necessary. The honourable member for Maribyrnong raised the point that had the Australia Card been put in place a further mechanism to clamp down on fraud and cheating would have been available to the people of Australia and certainly the banking industry of Australia because a ready form of identification and reference would have been made available.

We have seen the double standards of those opposite in this case. They come in here and profess their concern about supporting legislation, revisions and so on which are aimed at fighting organised crime. At the same time, one of the most important and effective Bills to go down that track has been denied the Government and the people of Australia. Instead, we have had a display of double standards.

In talking of double standards, I take the opportunity to raise a couple of points that have emerged from the other side on this issue. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and the honourable member for Denison said that this Bill should be delayed and referred to a committee; a joint select committee was proffered as an appropriate way to investigate what has been proposed in the legislation. It is curious that this should have been put forward by the honourable member for North Sydney and supported by the honourable member for Denison because two days ago in this place, when we were debating the Telecommunications (Interceptions) Amendment Bill, it was clearly demonstrated that the provisions of that legislation had in fact been referred to a joint select committee which I had the honour to chair. Yet the Government was accused of delaying tactics and of not fighting the good fight against organised crime by putting that legislation in place straight away and providing power to intercept telecommunications in criminal matters in Australia.

That shows the double standards. On the one hand, the Opposition is saying that something like the Cash Transaction Report Bill should be referred to a joint select committee for further investigation. On the other hand, it said-when a Bill that provided for the devolution of powers from the Federal Government to the States for telephone tapping, which would involve questions of invasions of privacy and a whole range of other matters, was referred to a joint select committee which investigated the possibility of extending the power to tap phones to a range of offences other than narcotics offences-`That is wrong. You should not do that. It should, in fact, have been considered only here in the Parliament and the legislation put in place with telephone tapping being made a matter of course.' The double standard is quite evident.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Denison also talked about corruption and about corruption in New South Wales. He talked about corruption under an Australian Labor Party government in the last 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he did not mention Askin.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Lowe rightly points out, there was no mention of the Ash Street boys, no mention of Sir Robert Askin and what he did or of the corruption that emerged in New South Wales under him. But more importantly, there was no indication of what is going on in Queensland, where we have the ridiculous position of Ministers travelling to work past brothels and saying that they do not even know the brothels exist. We have police commissioners and police officers saying: `It doesn't happen in Queensland-no way. Brisbane? No, no way. No, we are clean; don't you worry about that'. Absolute rubbish! Yet the honourable member has the temerity to stand up in here with feigned indignation, with a pretence of moral outrage and say that this Government and, indeed, governments in New South Wales under the banner of the Australian Labor Party are not committed to the fight against organised crime. Coming from New South Wales, I reject that totally, because I have had extensive discussions, in the course of the investigations of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception, with the Commissioner of Police in New South Wales, whom I find to be an extremely honourable man who is comitted to the fight against crime. We have seen evidence of that since he has been in power. I am convinced that the Minister for Police and Emergency Services in New South Wales, Mr George Paciullo, is similarly committed to the fight against organised crime and would take any opportunity presented to his Government or the New South Wales Police Force to get involved in that fight. It was the Premier of New South Wales who wrote to the Committee saying: `Yes, we would certainly embrace the opportunity to fight crime using telephone tapping as a facility.'

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, the sort of talk that comes from those opposite and the scurrilous attempt by the honourable member for Denison a little earlier to introduce extraneous material into this debate without going into the substance and without giving names-as he normally does-is, I believe, demeaning to this place. He came across here and said: `I might say a couple of things that might raise the hackles of those on this side of the place.' In my response, I said, `I am not involved in personal attacks.' He said: `No, I don't believe in that, either.' So what does he do? He does the same thing-he launches into a personal attack. This Bill is most important. It is part of the package this Government has introduced to fight against organised crime and I commend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 106a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) condemns the Government for its laissez-faire attitude to industrial disputation in Australia's export industries, particularly in relation to the appalling industrial record of Australia's coal mining unions, and

(2) calls on the Government to adopt the Federal National Party's policy of introducing essential services legislation to protect Australia's vital export industries from industrial relations blackmail.

This is the last day of the session-and I believe the last day of a Hawke Labor Government-and it is appropriate that we end the session and begin the election campaign on industrial matters. I gave notice of this motion on 1 May 1987 and it is appropriate to recall how much has happened since then in this regard. I refer particularly to the Hancock report of the Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems and the industrial legislation that followed two years after its presentation. In those two years there was no consultation with the employer groups. The legislation was prepared in haste and allowed to lay on the table for only 11 days before the Government felt that the reaction by the employer groups and people around Australia would not allow it to be a convenient mechanism to go into an election. That was the first we heard of an election.

Many of my comments must be related to the Industrial Relations Bill 1987. It would cause further disruption of business, of procedures and the export enhancement that we seek. There will be further debate on the Bill after the election; the Bill is only being waived to make way for the election that is about to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will never get it in.

—No, but I think it is appropriate that we deal with it here. The Bill would have prevented employers from seeking legal relief from illegal trade union activity before ordinary courts. It would have effectively placed unions above the law. That is a commentary on the manner in which this Government gives laws to this country-some have to obey but others are above the law. The Bill would have increased union power to the detriment of employers, the Australian economy and our export markets. The National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia and virtually every employer organisation around Australia opposed the Bill upon its presentation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill would have established an Industrial Relations Commission and Labour Court. The Industrial Relations Commission would have been able to deal with all industrial disputes between employers and employees, giving it unprecedented power. The Labour Court would have replaced the industrial division of the Federal Court of Australia. The Bill would have stopped employers and their employees from opting out of the system that has accumulated around us by entering into voluntary employment agreements. The Bill would have protracted the arbitration process and would have sought to alter remedies available both at common law and under the Trade Practices Act. It would have given the Commission powers to enforce compulsory unionism, and I would have thought that was basically against our Australian precepts. This would have been done by including preference clauses in awards and allowing closed shops. The Bill would have given the Labour Court power to reinstate employees and award back pay and compensation and the Commission would have had power to award strike pay in certain health and safety disputes-a move which would have caused a rash of disputes but, more importantly, it would have left the door open for other claims for strike pay to be made in other circumstances.

The Bill sought to restrict employment relations by not allowing employers and employees to opt out of the arbitration system. It would have really tied them right into it by making voluntary agreements between employers and employees without the approval of the unions illegal. It would have provided for employers and unions to enter into non-viable fixed term binding agreements certified by the commissions. It would have created an enormous bureaucracy to process the necessary certifications and it would have made a precondition for certification that such agreements contain grievance procedures within themselves.

It would have put obstacles in the way of employers, which comes back to the base of this address. The Commission would have been able to refuse to deal with a case until a grievance procedure had been complied with. An employer faced with a primary dispute would not have been able to get a common law injunction against a federally registered union. The employer would have had to apply to a Commissioner for a direction prohibiting the industrial action or obstructive conduct. If the Commission was not able to resolve the dispute quickly the Full Bench would have been able to issue a certificate, potentially drawing out all the proceedings. The case would have then gone to the Labour Court, which would have been able to issue an injunction to enforce the direction. The employer faced with a secondary boycott would not have been able to resort to any State or common law remedy of any kind provided by sections 45d or 45e of the Trade Practices Act. Again, if an employer wished to use sections 45d and 45e against the union he would first have to refer the dispute to the Commission for conciliation.

When the Commission under these circumstances was satisfied that it could not stop the dispute quickly, it could then issue a certificate, but as I mentioned before that would be a rather drawn out process. The employer would then have been able to proceed with an action in the Labour Court. But this is the hang up: If at that stage the union stopped its boycott just prior to such issuance but after causing considerable damage-and these damages could result in a loss of millions of dollars in export trade-no certificate would have been issued and the loss would have been irrecoverable in that court. Even if the matter were ultimately litigated successfully, an employer would not be able to recover his costs against the union. But the union would be able to recover its costs against an applicant where the Labour Court considered that the proceedings had been instituted without reasonable cause. Continued breach of a Labour Court direction would be grounds for deregistration, but the grounds are diluted-and even then the court would have been given excessive discretion.

All of this adds up to a time consuming series of obstacles which would have been open to massive abuse and exploitation by the unions. In the particular cases I mentioned these delays would have involved strikes in the field. The loss of production and the effect on our reputation world-wide as a reliable supplier, particularly in the coal products we handle, would have affected our inputs in other ways. It could have all meant a major interference with industry in Australia. It would have meant a lack of productivity and export opportunities would have been lost to our international competitors.

I turn to compulsory unionism. This is particularly relevant in the coal mining industry. The Industrial Relations Commission would have had the power to include preference clauses for unionists in awards, which would have led to closed shops. The Bill failed to provide penalties for union attempts to enforce compulsory unionism and an employee who objected to joining a union would have been able to apply to the Industrial Registrar for a certificate; but just objecting to it would not do. An employer would have had to prove that being a member of a union was against his conscience or religious conviction. Even the union would have been entitled to attend the hearing and a union official would have been able to cross-examine the employee. If an employee had been granted a certificate he would then have had to pay his annual union fee to the Government. So a successful conscientious objection case would still have ended in the payment of that fee. There would have been no right of appeal on either the determination or the fee. The certificate would have lasted for a maximum of 12 months but maybe for a lesser period, after which the persons would have had to go through the whole process again. At any time unions would have been able to inform on a conscientious objector, in other words pimp on them, to the Registrar, who would then have had the power to revoke the certificates.

All this flies in the face of what the public thinks about unionism in Australia. A survey carried out this year by Roy Morgan Research showed that 69 per cent of Australians think that trade unions have too much power, yet this legislation would have entrenched and deepened that power.

Eighty-one per cent of Australians think that union membership should be voluntary and yet the Bill sets out to give a preference and to make unionism compulsory. Fifty per cent of Australians believe wages and conditions should be decided between employers and employees. I turn to the current situation with the coal industry unions in Queensland and the rest of Australia. The Government member who will be following me in this debate keeps a very watchful eye on it. The coal mining industry in Australia probably has the worst record of industrial disputes because it is tied to the Coal Industry Tribunal, an independent tribunal set up by an agreement between New South Wales and the Commonwealth. It is a one commissioner tribunal. As far as I can see, there is no enforcement of decisions by the Tribunal Commissioner.

I give this example: A good 12 months ago, against every principle of indexation which the Government of the day was then enforcing, a $60 increase was granted to employees-and that was much less than the amount that was initially sought. It was granted to achieve industrial peace. In other words, the mine owners sacrificed a lot in that decision as far as payment was concerned to make sure they got on with the job of producing coal and selling to our international buyers. Industrial peace did not occur; there were record strikes. Over the last two years there has been a 181 per cent increase in working days lost in the coal industry. This is three, four or five times higher than the Australian average. And this is after the CIT had made that ruling.

Those strikes centred on matters that had nothing to do with award conditions or the work place. Most of them were to try to put pressure on the Government and on the miners to agree to the establishment of a coal marketing authority and to bring back more regulation to the industry. Therefore, the industrial peace sought to enhance our exports did not occur.

Questions on the matter were asked in the Senate and also in this House last month. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), questioned about the national coal marketing authority, was a little forthcoming but his answer was not sufficient to satisfy this House, for another question on the subject was asked of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) on the same day. There was a glorious opportunity for both those Ministers to say to the coal mining unions: `Enough is enough. There is a difficulty on our export market; there is a difficulty of blending; there is a difficulty between the undergrounds and the open cuts. That market out there is wide open to all of our competitors. Do not let us put any other authority in the way of the free marketing of our coal'. But they did not say that and even at this time there is industrial disputation. It may not be surfacing at this moment. Its aim is to establish a marketing authority which will tie the hands of every coal miner throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It will. It will enhance the position of the unions which the Government's legislation provides. If the honourable member does not know that maybe he should not be participating in this debate. This industrial turmoil involves bully tactics on the mine fields. I know of strikes which were called basically to decrease the amount of overtime work from 48 to 42 hours. Unions went to a selected part of the mine fields, took a vote which was not favourable, but went ahead and called a strike. When the miners on the field said that they wanted a full vote taken the unions backed off. What I am talking about today is not the miner in the field, not the worker in the factory but those people who have demanded of this Government-the union leaders, the Australian Council of Trade Unions-legislation that is probably unique in the world. I understand that the only other country that has a centralised system is Sweden. We would not want Sweden's system. The Australian taxpayer spent $80,000 sending a trade delegation to Europe because of the deal being made on wage indexation. We should have been concentrating on the markets in South East Asia and the Pacific rim. People in these areas are our competitors; they are the people who benefit from the costs of our coal mining and from our industrial situation.

SPEECH.PARA: If Australians have not got the message now, they never will. If this nation does not export profitably Australia's economic performance will be severely diminished. There is a very close relationship between the standard of living of every Australian and profitable exports. Australian coal exports account for $5.3 billion a year-15 per cent of total exports. The disputes that I mentioned earlier involved about 2.6 million tonnes of coal, representing a loss of approximately $130m in export earnings. Today's Australian reports that coal miners fear an imminent loss of 3,000 jobs and 15 mines. Unions are saying that some action has to be taken now and not 12 months down the track but I suggest that the unions should have taken action 12 months or 24 months ago to prevent the problem. We are the most efficient producer of coal in the world-I have no doubts about that-but what is hampering us on the world markets is an industrial system that will not be dictated to by governments, courts or anyone else.

I turn to the costs of the miners. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, is instrumental in this. The miners of Australia have to fight against the taxes imposed by the Government. I mention the fringe benefit tax as one. But the far more severe burden which the Government has imposed is the record rates of interest. We cannot compete against our international competitors with our industrial situation and the Government imposed costs.

I think it is appropriate that we understand the constitutional arbitration powers of the Commonwealth Government. There is no doubt that the Commonwealth Government has constitutional, executive and legislative powers which directly affect our industrial relations, our trade unions and our employer organisations. These powers are manifested in the Constitution in the following ways: The conciliation and arbitration of disputes extends beyond the limit of any one State. This is in section 51. The Commonwealth has the power to regulate employment of Commonwealth public servants and employment within Commonwealth Territories. The Constitution also provides for the regulation of employment in the course of or incidental to the exercise of other powers of the Commonwealth, such as the international and interstate trade and commerce power and the corporations power.

Since Federation, because of a very early decision, industrial relations and the processes which I just enumerated have had special consideration. They have been taken away from the courts of the land. Contract law, the laws of fair trade and interstate trading are referred to in the Constitution. Yet we have set up a special court. We have set up a special lot of people prepared to carve a niche in this country and to keep industrial disputation at a high level. I have moved the motion because of the necessity for the House to address this matter because of its implications for the economic future of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government totally rejects the proposition that has been put forward by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). I am sure that he firmly believes in what he said, which reflects a National Party of Australia policy on the Australian coal industry. The Australian coal industry is unique and it has some very special problems. The difficulties that are confronting that industry, I believe, have to be fairly faced by every person in Australia at present-and certainly every member of this House. I shall refer very briefly to those particular problems, which pick up on a couple of the issues that the honourable member for Dawson raised. The first is the number of days lost through industrial disputation in the coal industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The coal mining unions would be the first to admit that their record is not outstanding. But we have to understand some of the reasons behind the industrial disputes. The first and foremost is job security. The honourable member for Dawson mentioned reports in today's Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian with respect to potential mine closures and the loss of some 3,000-odd jobs in the coal industry. That is not fallacy, that is not some fairyland statement, that is fact in Australia at present. Australia is now competing on the world market against many other producers from overseas countries who are prepared to sell coal at any price so that they can boost their levels of foreign revenue. I refer specifically to China. China currently exports something like 10 million tonnes of coal annually but it wants to boost that to 30 million tonnes annually by 1990-only three years up the track. It is prepared to sell its coal at ridiculous prices because it needs the foreign capital to do other things. South Africa has costs of production far less than those in Australia. The producers in South Africa are not as efficient as Australian producers but their costs are reduced because of lower labour costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Slave labour.

—It certainly borders on that. Other countries with untapped resources are coming on stream, such as Colombia and potentially Indonesia. We are going to have to compete effectively in an oversaturated world market. We hope that Australian producers and the miners working in the industry in Australia recognise the difficulties facing the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I said in relation to industrial disputes in the Australian coal industry that the major cause of concern at present is job security and the future of the coal industry. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and I know only too well the problems that have faced the coal industry and the concerns about job security that presently exist. Only a week and a half ago he and I were both involved in very delicate negotiations with representatives from the coal mining unions and the mine operators on the South Coast with respect to the Avon and Yellow- rock collieries. Those collieries closed, throwing 206 coal miners on to the unemployment scrap heap. The Joint Coal Board in New South Wales, the national liaison committee of the combined mining unions and governments, recognise that unless things change in Australia this abhorrent occurrence could be repeated. The necessity for change does not exist only in Australia but is world-wide.

The honourable member for Dawson mentioned marketing arrangements and how they could lead to improvements in Australia. We do not hold the same view, that just open slather without any forms of control whatsoever will solve the problem. This Government, in September last year, moved partially down that road by removing the necessity for mine operators to obtain administrative guidelines in terms of pricing in their negotiations overseas. What we did not remove, and I think it is worth restating, is the power to control export licences which resides with the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins).

In fact, a committee which I chair, on this side of the House, was heavily involved in devising the sorts of national interest guidelines that should exist that would enable the Minister for Trade to determine what sort of matters he would take into consideration when determining whether or not an overseas coal sale contract should be approved. Previously a whole series of coal company negotiators have sat in the first class compartments in the front of the jumbo jets, full of camaraderie, going to Japan or to other countries. While they are in the aeroplane they say: `This is what we will do. We will all stick together, mates'. When they get there and the Japanese or whoever turn the screws on one of them they all break.

TALK.START.PARA: —They pick them off.

—Yes, one after another. There has been example after example of that happening. It has happened most recently with the steaming coal negotiations in Japan. Yet in the Japanese case, a conglomerate organisation acts on behalf of all the Japanese buyers. Yet if one suggests that we have at least a co-ordinated buying and selling arrangement people start to go `Shock, horror'. If we talk about Australian producers finally staying together and negotiating as one instead of breaking and one taking a low price, which shoots everyone to pieces, we find representatives in Australia for the major Japanese buyers phoning us and saying: `My God, you are not talking about a national marketing authority, are you? You are not going to allow them to do that? How are we going to squeeze the best possible price out of the Australian producers? How are we going to screw down the Australian coal industry if you do that?'. I think all of us here have a lot of national pride. As the honourable member for Dawson rightly pointed out, the coal mining industry contributed $5.3 billion to Australia's export income earnings. That is extremely significant so all of us, from both sides of the House, should be doing everything we can to ensure that the industry survives and is effective and efficient. I endorse comments about efficiency in the coal mining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the events at the Yellowrock and Avon collieries last week in Wollongong. The collieries did not close because of efficiency arguments. Honourable members should talk to Mr Ian Dunlop, the Managing Director of Austen and Butta Ltd. He will tell them that the mines were not closed on the grounds of efficiency or work practices; he highly praised the operations of those two pits. They were forced to close purely and simply because the product that they were trying to sell on the market no longer had a buyer. Its ash content was too high and the stockpiles were starting to rise and no one wanted to buy it, not even for steaming coal. No one in Australia-not this Government, not the Opposition government if it ever came to power, not the coal mining unions and, indeed, not the producers-is going to be able to say to overseas buyers: `You have got to buy this even though its intrinsic qualities are not any good'. I think that has to be recognised by people in the industry.

The honourable member for Dawson referred to the Coal Industry Tribunal decision of last year. I do not believe the difficulties in the coal mining industry at present-certainly on the industrial relations side-can be apportioned to any one sector. I think there is probably fault on both sides and I think the parties that are involved in the coal industry are willing to admit that there have been some problems in the past. If they recognise those problems exist and come together in a reasonable atmosphere to discuss those difficulties resolution may not be as far away as we have all been led to believe. It has been my experience in working closely with the people who work in the coal industry, particularly those whose job security is threatened, that they are willing to make sacrifices. The miners are willing to make sacrifices. The coal mine operators are also willing to make certain sacrifices and I think we have to try to bring the two parties together.

I have been involved in discussions with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) and the coal mining unions. There was a willingness to discuss all of these sorts of issues, to put work practices and a range of issues on the table for discussion. If that offer were taken up many of these difficulties could be overcome. A meeting that was convened in Sydney yesterday by the Joint Coal Board to look at the problems in the coal industry moved somewhere down the track. At least it got all the parties there. It had representatives of the New South Wales Coal Association and the Miners Federation and all the other union groups and State and Federal Government departments responsible for the coal industry. They all sat in a room to look at the problems in the industry. Now that they have been apprised of those real difficulties, they have gone away and will meet again in two weeks time. For the benefit of Australia, we all hope that some solutions can be put on the table and discussed.

The motion before the House today refers to essential services legislation. My colleague, the honourable member for Throsby, will pick that up shortly, but I think it is worth making a couple of comments about industrial relations in Queensland. As the honourable member for Dawson related, in recent times legislation enacted in Queensland has been aimed at stifling the trade union movement and taking away the right to strike and basic responsibilities and rights of trade unionists and workers. That, of course, is very inconsistent with accepted standards in democratic countries. The Queensland Industrial (Commercial Practices) Act of 1984, an amendment Act of 1985 and a series of other Acts, have been condemned outright by a number of people. They are unjust and go against a series of International Labour Organisation conventions-29, 105, 87, 98-the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. But, of course, those conventions were thrown out in Queensland and this legislation was put in.

The term `draconian' is often used in this place to describe legislation. I can see no more fitting description to apply to this piece of Queensland legislation. We have seen it criticised from one end of the country to the other-not only in this place, not only by the Australian Labor Party. We saw it criticised in Queensland by an assistant to the Anglican Archbishop of Brisbane and by the President of the Lutheran Church in Queensland. The Premier of Queensland is a member of that church. We have seen it criticised by the Catholic Church's Commission for Peace and Justice. We have seen it criticised from one end of the country to the other.

This Government has endeavoured to do something about it. As honourable members will know, it was announced two days ago in this place, and simultaneously in the Senate, that this Government will launch a High Court challenge to the validity of that legislation. That is going to have important ramifications not only for the general thrust of the trade union movement in Queensland but, in particular, for the coal industry. We know that Joh was waiting for the coal mining industry to blow up because he wanted to use it as an issue in the forthcoming Federal election. He has been denied that because people in the trade union movement in Queensland have displayed a responsible attitude in the face of provocation at every level by that Government. They have said: `No, we are not prepared to do that. We are going to take a responsible attitude'.

The motion before us today, which I have indicated we totally reject, suggests that this Government has adopted a laissez-faire attitude to industrial relations. That is nonsense. Through a non-confrontationist approach to industrial relations this Government has lowered the levels of industrial disputation generally in Australia to all time record levels. The trade union movement has been responsible. Real concerns have been expressed about the future of the coal mining industry. People are concerned about the future of their children and families because of the social destruction that exists in coal mining communities when the mines go to the wall. If one wants to see any of these communities that have suffered one should look at some of the devastation caused in the early 1980s on the south coast and in the Illawarra; look at the problems that occurred in the Burragorang Valley until it was revitalised; look at what has happened in the Western Districts of Victoria; look at what could happen in Ipswich because of Joh's decision to close the power station there and throw coal miners out of work from a couple of the mines that supply the coal. This is going to have ramifications that will stretch the length and breadth of Australia. We reject the proposition that was put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite evident in this debate so far today that the Government is unaware of the feeling of the average Australian, not only the employer in industry or commerce, business of any size, particularly the farmer, and is certainly out of touch with the thinking of the genuine trade unionists, their families and other people within the community. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would not have called an election if he had realised the repercussions that the Industrial Relations Bill has caused throughout Australia. The other evening in the House he said that the issues that would be before the people of Australia were the Australia Card and the television legislation. How far from the mark has he been? In the last three or four days it is quite evident that both these issues are not the ones to be considered. The ones that are going to be considered are taxation, the Australian economy and the industrial relations system. Make no mistake, the people of this country may rest assured that the issues that we as the Liberal and National parties will be bringing before them before 11 July will be the very issues that have been raised by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) today. They will be paramount in the minds of Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say something concerning the Industrial Relations Bill, its effect upon Australia and what this country needs. But let us look at the history of conciliation and arbitration in Australia. We have lost our pioneering spirit. This is an important fact. Australians had to work. We had to work to live, and to feed and clothe each other. We had to find markets throughout the world. Maybe we did not have to compete the way that we have to compete today. We have to do this now because we have freed up our dollar to a certain degree. We have become competitive throughout the world. So we have placed ourselves on a common basis with other exporters, with other workers throughout the world. We have to realise this today and we have to equip and change our industrial laws that enable us to compete and to keep the standard of living that we have enjoyed so much in Australia.

There has been a decline ever since, perhaps, Federation. The situation has gone downhill until we have reached the situation today where we appreciate that we are on that common basis with the rest of the world. We have a higher standard of living, but $3.5 billion of taxpayers' money a year is going to the payment of unemployed people in Australia today. Is that to the credit of this great nation that we have?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a terrible indictment of the Fraser Government.

—The Minister for Social Security is the one responsible; he is the one who interjects. But the fact is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says that the economy of this country has gone backwards, that we must accept a lower standard of living and that we are living in a banana republic. The Prime Minister said that we are in a war-like situation. A few months after that we are going to the people because he said suddenly, overnight, that things have changed. Can things change? We have a national debt of over $100 billion-over $26,000 on every man, woman and child in Australia. We are passing that on to our children. I am sure that the Minister for Social Security is not being realistic when he says these types of things. Have we reached the stage when young people today have to go overseas to get work because they cannot get it in Australia, with all the wonderful natural resources that this country has? We are forcing our young people to leave our shores, to work in other countries, because they cannot find work here. Is this not a situation that we, as Australians--
—They are our major asset.

—Our major asset, as the honourable member for Dawson says. Young Australians have to go overseas to find a job. It is a challenge not only to our industrial relations but to our education system to teach these people trades, to teach them in our schools and to equip them for the responsibilities that they have to face.

SPEECH.PARA: What are some of the things that we have to look at? In answer to the Industrial Relations Bill and to put in place the policy that the National Party and the Liberal Party will have, I want to state some of the things that I believe in. I am sure that my Party would concur with me. There has to be a flexibility in industry between employer and employee. We have to take into consideration the state of Australia's economy when the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is setting the laws or actual requirements in the regulations so far as industry is concerned. We must retain the common law principles and sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, which I will say something about later. The Government tried to take out the common law principles that we have inherited. It was going to take them out of the statutes of this country, in order that they would not inhibit unions, as happened in the Mudginberri dispute and the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd dispute. Employers would not have the right to go to the courts under the common law principles. Of course, there is a need for these provisions. There is a demand by people today for a review of our industrial awards-the 17 1/2 per cent holiday pay loading and the five-day week. There is no flexibility on those and other issues that are of so much concern. We have to prohibit secondary boycotts. I know that is what Queensland is keen to do and has done and I support the Queensland Government fully. Secondary boycotts today should be illegal. There must be a strengthening of the provisions against primary boycotts. There must be an ability of the employer to pay.

This brings me to the question of arrangements between employer and employee. I refer to arrangements on the factory floor. The employer cannot afford to pay a wage or agree to working conditions within an industry if he has not got a market, if he has not got the profitability to pay these things. Certainly, there must be greater penalties so far as illegal strikes are concerned. Look at the conduct of the industrial organisations today. Why should they not be accountable to the public, to the community? Look at the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. It has assets of $18m and is possibly receiving interest on that money that it has invested at 16 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much tax do they pay?

—How much tax, the member for Dawson asks. It pays no tax. The Treasurer comes in here every day and accuses people of tax avoidance. These unions pay no tax. The Government condones that. I hope the Government does something about that. Surely there must be some equality between the public sector--

SPEECH.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —The person in the public gallery who is protesting would probably agree with me. I bet that he has not got a job. There are people in the public gallery today protesting to this Parliament and to the people of Australia because they have not got a job. They have the right to work. They should not be compelled to join a union. There should be freedom of association. No one in Australia today can say that there is not compulsory unionism. It is a closed shop so far as many of the unions are concerned. That is another factor that we have to look at here.

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned about the club-like atmosphere today in industry. It has to be cast aside. The Coal Tribunal and other statutory authorities mentioned in the legislation that we had before the Parliament a week ago should not be included.

What about the essential services legislation? It is very proper indeed that such provisions should be embraced within the statutes of the country and used when necessary. I shall also say something about the Industrial Relations Bill. I am sure that the Prime Minister had hoped he would be taking the middle of the road with his economic policies. The Industrial Relations Bill has proved, black and white, to us that the Labor Government is still controlled by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In other words, Labor has not changed its colours with respect to its close association with the ACTU. I took out a census and found that over 60 members of the House of Representatives and the Senate came in here belonging to unions, and possibly they still belong to unions. So honourable members opposite should not dissociate themselves with the trade union movement in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do, and I am proud of it.
—You've got a vested interest in this. You should not be speaking on it.

—Yes, the honourable member has a vested interest. Under socialism, the rich get richer, the very rich get even richer and the poor get poorer. This is why middle Australia will not tolerate those opposite after 11 July. I have no objection to unions run in a proper way in the interests of their members, to negotiate with the employers. But, unfortunately, the unions look after only their own interests. They exclude people from working. The Australian people have not forgotten that the Prime Minister was President of the ACTU for years. He is the man that called the strikes and then turned around and solved them.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Hunter Valley because all the southern end of my electorate of Lyne is in the Hunter Valley. It is one of the richest valleys in the world and it has been ruined by the Newcastle Trades Hall. Great deposits of steaming coal and coking coal in that area could be shipped around the world and sold for the benefit, and for the employment, of the people of the Hunter Valley. What has happened on the waterfront there for years and years? Wran's navy of almost 60 ships sat off the Newcastle harbour for months on end.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—They don't like that.

—The honourable member for Throsby does not like that. What about the Signa, half of which today lies on Stockton beach because the tuggies would not go out and move it when it could be moved and taken back to Japan again? It is still sitting there on Stockton beach today. What about the submarine contract that could have gone to Newcastle? When the Defence Department was making up its mind as to the submarine we should choose and where it should be built Newcastle was considered. It was knocked back because of the industrial relations problem there. I did not see the Government members from Newcastle standing up here and battling for Newcastle either, because they knew that the Newcastle unions were not to be trusted. This is the important fact. There is not a Newcastle member in the chamber to respond to the motion that has been put by the honourable member for Dawson. I respect the honourable members from that area but they should have put up a better fight to get that contract for Newcastle. Now, as a second prize, we are talking about patrol boats or something else, and battling for that. The Newcastle State Dockyard has been closed. At last the State has seen that the dockyard cannot operate there. We knew this years ago, and only a month or so ago the Newcastle Herald printed the ridiculous awards of arrangement. Of course it could not succeed. There was not a hope. I have not spoken today about the farming industry. I would have liked to have spoken about it because the very issues that we have here are the issues on which the National Farmers Federation has been fighting for months.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) said, we on this side reject the motion moved by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). I was very interested in the comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan). I thank him for one point which I will be using through all my election campaign-he put on the record the fact that the Opposition would, if elected, abolish the leave loading that all workers in Australia get. Let me thank him because that will go into all my election material.
—Are you sure he said that?

—Yes, he actually said that the Opposition would abolish the 17.5 per cent leave loading, so it must be part of its policy. He was actually talking about accountability. We hear a lot in this place about accountability-accountability of this and accountability of that-and he focused in on the accountability of the trade unions. It always amazes me that when those opposite start talking about accountability they are very selective about who they want to be accountable. I notice that they are very silent on the accountability of the doctors in the Australian Capital Territory at the moment. They do not talk about that. They talk about people paying tax. I would like to ask them how much tax their friends in the white-shoe brigade pay. I stand corrected if I am wrong, but was it not someone called Mike Gore who was promoting the Queensland Premier as Prime Minister? Was he not the one who was going to--
—Mr Deputy President, I draw your attention to the terms of the motion. I do not think it has anything whatsoever to do with the subject on which the honourable member for Throsby is speaking.
—This has been a rather wide ranging debate promoted by both sides of the House.

—I am just using this point to get into my speech. To finish on that point, it was this person who was talking bout raising $25m for the `Joh for PM' campaign. Correct me if I am wrong, but was it not reported yesterday that he was up on a tax avoidance charge? I think that is right, and those opposite are talking about who pays tax. They say the trade unions are not paying tax. That is absolute rubbish. They talk bout accountability. I must say they are very silent and very selective when they talk about who pays tax and who should be accountable.

SPEECH.PARA: I might also say that the honourable member for Lyne made, in my view, a very unjust attack on the Newcastle members in this place concerning the submarine contract. Whatever the reason that Newcastle did not get the contract-and it was very carefully evaluated with all factors, including industrial relations and a whole range of other factors, being taken into account-I must say that since I have been in this place I have never seen anyone work harder than the Newcastle members, especially the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), to get that contract. New South Wales members attended meeting after meeting to try to get the contract for Newcastle, but I did not notice any New South Wales Opposition members there.

Part of the industrial relations legislation deals with the coal mining industry. We hear that all the industrial disputes in the coal mining industry are leading to job losses. Two coal mines in my electorate have recently closed-the Yellowrock mine and also the Avon mine. This had absolutely nothing to do with industrial disputes, as the honourable member for Macarthur said. The coal there has a very high ash content-up to 25 per cent-and although at times it could be sold, but always at a lower price, given the world oversupply of coal at the moment there was no way that it could be sold. Let me quote from the annual report of Austen and Butta Ltd last year. In reference to Yellowrock, it says:
During the year generally favourable mining conditions and excellent industrial relations-
I repeat, `excellent industrial relations'-
combined to achieve a mine record production level.
In the Telex sent by Ian Dunlop announcing the closure of the mines, he said:

The decision to close Avon and Yellowrock was taken most reluctantly. The two mines are among the most productive underground operations in the State, due in main to the loyal and dedicated work force and management of both pits. It is unfortunate that the combination of poor quality coal and current market conditions do not allow continued operations.

So let us not hear any more of this nonsense about it being the workers, the coal miners, who have led to the closure of these mines. It is not the coal miners at all, it is the international coal situation at the moment-the overproduction and the way that some countries such as China, because they want foreign currency, will undersell other countries. South Africa has an advantage because of the working conditions there. If honourable members want us to adopt South African working conditions in our mines, they should come down to the Illawarra, they should go through the Illawarra and Hunter pits and tell the miners in those pits that they are pushing to have the same working conditions for them as the black miners in South Africa have. That is what they are trying to push.

Of course what we are really debating today is the different approach of the political parties to industrial relations. I would hope that both sides of the House want harmonious industrial relations. The unions accept this, as indeed does this Government. But do Opposition members accept it? Do they really want harmonious industrial relations? This Government, in the more than four years it has been in office, has worked through consultation and negotiations. We have achieved harmony. We believe in consultation, not confrontation, but those opposite, with their almost pathological hatred of the trade union movement, do not want consultation; they do not even know the meaning of the word. They just want confrontation.

We hear much about industrial disputes, but look at our record. Over the last three years, the average annual number of working days lost per thousand employees was 240.7. This compares with the annual average during the Fraser Government of 590.6 days lost per thousand employees. The results show a massive decline of the order of 60 per cent in the level of industrial disputation, and we have achieved this through consultation with the trade union movement.

The second part of the motion put forward by the honourable member for Dawson refers to essential services. He wants us to adopt the Federal National Party's policy of introducing essential services legislation. We really have to define what essential services are. It seems to me that we would be embarking on a very political task. I think those opposite are more interested in the politics of the matter rather than the industrial relations aspect. I speak now as someone who has always been a trade unionist and who is still a member of a trade union, and I always carry my trade union ticket with me. I have it here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a vested interest.

—It may be a vested interest, but I believe in the trade union movement in Australia and when I came into this Parliament I continued to be a member of my union and I pay my union dues every year. I wonder how many of those on the other side who are always talking about trade unions are members of a union or have ever been members of a union. While three honourable members have put up their hands, their attacks on the trade union movement and their comments on that movement really indicate to me that they have not been very active members of a trade union.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is now 1.45 p.m., and in accordance with standing order 109, as amended for this session, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the time for discussion of notice No. 1, General Business, be extended to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I was making is that industrial relations in this country need not be a bear pit. The Illawarra region, the region from which I come, is often criticised-very wrongly, in my view-for having a bad industrial relations record. The unions are portrayed as being militant. Of course the unions will fight to maintain their hard won rights and no right from the bosses in this country is ever given lightly or, in my experience, without a fight-and a long fight, when those rights apply to the Illawarra. When people sit down and negotiate with good will on both sides, agreements can be reached. I refer to the construction a couple of years back of the coal loading facility in the Illawarra which came in millions and millions of dollars under the budgeted cost and a couple of months ahead of time. That happened because the trade union movement and all involved in it sat down and negotiated before work commenced. The same is happening today with the work being carried out by the Port Kembla Harbour Task Force.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that there is a lot of misunderstanding and suspicion on all sides. I well remember a couple of weeks back I attended a seminar at Orange, organised by the college at Orange and attended by the Port Kembla Harbour Task Force and the farmers of the west, because we hoped to ship grain and other products through the port of Port Kembla. One of the farmers' representatives was talking about the feeling he had the first time he had a trade unionist in his house. He had him there for the evening, and he made the very telling point that they had a lot to talk about. He said: `After all, why shouldn't we have a lot to talk about because we haven't talked to each other for 100 years'.

It seems to me that one of the problems in Australia is that everyone is quick to criticise trade unions and other groups but no one is keen to sit down and talk through some of these problems. We have seen in Queensland a model of what is being proposed by the Nationals. We have also seen the bitterness and the confrontation. The Australian people will have the opportunity on 1 July to say what sort of industrial relations approach they want to see followed-the policy of confrontation that those opposite are pushing, or the policy of consultation.

The honourable member for Dawson made much about the Industrial Relations Bill. The way he was talking about this Bill, one would think we were debating it. Following our policy of consultation, we have laid the Bill on the table and we will listen to all points raised. If management, the bosses, or the unionists or any other groups have a point of view, we will listen to that point of view. We could have put the Bill through, we have the numbers in this place, but following our policy of consultation, and as we knew that some people had a few questions about it, we put it on the table and said: `Tell us what your problems are; we will listen to your problems'.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the next day you called an election.
—Who is any the wiser!
—Order! The honourable member for Dawson will cease interjecting, as will the honourable member for Mallee.

—We are none the wiser for hearing what the honourable member for Dawson has said. He also touched on a coal authority, but I will correct him here. We never pushed for a coal marketing authority; it has always been a coal authority. I support a coal authority. I have said many times in this House that I have supported a coal authority, and let us face it, the producers have not done too well in selling and maybe it is time that someone else had a go. I believe that a coal authority would help our marketing. I also think it would help the orderly development of coal production in this country. The companies are talking about closing 20 pits, while in Queensland they are talking about opening new pits. There has never been an orderly approach to the production of coal in this country. If we had a coal authority and it could achieve that, that would be a good thing. It is the same with the marketing of coal. We have the producers going overseas, and the Japanese pick them all off one after the other. Japan has a centralised body, and maybe it is time we looked at some of these new approaches.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For many months now the National Party of Australia has been endeavouring to get this Government to come to grips with some of the serious economic problems facing Australia, particularly in the exporting areas, the farming and mining areas, and the small business sector of Australia, yet it is not until the last day of the Parliament that we are given our first real opportunity to have something to say about the industrial problems that have so hampered our balance of payments situation.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the fundamentals of this country are in a very bad way. We know that they are characterised by a huge and rapidly rising overseas debt, in excess of $100 billion-the third or fourth largest debt in the world. It is largely a consequence, I believe, of irresponsible corporate and public sector borrowing. We know that we have severe accumulated balance of payments problems resulting from years of importing too much, borrowing too much and not earning enough to make ends meet in a very unforgiving international market-place. We know that the costs of producing goods and services are extremely high, with crazy on-costs such as penalty rates, holiday loadings and workers compensation claims that at this point in time have become parasitic. Of course these things affect our exports very dramatically, as of course they also affect another major and growing industry in this country, the tourism industry. We know that record high interest rates are crippling our farms, our businesses, our mines, our whole productive sector and are forcing increasing numbers of families to abandon their homes and their land.

I just point out to this House that one of the worst situations in Australia's rural community is evident in my own electorate of Mallee, where families are simply having to shut the gate and walk off their properties. Of course our inflation rate is now some 400 times higher than that of the world's respected economies. In summary, we are a nation that is far too deeply in debt. We are rapidly losing our creditworthiness. We are demanding far too much and not giving enough in return to justify our high expectations.

So what is the industrial relations record of this Government? This motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) refers particularly to the coal mining industry. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) invites us all to go to South Africa, to look at the conditions in the South African mines. We are not talking about conditions; we believe conditions in Australia are relatively adequate for the mining workers, as they are for most other people in this country. We are not talking about conditions, but about the need for people to get on and do a bit of work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Productivity.
—Productivity is what we are talking about. I refer to a report in today's Australian, headed `Coal miners fear imminent loss of 3000 jobs, 15 Mines', which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Miners Federation yesterday warned that 3000 jobs might soon be lost and more than 15 coal mines faced closure in NSW and Queensland.
The Secretary of the federation, Mr Barry Swan, said in Sydney that the coal industry was in grave trouble and action was needed now to address its problems.
We believe that something like 3,000 jobs are going in the very near future-and I am talking about in 12 months time. Mr Swan said:
This union also has very grave concerns that in excess of 15 mines in NSW and Queensland will close.

Yet the honourable member for Throsby tells us everything is all right. He tells us there have not been any major disputes in the coal industry. Let me just for a moment outline to the House some of the unions' record of not honouring their promises and their agreements. There have been 180 disputes in the coal industry since June 1986 and early February 1987, despite firm undertakings that there would not be any. The cost of these disputes which have ended in strike action has been estimated at 2.6 million tonnes of production, or approximately $130m in export earnings. That is why so many people in our community refer to the innate industrial rape of this country's economy. All of this is left unchallenged by the Government, as we have heard Government members say. One therefore has to ask whether this is just pure bloody-mindedness or economic vandalism, or is it in fact a long range plan for the nationalisation of the coal industry. Let me just for a moment look at the wheat industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—The honourable member says it is not true. We all know what happened in New South Wales last year-the wheat handling authorities were held up to ransom by 16 people who were earning in excess of $60,000 a year. They held up the export of our wheat from the New South Wales handling terminals at a cost of some $270m to the wheat industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Do honourable members opposite agree with that? It is no wonder that our balance of payments situation is as bad as it is. The coal industry is suffering, the wheat industry is suffering, miners are losing their jobs, mines are closing and farmers are walking off the land. What is their answer to it? They introduced the Industrial Relations Bill as a result of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. Of course we knew what the Hancock inquiry would come out with before its report was even presented to this place. No doubt it was greeted by the Public Service with an unusual amount of excitement, because it solved, of course, a serious problem for the bureaucracy. It provided a means by which people would be assured of jobs, of promotions, in the days and weeks ahead. So we got the Industrial Relations Bill. Let us be under no illusion as to what the Industrial Relations Bill was all about. We know that the Labor Government, under the Willis industrial relations club, is committed to the destruction of all that we have achieved in hundreds of years of British history in this country. If ordinary Australians and businesses are denied access to common law and injunctions against uncivilised behaviour, there will be nothing to stop union bosses taking over this country. The National Party opposed the Industrial Relations Bill; the Government delayed consideration of the Bill, and I believe that it did so not because it wanted to involve itself in further consultation but simply because it was frightened about the effects the Industrial Relations Bill would have on its election results in a few weeks time. That is why the Bill was delayed, and make no mistake about it, if this Government gets back into power on 11 July, which fortunately it will not, the industrial relations legislation would be introduced immediately and this country would have to suffer the same sorts of problems, the same sorts of difficulties, the same sort of loss to export markets, as we have had to face over the last four years.

The honourable member for Mallee will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day under General Business for the next sitting.

—I would not hold my breath, either.
