The Committee of Members' Interests, at its last meeting, decided to postpone any consideration of whether other classes of persons should be covered by the Register of Members' Interests.

—Does the Prime Minister recall his promise to the Australian people, made in his policy speech, that under his Government nine out of ten Australians would pay less for the health needs of themselves and their families? How does the Prime Minister square that solemn undertaking with the fact that since the introduction of Medicare, the 60 per cent of Australian families with children who maintain private health insurance have had the cost of their basic health cover rise from $9.66 a week to $14.30, which will soon be $15 a week, a rise of almost 60 per cent?

—The basic intention of the Government in introducing Medicare has been not only achieved but also, more importantly, recognised as having been achieved by the people of this country. When this Government came to office, two million of our fellow Australians were uncovered for their likely commitments in regard to health and hospital coverage. We made a commitment to the people of Australia that a progressive system would be introduced in this country whereby, essentially, the healthy and wealthy, relatively speaking, would help to meet the commitments of all Australians. In the result, this country now has a system, under Medicare, which provides universal medical cover for all Australians and entitles them to free public hospital treatment. That scheme has, I believe, not only overwhelmingly met the needs of the Australian people but also has done so equitably. Against what the Government has achieved, the fact is that under the proposals that have been advanced by the Leader of the Opposition and various spokesmen on the Opposition side on this subject, there would be a total turnaround of that equitable situation. A far greater burden would be placed on those in the community least able to afford health cover.

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: The question was directed to the Prime Minister's promise. He is not as yet the spokesman for Oppositions policies. He will be in six weeks time. He should be told to be relevant to the question.
—Order! The question by the honourable member for Barker included a comparison. I call the Prime Minister.

—The situation, as has been revealed both by the Leader of the Opposition and various spokesmen on the other side of the House, is that the ordinary Australian family would be significantly worse off. The honourable member for Barker asked about the impact on the average Australian family. As far as can be ascertained, under the Opposition's proposal a family on an average income of about $23,000 would be $21 a week worse off. Not only would there be a turning on its head of a situation where those of us in the community more able to do so are subsidising the worse off in the community but also, paradoxically, this proposed dismantling of the Medicare system is put on the basis that it would provide some $3 billion to help fund the Opposition's proposed tax cuts.

—Madam Speaker, on a point of order under standing order 145 as to relevance: The Prime Minister was not asked to do a comparison with Opposition policies. He has been speaking for two minutes on Opposition policies. In my submission, he should be ruled out of order, or he should be asked to be relevant.
—Order! I find the Prime Minister in order in the answer he is giving.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. As I was saying, it comes as no surprise that the Opposition is attempting to interrupt the exposure of the fact that under the Opposition's proposals, not only would the average Australian be very significantly worse off, to the tune of more than $20 a week, but also, paradoxically, this total disruption of an equitable system is allegedly to be done to provide $3 billion in savings for tax cuts when it has been exposed by my colleagues the Treasurer and the Minister for Health that it would be deficit neutral. The alleged savings in medical payouts and payments to hospitals would be more than offset by the loss of revenue that would be involved in the proposal. So, in sum, I assert that under the Government's Medicare proposals, the people of Australia, particularly those most in need, are significantly better off, as we promised they would be. The consequence of the implementation of the Leader of the Opposition's proposals would be to make those in the community on very high levels of income perhaps better off but at the massive expense of the middle and lower income people in this community.

—Will the Minister representing the Special Minister of State outline the arrangements which will apply to the conduct of the Federal election to be conducted on 11 July? In particular, by what date must electors enrol in order to be eligible to vote at the election?
—Bye, Bye, Mick.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that I was pretty safe, but I have just received a wire from Australian Associated Press and all of a sudden I find that I live in a marginal seat now, because Mike Gore has switched his support from Bjelke-Petersen to John Howard.
—Who is Mike Gore?

—Who is Mike Gore? I can tell the honourable member that he is having a bushfire up there and is burning all the white shoes on the Gold Coast. Honourable members will know who Mike Gore is. It is nice to see the honourable member for Ryan back in Canberra. Someone said that John Howard had left him in Queensland as a hostage; he had to leave something there. We thought that they had done a deal, but Joh says that there is no deal; he is running all the candidates anyhow. Who has got Mike Gore's $25m? Where is the $25m? Those opposite called their old mate Joh a scrambled egg, I see, for doing a deal with him.

ANSWER.PARA: The issuing of writs for the election will take place tomorrow. The rolls will close at 6 p.m. on 12 June. It is estimated by the Australian Electoral Commission that there are still some hundreds of thousands of people eligible to be on the rolls and to vote who are not on them. As a result of the amendments which we have made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act since we have been in Government, people have a lot more time to enrol than they did under Malcolm's regime. He gave them about 48 hours to do so and tens of thousands of people were denied the right to vote. We are letting everybody in Australia know that we want them on the rolls by 6 p.m. on 12 June so they can vote at the election.

Nominations for all the candidates, including Joh, will close on 18 June. Polling day will be on 11 July, and the return of the writs will be on 3 September. It is most important to point out the time for the closure of the rolls so that everybody in Australia who is eligible has an opportunity to get on the roll and vote-because we are looking for a major landslide victory. It is indicated now that the support from the Prime Minister is 70 per cent as against 20 per cent for the Leader of the Opposition, so for every 100 we put on the roll we get 70 votes. So the more who go on, the better. People ought to take the opportunity, living in a democracy such as Australia, to vote on July 11. Which party will the honourable member for Maranoa represent?

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party.
—Which one? There will be a bit of a snakes and ladders game going on in Queensland in the next couple of weeks. Anyhow we wish them all the best.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer to this week's Bulletin article which details the financial power of unions, such as the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, which has net assets of $18m-plus and is getting 16 per cent tax free returns on its investments. What is the Treasurer's best estimate of the annual revenue forgone by the Commonwealth, due specifically to the tax exemption given to trade unions on income arising other than from dealings with their members?

—I did not see the article, but there is an exemption for co-operative bodies in the Income Tax Assessment Act, which has been there for a very long time. I can only presume that the import of the question is that the honourable member thinks that the exemptions for trade unions, charities, churches and the rest should come out.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has the Government had any response to its representations to the Soviet authorities about Soviet Jews?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Barton for his question. Since its election in 1983, this Government has made clear to the Soviet Government its concern about human rights in the Soviet Union, including of course, the important question of the rights of Soviet Jews. My colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs did this directly in Moscow in 1984, and on a number of occasions both the Minister and I have raised the issue with Soviet representatives in Canberra. When the Soviet Foreign Minister, Mr Shevardnadze, was in Canberra in February, I drew his attention, among a number of other matters, to the case of Professor Abram Englin, a very distinguished 78-year old scientist of Jewish background who had been trying for 14 years to obtain permission to leave the Soviet Union. I did this in response to representations from his son, Dr Boris Englin of Melbourne, who contacted me immediately prior to the Foreign Minister's visit to this country.

ANSWER.PARA: During the conversations I had with the Foreign Minister, Mr Shevardnadze, he undertook to take account of my representations. I was, therefore, delighted to learn a few days ago from Dr Boris Englin, that his father had received permission to emigrate from the Soviet Union last month and has indeed been in Israel for the past two weeks. Australian Embassy officials in Tel Aviv have been in touch with Professor Englin with a view to issuing him with a visa to come to Australia, and he hopes to be able to travel to Australia later this year. I am pleased to note the progress which has also been achieved in respect of the list of people, mainly Jewish, wishing to emigrate from the Soviet Union which you, Madam Speaker, presented on behalf of this Parliament to the Chairman of the Council of Nationalities of the Supreme Soviet on 4 July last year. Three families on that list have now received permission to leave the Soviet Union.

This modest but encouraging improvement can in part be attributed to the general policy of seeking a more constructive relationship with the Soviet Union instituted by this Government. I assure all members of Parliament that it will continue to make representations in this important human rights area. Similarly, modest but I would suggest significant progress has been achieved in respect of other lists, two of which you, Madam Speaker, also presented during your visit. These were based on the Government's register of outstanding family reunion cases. Since the beginning of 1987, approximately one family group has been able to depart each week for Australia. I assure you, as I do the honourable member who addressed the question to me, that this Government will continue to pursue vigorously the objective of resolving outstanding family reunion cases with the Soviet Union and other countries which do not permit freedom of travel. I conclude by saying that at a time when the two sides of this Parliament are emphasising points of difference between them, I know with certainty that the views I have expressed on this matter will receive the wholehearted endorsement of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the Government's mini-Budget decision to means test family allowances. Does this decision mean that all of the 2,130,000 recipients of family allowances will be required to fill out Department of Social Security forms detailing information on joint parental incomes? What information will the Hawke Government require individuals to provide to officers of the Department of Social Security? Does this mean that family allowance recipients, 98.3 per cent of whom are women, will be held accountable for the accuracy of information supplied by the other parent? How will this be implemented in cases where parents are divorced or separated or have remarried? What checks does the Minister envisage taking to ensure that the information is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Income testing comes in at the beginning of October, but over the next several months, the Government will be placing steps in train to ensure that it acquires what is not currently available to the Department of Social Security, that is, relevant information on all Australian families. It is to be understood that that is necessary, and it will be extraordinarily helpful because one of the problems in the social security system is, of course, that a very high proportion of payments are made to low income families on an income tested basis. It is a matter of considerable concern to the Government that the family income supplement scheme, which is one of the significant reforms in the social security system in recent years and which is a considerable help in terms of providing incentive for people to move into the work force, has what is generally regarded as quite a low take up rate. In the process of gathering the necessary information, it will be possible to increase the take up of some payments. A second example is the handicapped child allowance. That is also an important payment within the social security system and, for some years, there has been concern about the relevant take up.

ANSWER.PARA: The overwhelmingly positive response and acceptance of income testing for family allowance purposes has surprised me. After every economic statement, similar to a Budget or the May economic statement, the Department of Social Security has provided a hot line for people to ring up and make queries. On the last occasion on which I checked, something like 60 per cent of all people who rang the social security hot line endorsed the measures within the May economic statement. Something like 30 per cent of the people were critical of it but they were satisfied with an explanation and very few people were hostile to the measures. In a very tough statement, that is surprising. Family allowance was not a matter about which there was a considerable frequency of calls.

In terms of the thresholds, people will effectively be able to remove themselves on the basis of the approach the Government will take with respect to income testing. In no way is it intended to be intrusive, and I believe there is considerable acceptance of the measure the Government has introduced. Some matters have not yet been resolved. The honourable member for Moncrieff referred to cases of separation and matters of responsibility. They are matters the Government will be looking at. I remind the honourable member that there is still quite a considerable lead time before the income testing comes in in October.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of enlightened economic debate in this country, can the Treasurer inform the House of the cost to Commonwealth revenue of reducing the personal marginal tax rates to 35 per cent and 25 per cent, with a threshold of $5,400, and a company tax rate of 35 per cent?
—What about your tax policy?
—I am trying to enlighten the honourable member.
—The honourable member will not be led astray by interjections.
—Honourable members opposite have not asked any questions on the economy.
—Order! The honourable member will get on with his question.
—How does this cost compare with the cost of implementing a flat 25 per cent personal and company rate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A tax scale of the kind the honourable gentleman mentioned, with a threshold of $5,400, a 25 per cent rate between $5,400 and $25,000, and a top rate of 35 per cent matched with a 35 per cent company tax rate would cost $8 billion; made up of $5 1/2 billion on the personal tax side and $2 1/2 billion on the company side. The honourable gentleman asked me in the second part of his question about the contrast in cost of a 25 per cent flat tax, with a $5,400 threshold, and a 25 per cent company rate. The comparable figures are $12 billion-$8 billion for the personal scale at 25c flat, and $4 billion for a company rate at 25c in the dollar.

ANSWER.PARA: Those two propositions mirror the propositions being leaked by the Opposition as its tax policy. Tonight the Leader of the Opposition is to tell his back benchers what the tax policy is. I have no doubt that he will not be telling them where the money will come from to fund it. The fact is that with this `unified' Opposition opposite we have the Queensland Premier campaigning on a 25 per cent flat tax rate, as I described it, and a company rate, costing $12 billion. The leaked scale of the Leader of the Opposition will cost $8 billion. There is a $4 billion difference between the leaked Liberal Party proposals and the Joh proposals. Yet the Leader of the Opposition would have us believe that there is no difference between them on tax-only $4 billion.

Need I say that the Government has delivered $4 billion of paid tax cuts, which have not only reduced the tax rates but also have reduced the Budget deficit. A scale of the kind that has been leaked, costing $8 billion could only be funded, if the deficit were not to rise and were it to be funded from outlays, by the abolition of indexation to pensions, major cuts to social security, major cuts to education, and major cuts to health. If that were to occur, the upside costs to the public from such changes would far outweigh the tax cuts for anyone on the lower to middle end of the scale. The only recipients, as usual, as with every other thing the Liberals have ever done, would be the high income earners.

At a time when the nation's income has been cut by $9 billion because of declines in our terms of trade we have the coalition parties arguing that the living standards of Australians may rise by their after tax income rising as a result of tax cuts which they think they can deliver but which they know the nation cannot possibly afford. The accurate cost is $5 1/2 billion for the Liberal personal tax scale as we know it and $2 1/2 billion for a matching company rate, coming to $8 billion. For the `no difference in policy between us and them'-the Liberal Party and the National Party in Queensland-the figures are $12 billion for the Joh scale, made up of $8 billion on the personal scale and $4 billion for the company scale. So there is, of course, a $4 billion difference.

That is why the Queensland Premier has said that he is still campaigning on his agenda issues. He said today that he hopes to control the Senate through the National Party. So let us not have any pretence that there is any unity whatsoever on the other side of politics in relation to the Queensland Premier's position, the arguments that he will put at the election, his support for candidates of the National Party and for the National Party's policies. Again, we are seeing that it is impossible now for the Liberal and National parties to be putting any proposal in relation to tax which has a majority position.

We heard the honourable member for Maranoa who is not a National Party member of the State Parliament but who is a member of the National Parliamentary Party here in Canberra, saying two days ago on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio that he still is in favour of the 25 per cent top rate tax. There is no unanimity of agreement within the parliamentary parties on the conservative side of this chamber.

We will wait to see what is hatched up on the other side of politics in terms of fiscal bribes, hands full of dollars, fists full of money, and all other manner of irresponsible tax commitments which can only destroy the fabric of this country's economy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister recall the promise he made to the Australian people on 13 November 1984? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: And I now give this undertaking-that for the term of our next Government, the Medicare levy will not be increased.

How does the Prime Minister square this solemn undertaking with the fact that in the 1986-87 Budget the Medicare levy was increased from one per cent to 1.25 per cent? Can the Prime Minister now give a similar categorical undertaking to the Australian people that he is not going to the election with a hidden tax agenda which includes a further increase in the Medicare levy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have had cause to say before, what has characterised this Government has been the preparedness to make the hard decisions which have been necessary to deal with the new economic circumstances that have been forced upon us. If the Opposition members-while it very temporarily retains the honourable member for Casey amongst its ranks-want to continue to say to the Australian people that the loss of $9 billion from our economic capacity makes no difference, I urge them to continue with their voodoo economics in the election campaign. I hope they do, because all the evidence is that the people will not buy it.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been forced to take a number of decisions that we did not want to take. No politician in his right mind would wish to pursue a tight monetary policy which would involve an increase in interest rates. As I have said in this place before, no politician wants interest rates higher for a day longer than is absolutely necessary.

But a number of decisions, including that to which the honourable member referred, were adjudged necessary by the Government to bring in a responsible economic policy to match the economic challenge confronting the country. As distinct from the Leader of the Opposition and the various spokespersons for the conservative forces, we will not be preaching voodoo economics.

In the May statement and in the associated meeting with the Premiers at the Premiers Conference we made the toughest set of decisions in more than 30 years in this country. We took no pleasure in making those decisions, but they were necessary not merely to adjust this country to that loss of national economic capacity but also to put this country in shape for the restructuring of its economy so that in the future it would not remain so exposed to the variations in international commodity prices. We make no apology for that. If the honourable member wants to talk about a hidden agenda, that will be very much on the election agenda. When he considers what his Party will have to explain to the Australian people about its hidden agenda, he should shudder with fright. The fact is that the Opposition has been saddled with the promises of its current Leader. If we look at what the Leader of the Opposition has said-word for word; not something that someone else has said-he has a $16 billion credibility gap. What we have been told, of course, is that to pay for that he will find $3 billion from Medicare. The fact is that he will not find a net cent from Medicare.

What is involved in this hidden agenda? What is involved in this most remarkable statement by the Leader of the Opposition yesterday, after his cap in hand visit to the Premier of Queensland? We should remember what he said because it will come to haunt him and members of the Opposition because the Australian people will hear it every day. He said:

At a meeting in Sir Joh's Brisbane office today, the two leaders agreed that any important variations between their basic policies for Australia's economic recovery could be resolved immediately after a new Conservative Government was sworn in.
Does the House remember the famous statement of the Leader of the National Party of Australia? He said the same thing even more graphically on 29 April.

TALK.START.PARA: —A point of order, Madam Speaker.
—We are talking about hidden agendas, Madam Speaker.
—Order! I call the honourable member for North Sydney on a point of order.
—The question was on a specific subject. In my submission the Prime Minister should not be allowed to return his pathetic censure of yesterday--
—Order! I remind the honourable member for North Sydney that if people stopped interjecting we would not get these widenings of the answers to questions.
—What the Leader of the Opposition said yesterday on the subject of the hidden agenda was central to the question. On 29 April the Leader of the National Party stated:

ANSWER.PARA: It will be necessary to go into the election campaign with our separate policies and then after the election to enter negotiations with the Liberal Party and then work out which of the policies that have been presented to the people are going to be in fact put in place.

We will disclose during the election campaign the inevitable fact that the Leader has on his hidden agenda a 12 per cent consumption tax. That is on the hidden agenda because there is no way that he could begin to pay for the suggested income tax cuts that he is talking about. We have no hidden agenda. We have done the job. The Opposition has a hidden agenda. The problem for the honourable member, and one of the reasons why this is his last day in this House, is that we will expose that hidden agenda during the election. The honourable member, and many like him, will be swept from this place.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: AGRICULTURAL POLICIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Trade inform the House to what extent the United States Administration, Congress and community at large are aware of the detrimental effects on Australia of its domestic agricultural policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and indicate that over the last couple of weeks he, as leader of the joint parliamentary delegation to Washington, and I a few days later pressed Australia's case with members of Congress and the United States Administration. I commend the work of the delegation and take the opportunity to table a copy of the delegation's report. I think the important part of what we have been doing falls into two categories. One is the way in which we have been encouraging the United States to participate actively in the international movement towards reform in agricultural trade. The second is that we have pointed out to the Congress the damage which some of the measures which it is contemplating would cause, particularly to Australia. On that last point it is worth making the comment that there is now a wider appreciation within the Congress of the damaging consequences which would flow to Australia from some of its measures. I am quite confident that that will be borne in mind as the current trade Bill reaches its final form.

ANSWER.PARA: It is perhaps not surprising that there is some ignorance in the Congress of Australia's position. I refer to an item in a publication known as Congressional Quarterly which discusses the movement in production of grains and the slide in the United States share of the world grain market. It states:
Several countries including Canada, Australia and others in Europe and South America, have since geared up their grain production capacity by subsidising their local farmers.
Of course, Australia distinguishes itself-with a few other countries-in not subsidising its agricultural producers, particularly grain farmers. Part of our task is to correct that misinformation.

As well as working on the Congress, which we have done not only by way of the work of the delegation, my work, and that of my colleagues the Minister for Primary Industry and the Prime Minister, but also by the work of the very competent officials in our embassy in Washington, we have been working on the international front. The work of the Cairns group has had a very significant impact on the way in which the course of world events is turning out. I quote very briefly from an editorial in the United States Journal of Commerce, which is an important daily economic publication. Its leading article of 27 May, under the title `The Mighty Cairns', states:
It's about time the Cairns group of agricultural exporting nations got a little credit for the progress made on farm trade talks.

The 14 countries, who derive their name from the Australian town in which they first met, have succeeded in embarrassing both the European Community and the United States into serious negotiations on farm trade talks.

I table that very important editorial and commend it to all honourable members. The important thing about our relations with the United States Administration is that, whilst we agree with the central object of reform in agricultural trade, we have some serious disagreements about some of the means by which that reform might be achieved. The most important difference of opinion we have is on the effect and validity of having the export enhancement program, which is costing Australian farmers in excess of $1 billion a year. We fundamentally disagree with the Administration about the need for that program and believe that action should be taken immediately to scale down that program towards its early abolition. Through our joint efforts we have been able not only to push the case for reform internationally, but also to impress upon the Congress the importance of taking into account the position of Australian farmers as it devises its various pieces of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aviation. The Minister will be aware that the earliest time for the three years notice to be given for the termination of the two airlines agreement, 26 January 1987, is almost five months behind us, and the earliest date for any significant change to domestic aviation regulatory arrangements is fast approaching 1991. Why is the Government wasting so much time in announcing the new arrangements, particularly when the Minister has been so critical of the present arrangements? Is the Minister intending to make an announcement before the election? If so, when? Will the Minister, as part of any announcement, also declare that any proposed change which amounts to less than the complete termination of the two airlines agreement will not be acceptable to the incoming Liberal- National Party Government?

—I said earlier in the week that the existing set of arrangements is the result of the efforts of those who now sit opposite. It is the height of political expediency to be critical of the existing arrangements and then duck off and say: `We shouldn't have had those arrangements at all'. They have been there for over 30 years as a result of previous conservative governments.
—We have heard that for four years. Tell us something new.
—Order! The honourable member for Bass will not interject like that again.
—Maiden question.

—Maiden question, was it? I thought for a moment that there was a stranger in the House. As I was saying, the arrangements in this country exist because of successive conservative governments over decades.
—Oh, come on!

—It happens to be a fact. I know that honourable members opposite do not like the truth. We saw considerable debate during the run-up period to the renewal of the last agreement, particularly during the early part of 1981. At that time the Liberal Party was sharply split with all sorts of divisions and was in the same kind of turbulence and disarray that we now see in the conservative parties. Around the nation there is agreement that this Government has been the most able economic manager in the history of Federation. When this Government implements changes in direction it ensures that there is proper consultation with the people affected by those changes. There was an agreement which the National Party strongly supported and was responsible for, but we decided to seek the views of the community on what was the most appropriate set of arrangements; and we have done that. As soon as the report was received it was released to the public for further comment. The closing date for that comment was 31 March. There has been a considerable number of responses to the May report and its five options. Those responses are being assessed and the matter is still being considered by the Government. When we consider the manner in which those who now sit opposite operated in respect of domestic aviation I think that this Government's performance is by far more credible, and certainly we will not be embarking on the kind of processes that members opposite followed in government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, and he is a very good Minister, too. Can the Minister inform the House of the effect on sport in Australia of a Federal government abolishing the Australian Sports Commission and its many programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Canning for his question. Even as a veteran, he is one of the leading surf lifesavers in Western Australia. To eliminate the Australian Sports Commission from the Australian sporting scene at this time would be an absolute disaster for sport. At the present time one of the programs administered by the Sports Commission is Aussie Sports, which was a discovery of our sporting Prime Minister. Some 10,000 schools and some 500,000 school children participate in sport and that would not have been possible were it not for the advent of the Sports Commission. I noticed with some disdain that today the honourable member for Flinders released his `sports policy'. The first thing it states is that a coalition government would abolish the Sports Commission. That is rather strange because only a month ago the honourable member for McPherson, who was the then shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, said that a coalition government would eliminate the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism and the Institute of Sport and that the big sporting body in Australia would be the Sports Commission. So there has been a radical shift in a month-but that is fairly typical of what happens on that side of the House.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from the Aussie Sports program the Sports Commission administers STEP grants, which are funds administered to our elite sportsmen who are not scholarship holders at the Institute of Sport. Further, it disperses some millions of dollars to hundreds of sporting organisations around Australia under sports development grants. I do not think that the hundreds of sporting bodies around Australia will be terribly enamoured about the proposition to eliminate the Sports Commission. I will mention a few other things that come under this umbrella.

For instance, this Government has increased by 400 per cent funding to the handicapped in sport in Australia; and it has increased by 300 per cent funding to surf lifesaving associations. Under this Government, women in sport for the first time will have some recognition. However, I noticed in the Liberal Party's manifesto released today that at long last it has discovered that women do play sport. The Liberal Party totally ignored that fact during its 30 years in government. I notice also that the Liberal Party will strictly adhere to the Gleneagles Agreement. I must say that during the previous Government's term in office that was the case, but always with someone else's money. It was with the great support of the Minister for Foreign Affairs that I was able to get through Cabinet in our first year of government a payment of some $64,000 to Australian kids-one of whom was the late Phil Lynch's son-who had withdrawn from sporting events around the world at the request of the Fraser Government without receiving any financial support from that Government and with no reimbursement for the funds they had expended. This Government had the great satisfaction of retrospectively paying those kids $64,000 for complying with the Gleneagles Agreement. I see now that members opposite at least recognise that Agreement.

The `great' effort made by honourable members opposite in relation to sport is fully recognised by the Australian Olympic Federation. We well remember the former Government's attempts to blackmail our olympic athletes into not attending the 1980 Olympic Games and the then Government's reduction of grants to that olympic team by two-thirds. Olympic athletes will receive $2m for the 1988 Olympic Games from this Government-and that is five times the amount of money the former Government gave the 1980 team when it eventually went to those games. Apart from that, there have been other great reforms, one of which was the application of tax deductibility for contributions to sport in Australia-for the first time ever. We were the only developed country which did not have that advantage for sporting bodies. Also we introduced tax averaging for the incomes of professional sportsmen. We also had a renewal of the racing-breeding industry in Australia as a result of the tax reforms introduced by this Government.

I was rather amused to read in the Liberal Party's manifesto this morning that its policy has been approved by the Chairman of the Confederation of Sport, who is a colleague of the honourable member for Flinders. The hundreds of sporting bodies in Australia, the six million sporting devotees in this country and everyone who is interested in sport in this country all know that something the honourable member for Kooyong told me once is correct. When the honourable member for Kooyong was Leader of the Opposition I asked him why his party opposed the first piece of sporting legislation to come into this House since Federation. At that time honourable members opposite were given their first chance to support sporting legislation. The honourable member for Kooyong replied: `Mate, there are millions of votes in sport and you have got the lot; so why shouldn't we oppose it?'. That will continue to be the case.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

—Pursuant to section 37 of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act 1973, I present the annual report and financial statements of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation, together with the Auditor-General's report, for the year ended 31 December 1986.
