DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House of discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The growing community outrage at the increases in the cost of Medicare which needs fundamental changes to ensure all Australians have access to affordable high quality health care.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week, day after day, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) have been trying to justify their Medicare policy. That forlorn effort to sell Medicare to the public is doomed to failure because, of course, no one believes it. On Monday, the Treasurer had the gall to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare is a fair and progressive system . . . It is a piece of progressive social policy.
He is certainly right. It is social engineering. It is typical socialist social engineering-an increase in cost and a substantial decline in the standard of service.

Of the 16 million people in Australia, only two groups have benefited from the introduction of Medicare. The first is the 3,000 new public servants who have been employed to administer the Medicare mess. The other group is the few, unethical entrepreneurial doctors who, with the blessing of the Australian Labor Party, have taken advantage of the Government's bulk billing system. The 100,000 Australians waiting for a public hospital bed-mainly the elderly and the underprivileged-are not enamoured of the new Medicare system. In fact, never has this country had such a national public hospital crisis as it has today. Public hospital queues have more than trebled under Medicare. People are actually dying as they wait for elective surgery.
There has been a rash of headlines in the newspapers on this issue. For example, the Sydney Morning Herald stated:
21 die while on surgery list.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that?
—It is an article by Chris Thomas, and it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Twenty-one patients are known to have died from heart related conditions while waiting for elective cardiac surgery in Sydney's troubled public hospitals.

The Sun shouts: `Shame! No beds for new mums' and `tiniest victim'. It has a photograph of a baby who has been put into hospital and whose mother cannot accompany the baby in hospital. This situation is common right around Australia. Medicare has caused the collapse of the public hospital system right around Australia.

Medicare is responsible for stopping more people than ever before from getting a hospital bed when they need it. Twelve million taxpayers are fed up with having to pay $4,400m more in tax to pay for the Medicare disaster. The 63 per cent of families with children who have maintained their private health cover are disgusted with the increase of 60 per cent from $9.60 to over $15 a week that they have to pay to maintain their basic health cover under Medicare. The specialist health experts have roundly condemned Medicare. For example, only a couple of weeks ago, Professor David Penington, one of Australia's leading health commentators, said:

Bulk-billing as we know it must change and `entrepreneurial' medicine, at the public expense, must be curbed. Private medicine must increasingly look after itself and public funding go where it is most needed. Health maintenance Organisations in the United States have many lessons for us in ensuring that only cost-effecting services are delivered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Penington is a real authority.

—He does have authority. He knows, as do all Australians, that Medicare has totally failed to provide the health cover promised by the Government-and it has cost the Australian community a bomb. The depth of the community's outrage is highlighted by the fact that the Australian Labor Party could not even find an advertising man to handle its multi-million dollar election account who actually agreed with its policies. It picked a man who has been one of the country's most strident public critics of Medicare. Of course, I refer to John Singleton. He had the temerity to tell the grim truth about Medicare when he was a radio announcer on station 2KY. John Singleton knows that Medicare is not working. He knows that it is massively expensive. He says that similar socialist health systems have not worked overseas in the United Kingdom and Canada where they have been tried. He knows that Medicare is costing people their lives rather than saving them. But, as well we all know, the Labor Party does not believe in the right of freedom of speech, as John Singleton soon found out. He found out that, especially in the media, if a person does not take the Labor Party's line, he is out. The Labor Council of New South Wales wrote to Mr Singleton after he had made his comments on 2KY and informed him that he had been sacked by 2KY.
—The Council owned 2KY.
—The Council owned 2KY. It said in its letter to Mr Singleton:

SPEECH.PARA: On every occasion your commentary as to the current dispute between the visiting Medical Specialists and the Federal Government concerning the operation of Medicare has also been in conflict with policies of the Labor Council of New South Wales.
In a document that he has published, John Singleton says:

This is a paragraph from the actual letter I received the day before my suspension and ultimate sacking by radio station 2KY. The letter was signed by the General Manager as instructed by the board led by Trades and Labour Council boss John MacBean.

It is quite clear that this was a concerted attempt by the Labor Party to gag criticism of the disastrous Medicare policy. John Singleton and all right-thinking Australians were incensed by the Labor Party's action. Singleton then launched a campaign and gave himself a high profile in it. The campaign featured him and the sacking. In that publicity campaign he stated his own views about Medicare. While the ad was probably paid for by a private health fund, nevertheless the advertisement carries John Singleton's photo and it expresses his personal concerns about Medicare. The heading is: `I got sacked for telling the truth about Medicare'. There is a photo of Singleton and the ad states: ` ``This is the truth'', by John Singleton'. But there is more. It gets better and better. He also states:

Medicare might be great in theory . . . Every day the media reports how Medicare is and will continue to be a disaster. Similar plans have failed in Great Britain and Canada, and the same thing will happen here. You only have to look at the waiting lists at hospitals to see that.
John Singleton, the Labor Party's ad man, said that. He went on to say:
If you can't afford or don't have private health insurance, all you can do is hope for the best. Hope you don't have to wait in casualty for four hours. Hope there is a doctor there.
He is talking about Medicare, under Labor, under this Minister. John Singleton also says:

Hope that the doctor who treats you and your child in an emergency has been out of medical school or off the boat for more than 10 minutes. If he is a competent doctor, hope he has not been working all night. Hope they can have you x-rayed that day or at least the next.
So he goes on. In the end he quite rightly asks:
Is this good enough for your family?
Of course, the answer is a resounding no. Medicare is not good enough for Australian families. A few paragraphs later in this advertisement John Singleton says:
I didn't think about it until a smashed knee put me into hospital.

In other words, John Singleton has had an experience under this Medicare health policy of the Labor Party and he did not like it. When he started to tell the truth about what had happened to him, and when he started to tell the truth about Medicare, he was sacked. The Labor Party gave him the boot. But, of course, he is only saying what a number of Labor Party Ministers already know. They do not trust the public hospital system. They do not trust the Medicare system. When they get into strife, when they are ill, they do not go to the Medicare system; they go to the private system. The Prime Minister, ex-Premier Neville Wran and nearly all of them, when they have been ill over the last few years, have gone to private hospitals. It is not just Singo who is expressing the true views about Medicare. Most of the Labor Party Ministers also know in their hearts that Medicare is not providing the health care that this country needs. I know that Bob McMullan is tearing his hair out. He is running around like a bee in a bottle.

TALK.START.PARA: —He hasn't got much left either.

—No, he does not have much hair left; the honourable member is quite right. Mr McMullan is setting up emergency meetings and burning the midnight oil, trying to figure out what to do with this disaster collapsing around the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me plead with the Minister for Health, the non-medical Dr Blewett who is at the table: He should not let his colleagues sack Singo. He should not let them sack him again for telling the truth. Clearly the Labor Party's advertising campaign is shot to pieces; certainly any Medicare advertising will now be totally without credibility. But the Labor Party should not worry about that. It should save itself some money because we have the answer to the nation's health problems. Singo will love our health policy and all the Labor Party has to do is to allow Singo to do exactly what he wants to do. He will say that Labor has had it wrong for four years, that the Libs have got it right and that Medicare needs to be fixed up.

Medicare may not be the only area with which the Government will have difficulty in the forthcoming period. It seems to us on this side of the House-we will shortly be on that side of the House-that tax will be an issue in this election. We perceive that the electorate is deeply concerned about the massive decline in their standard of living and the massive increase in the taxes that this Government has foisted on them to pay for its grandiose spending spree. This Government has taxed families to such an extent that a substantial number of them just cannot afford to make ends meet any longer. Of course, the answer is to blow the whistle, take a knife to Commonwealth spending and cut taxes. Our policies will do just that. Lower taxes are fundamental to restoring incentive and growth in this country.

That raises two very basic questions. Firstly, what commitment will the Minister give in this campaign not to increase the Medicare levy? The Minister and the Prime Minister gave a commitment before the last election not to increase the levy, yet they increased it by 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can't be trusted.

—The Minister cannot be trusted. Perhaps he will tell us in his response whether the Government will undertake the same sort of charade in this election of promising not to increase taxes but, as soon it gains power, increasing them.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that I have no doubt that the Labor Party is planning an attack on our tax policy to be released next week. But like the Labor Party's commitments on the Medicare Levy, will its attack on our tax policy have any credibility? Its record in this area is contemptible. It has not kept any of its tax commitments. But in this case it has an even more serious problem, and I raise the question whether it has the right advertising man. Will he be believed when it comes to selling the Government's high spending, high taxing record?
Opposition members-No.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear honourable members say no, because I have my doubts, because my old mate Singo agrees with me regarding the outrageous level of taxes that Australian citizens have been required to pay under this Labor Government. In fact, he goes further. Let me quote from an article in the magazine section of the Adelaide Advertiser of 28 March 1987-this year. This is not vintage Singo from 10 years ago, but Singo a couple of months ago. In an article under the headline `The lovable larrikin' he says of politics:

SPEECH.PARA: Joh doesn't go far enough for me. All he wants is a flat tax. I want absolute deregulation of the economy.

Singo is saying that he does not like this Government's 49 per cent rate and he does not even like Joh's 25 per cent flat rate. He wants lower taxes; yet the Labor Government wants that man to go out and sell its tax record of 49 per cent. It wants him to go out and plan advertisements against our tax rate which will be substantially below the Government's. Clearly the Labor Party's advertising campaign is shot to ribbons. It will totally lack credibility. Singo was right when he said only last week, on 29 May-again in the Adelaide Advertiser:
A hell of a lot of people-
I am quoting; I would not use that language-
have suffered under the Government.
He thought that the poll would be `touch and go'. Of course it will be touch and go.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will come and they will go.

—Precisely. There is more than a touch of chaos opposite and the Government is gone for all money. The Liberal Party does have the answer to the Medicare mess which this Government has got us into. We will change the Medicare program and we will assure the Australian public that it will have access to health care when it needs it and that it will have access to affordable health cover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing one could say is that it is pretty appropriate that this the last matter of public importance on health matters introduced by the Opposition in this Parliament has simply produced a cynical and rather hypocritical performance by the Opposition. The Opposition has talked about our costs; yet it is proposing to impose much higher health costs on the Australian family. With its flat rate private insurance it will burden the ordinary family with a minimum private basic insurance rate of $27 a week, and if that family wants top cover, it will cost up to something like $37 a week. The Liberal Party is the party which complains about problems in public hospitals, but says it will cut the money going to the States for public hospitals. Indeed, under Medicare more people are receiving treatment in our State public hospitals than ever before. It is the Opposition, not the Government, which wants to gut the State public hospital system of funds.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come to the problems with the Opposition's health policy in a moment. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) now talks about means tests in public hospitals. Once again people will have to prove that they are poor before they can use the public hospital system, unless they pay much higher amounts for other cover. The Opposition wants to deny millions of Australians, particularly low income families, access to bulk billing. The whole advantage of bulk billing-that is being able to go to the doctor and to get medical service but not be charged for it-is very much to the benefit of low income families. When we surveyed the situation in Sydney we found that the doctors who are bulk billing work mostly in the working class areas providing those bulk billed services to people in need.

The Opposition has already admitted this week that under its health scheme five million Australians will be worse off. Those five million Australians, are of course, the middle and lower income earners. I have no doubt that the Opposition will be able to design a health scheme which will benefit the well-off, but the five million who it has already admitted will be worse of-I can assure honourable members that the figure will be much higher than that-are in fact middle and lower income earners.

Over the last three years we have given the people of this country a health insurance scheme which, unlike the schemes of the past 20 years, has been basically stable. In fact, under the Fraser Government an entirely new health scheme, not just one with a marginal alternation, was brought in every 18 months. One of the great things that we know the Australian people value is that basically they have had the same health scheme for three years. We have had to make adjustments at the margins, but there has been no change in the principles of Medicare, unlike the Fraser health schemes whereby a new scheme was introduced every 18 months.

There are three characteristics of Medicare to which this Government is firmly, totally and completely committed. The first is that it is a universal system. Under Medicare every Australian is guaranteed basic medical and hospital services. Under the last Fraser scheme, introduced in 1981, two million Australians were without cover provided either by government or through insurance. Our system has provided automatic universal cover so that every Australian need not fear the cost of health or medical cover.

Secondly, Medicare provides equality of access. We do not demand that people show cards and prove themselves to be charity patients in order to get public hospital care. Thirdly and most importantly, particularly in days when health costs are so high, we have related payments to people's income; that is, they contribute to their health cover according to their ability to pay. We have provided quite generous thresholds so that many low income families, not just pensioners, not just the defined disadvantaged, do not have to pay the Medicare levy.

Where are the Opposition's policies? It has been here for four years. We have just listened to the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) for 15 minutes, and all we got was the statement that the Opposition has a health scheme. We did not get a single detail, a single funding arrangement, or a single point about the new scheme. All we got was a lot of waffle about Labor's advertising agency. That reflects the total inability of this Opposition, over four years, to face the health challenges of this country. It has been almost totally negative and totally unconstructive, and this was reflected perfectly in the speech delivered here today. As with all the honourable member's speeches on health, there was nothing of substance in what he had to say. In four years the Opposition has not contributed a single creative idea on health policy in this country. It has simply been a negative wrecker.

It is true that some three or four weeks ago the honourable member for Barker produced a health policy, and almost immediately he was dismissed from his role as shadow health spokesman. So we have to ask what the Opposition's health policy is. What are its costings? We were not able to find out from the contribution of the honourable member for Barker because he had no costings at all in his policy speech-not a single one, other than the fact that he would save $3 billion of Commonwealth moneys. Of course, the Government has had to do the handwork for the Opposition. Again I suppose it is typical. In the Fraser years we were offered five health schemes in seven years. In the last election, if I remember rightly, the previous shadow Minister produced three schemes in the one election campaign. As I say, on 12 April we got this vague document `The Liberal Party and Federal Health policy'. After 18 months the honourable member for Barker produced a health policy and then almost immediately disappeared from the shadow portfolio. He, and the man who at the moment leads the Opposition, have constantly talked about saving $3 billion of public money under Medicare. Let us just be clear what that means. It means transferring $3 billion from the Commonwealth sector on to private shoulders.

I just want to explain-I am glad I have this opportunity on the last day of the Parliament-the costings of the Opposition's scheme. Any effort to remove $3 billion from the Commonwealth Budget under Medicare means that the basic insurance ordinary families will have to buy from private companies in order to get any health cover in this country will cost $27 a week. Let me explain the basis of that. What we can learn from the vague statement made by the honourable member for Barker is that he is going to introduce the scheme that Mr Fraser introduced in 1976 whereby people will be able to opt out of Medicare into private health insurance. That scheme lasted 21 months. The Australian population has every right to ask: `Why are you going back to a scheme that failed after only 21 months in 1976-77?'

Under that scheme something like 64 per cent of the population moved out into private health insurance. Let us see what would happen on this occasion. Medicare benefits for these people currently equal $1.3 billion; that is, there would be $1.3 billion in medical benefits that the Government would not have to pay, but that the private funds would have to pay. That would mean that people would have to take out an extra $8 a week just for medical cover so that the private funds could pay the $1.3 billion. That does not give the Opposition its $3 billion. So where does it go to get it? It has to deny moneys to the public hospitals in the States. To get the $3 billion it would need to deny the public hospitals $1.7 billion. That would mean the States would have to put up their public hospital charges and there would be extra private insurance to pay for that. It would cost a family another $9.80 a week to make up for the extra charges the States would impose every time somebody came into a public hospital.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would it do to inflation?

—We will talk about inflation in a moment. Let us just add those figures together. At the moment the current basic hospital insurance-that is, minimum private insurance-will cost a family $9.60 a week. On to that there would have to be added the medical insurance I have just talked about of $8 a week and the additional basic hospital insurance to make up for the public hospital charges of $9.80. That adds up to $27.40 a week as a result of the changes-the saving of $3 billion. If the $3 billion from public moneys is transferred across to the private sector, all of those extra charges fall on ordinary people. They fall on ordinary people in a most unfair way because the characteristic of private insurance is that it does not charge according to income; it charges a flat rate right across the community. So a family on $20,000 a year pays exactly the same amount as a family on $60,000 a year. All of them pay some $27 a week as a minimum private insurance charge as a result of these transfers.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at it in relation to the present system. People who pay only the levy now and get all their cover through the levy would need an income of $110,000 a year to be better off. If they rely, like I do and many of my colleagues-despite what the shadow spokesman, the honourable member for Barker was saying-simply on the Medicare system because of our faith in the public hospital system, they would need $110,000 family income a year before they would be better off under the Liberal scheme. If a family already has basic private insurance, under the Liberal scheme it would be better off once its income passed $72,000 a year. At the moment if a family on average weekly earnings with private insurance were paying only the levy, it would be paying $21 a week more. If it had already taken out private insurance it would pay $12 a week more. Let that be quite clear. A family on average weekly earnings which pays only the levy now would, under the system, have to pay another $21 a week. If the family is already paying private insurance, it would have to pay another $12 a week. Moreover, even the $3 billion is not saved because once these people contract out of Medicare they would no longer pay the levy. So if 64 per cent move, $1.6 billion of levy receipts will be lost. That is, $1.6 billion has to be found somewhere else. At least it is no longer a saving.

To try to soften the impact of what members of the Opposition are doing, they talk about having a tax rebate for private health insurance. Once that is added, even at the low rate provided by the last Fraser Government, another $1.4 billion would have gone; so there would be no savings. There would be a massive exercise and massive burdens would be placed on the Australian people. The family will lose more than half-something like 80 per cent-of its levy income because the rich and the well-off are opting out, the people who pay the most money into it are opting out. So $1.6 billion is lost. To try to soften the impact of the $27 by providing tax rebates the rest of the savings are lost.

Those opposite will destroy a fair, equitable and open access scheme whereby people pay according to their income by this flat rate, unfair system and there are no real savings because they lose most of their levy earnings. Any effort to soften the impact, which those opposite are going to have to do for electoral reasons, will mean that the rest of the savings will be lost. I think that a most appropriate comment was made this morning by Ken Davidson in an article in the Age newspaper. I noticed that there was no effort by the spokesman for the Opposition to face these issues. Ken Davidson stated:
The doctor/Opposition policies-
a good description-
for health can only be supported out of gross ignorance of how health markets work or out of cold blooded lack of concern for community health and the health of the economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I relish the opportunity to join the debate on this matter of public importance because there is a growing concern in the community at the burgeoning cost of Medicare. What is worse is the fact that Medicare is not delivering the services that this Government claims it does deliver. There is one point that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) missed-conveniently, I would suggest. He made no reference to entrepreneurial medicine in this country. He ought to be ashamed for his promotion of entrepreneurial medicine. It is the Dr Edelstens of this world who are on the increase, who are ripping off the system. While this Government talks about tax cheats and social security fraud it is, at the same time, saying to doctors-not all doctors; I want to emphasise that point-`Go out there and rip off the system'. When we come to government on 11 July the pensioners and the disadvantaged will be bulk billed, but bulk billing will be stopped, as it should be, for all other Australians. There is no good reason why bulk billing should be promoted except by the Australian Labor Party. It is a philosophical bent that the Labor Party has. There is no other reason for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer not only to the burgeoning cost of Medicare, but also to the fact that Medicare has large waiting queues throughout many hospitals in this nation. I want to look at how this Government has fleeced more money from the average family for health care and I want to reassure pensioners and the disadvantaged that they will have nothing to fear under a Howard government in relation to their health and welfare.

The Minister for Health and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) earlier today in Question Time talked about an equitable scheme and equality of access. I would like to put the Health Minister at the end of some of the enormous queues that exist for elective surgery throughout this country. I would ban him from entering a private hospital and let him go to the end of the queue with ordinary Australians to see how he likes it. Where is the equity, I ask him and the Prime Minister, when 100,000 Australians are waiting in those queues for elective surgery? Why did the Prime Minister break the promise that he made when he said that beds would be available for all Australians? Let me repeat that: He said that beds would be available for all Australians. Why has he persisted in saying that the scheme is fair and equitable and that it is running smoothly when the real truth is that it is a disaster on all counts? Medicare is a mess, like the Australian economy is a mess, and it has got to be cleaned up. The rot has got to be stopped.

I shall refer to some of the matters mentioned by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter in relation to the Labor Party's advertising agent, Mr John Singleton, and John Singleton Advertising Pty Ltd. John Singleton now has a contract for $4m to promote the Labor Party in the forthcoming election. I remind the House that John Singleton did not write the advertisements that were referred to on behalf of someone else. As an advertising man he did not write them for someone else; he wrote them for himself. He appeared in them. He is the man who has denounced Medicare. Having denounced it how will he be able to say kind and supportive things about Medicare when he writes the advertisements for this Government? Perhaps the Labor Party will get another advertising agency to handle their health advertisements. But he was telling the truth, let me emphasise that, when he said that our hospitals are sick and when he said that our doctors are sick of it also in some of those quite famous quotes that were mentioned by the honourable member for Barker. I emphasise that he said:
I am telling the truth. I have had personal experience. Medicare is a disaster.

That is the man who is to sell the health policy for this Government. When the Minister for Health introduced the Medicare tax-and the scheme came into operation in February 1984-he said that the one per cent levy would substantially fund Medicare. That tax, as I like to call it, was increased last year to 1.25 per cent, a 25 per cent increase. That levy, that tax, is bringing in $1.6 billion. The levy would need to be about 4 per cent if it were to cover the cost of Medicare to this nation, because we are spending $5.5 billion in outgoings on Medicare.

It is all right for the Minister for Health to stand here today and tell us that if things were changed under the Opposition the public would be paying more; they are paying more now but they are being deceived by this Government. I shall put it in simple terms, not in billions. A person in Australia who goes into a supermarket with $16 in his pocket and finds that when he goes through the check-out, through the turnstile, the girl says, `that will be $55', has a shortfall of $39. That is the equivalent figure. If a person has $16 in his pocket-it is $1.6 billion in the case of the Government-and there is a payout of $55-or $5.5 billion-there is a shortfall of $39-$3.9 billion. Where does that shortfall come from? It comes out of consolidated revenue, out of the pockets of the taxpayers of this country. No wonder there is a growing concern about the burgeoning cost of Medicare in our communities.

But that would not be the worst thing that could happen if the system were working. The Minister should go down to the Victorian hospital system. I took the opportunity last year of talking to some of the specialists at the Royal Melbourne Hospital. The Minister should talk to them and listen to their disgust at the system. I shall quote from a document put out by the Health Department of Victoria. These are average monthly waiting times for people in Melbourne. A patient going to a teaching or specialist hospital to have, say, general surgical procedures performed, in May of 1986, compared with March of this year, would have had to wait 2.6 months, which this year has increased to 3.68 months. For a suburban hospital it was 1.99 months and it is now 2.22 months. For urology surgery it was 2.79 months and that has risen to 5.29 months. In a suburban hospital it would have been 2.88 months and 4.19 months this year. They are just a couple of examples. There are some instances in which there have been decreases in waiting time but overall there has been a massive increase in waiting times for elective surgery in Melbourne. Waiting lists are showing an unhealthy upward trend.

I now turn to the additional amount by which the average family has been taken down during the last 12 months. Apart from the Medicare levy increase, which is about $50 a year for a person on a taxable income of $20,000 about another $100 a year has to be added to that because the maximum gap has been increased from $10 to $20. Pharmaceutical costs have increased, probably costing the average family $20 a year extra. Basic hospital cover has increased, and it has increased because this Government has taken away the Commonwealth private hospital bed day subsidy, costing about another $100 a year. The reduction of Commonwealth benefit from 85 per cent to 75 per cent of schedule fee will put up hospital rates by about $39 a year. If one adds all those figures, one finds that the average Australian family is about $5 to $6 a week worse off.

Finally, I turn to a point that is worrying a lot of people, a lot of pensioners, in our community. An article appeared in yesterday's Melbourne Sun in which concern was expressed that under a Howard government pensioners would be disadvantaged. Let me assure honourable members opposite that pensioners and the disadvantaged in this country will not fall for the scaremongering of the Labor Party members opposite. Right throughout their branches they are doing that sort of thing. I assure them that the people will not fall for that. They have nothing to fear under a Howard-led government from 11 July.

Last year, both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) admitted that the economy was in deep trouble. The Prime Minister said that we were in a position akin to the seriousness of wartime. He said that the party was over. The Treasurer talked about a banana republic. Who steered the economy in the disastrous direction in which it is heading? The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Treasurer, Mr Keating. They cannot blame the Liberal Party; they cannot blame the National Party; they cannot blame an obstructionist Senate; they cannot blame the Fraser Government; they cannot blame the international community. No, the blame falls fairly and squarely on the shoulders of the Hawke-Keating Government. Mr Hawke, you have failed! Mr Keating, you have failed! And on 11 July they both must go and all their Ministers and back benchers with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), I am extremely disappointed that although the Opposition has had the opportunity of explaining to all Australians the precise impact of its health policy and of giving the Government the right to respond, it has squandered that opportunity. No new detail has been given and no new aspect has been explained by either the former shadow Minister for Health or the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges). I must express a concern, because health is a very important issue for millions of Australians, that it was an opportunity for the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) to yet again reveal on this most important matter mirth and subdued cynicism. I regret that. The health needs of Australians are too great to be trivialised.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true to say that this Government has provided a universal system of health coverage. That means that it does not matter whether a person is poor or rich, a pensioner or disadvantaged, a member of a young family trying to build a family life, that person is entitled under our scheme, without recourse to position or privilege, to basic medical services. That is a great triumph of this Government. Look what happened in the seven years of the Fraser Government-and that is all we have with which to compare ourselves. We had five health schemes. The important point that the Australian people should understand is that under the previous Liberal Government two million people were not covered by that Government's scheme or by private insurance. In the western suburbs of Sydney, with 1 1/2 million people, I can anticipate-and I regret anticipating it-that up to a quarter of a million people will not be able to afford the Opposition's health policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a flat rate of $27 a week.

—As the honourable member for Dobell says, by way of interjection, it will be a flat rate of $27 a week. That is what is so obscene about the Opposition's proposal; It does not matter what a person earns, he will still pay $27 a week. A shop assistant, a bank clerk, a labourer and a technician-it does not matter what their level of income is-will pay the same amount of money as the white-shoe brigade, stockbrokers and millionaires. Where is the social justice and equity in such a scheme? The honourable member for Petrie talked about the Medicare levy being a 1.25 per cent tax on the Australian people. Under Fraser, the levy was 2.5 per cent. Even the honourable member opposite would understand that that is precisely twice the amount of the existing levy. The Economic Planning Advisory Council, in a paper entitled `Aspects of the Social Wage,' stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The main beneficiaries of Medicare are wage earners and their families, particularly less well off families.
In the western suburbs of Sydney, there are many young people trying to establish homes and families. They are the main beneficiaries of Medicare. The paper continued:
Since the share of health benefits received by the lower income groups is greater than the share of private income received by these groups, the redistributive effect is progressive.

It is not regressive which it would be under the Opposition's scheme where millionaires would pay the same amount as poor people in the community. No mention was made in the House of the rate at which the Opposition would set the levy. Why does it not come clean? What is its hidden agenda? What is the horror Budget that it would bring down? What would the levy be? Did the honourable members for Petrie and Barker deny that they would set the levy at 5 per cent or greater? Did they say what the amount of rebate would be? The honourable member for Petrie referred to the Sun newspaper of 3 June. I would like to read the full quotation to the House because the honourable member launched into a vicious attack of Mrs Nora Maguire of the Combined Pensioners Association. I attend the regional meetings of the Combined Pensioners Association in the western suburbs of Sydney. The Association comprises a very fine group of men and women who have done a lot for this country. Let me read the full quotation--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I was accused of referring to a name when I made no such reference.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Nora Maguire, of the Combined Pensioners' Association, said pensioners did not want the system abolished-
that is, the Medicare system-

We don't want a return to the pre-Medicare days when pensioners had to wait out in the cold, out-patients clinics for doctors' charities. Pensioners want to know if Mr Howard is going to reduce the Medicare rebate to 60 per cent, as demanded by the Confederation of Australian Industry.

What Mrs Maguire said is true of all Australians; they want to know whether the Opposition would reduce the rebate from its current level to 60 per cent. The Opposition, particularly the honourable member for Petrie, talks about hospital waiting lists. I think that I should say a few things about those. The Opposition would cut $1.3 billion from State government funds, doubling the cost of public hospitals. What would be the inference there? What is the Opposition's hidden objective and agenda in terms of this freedom of choice about which it talks? Does it anticipate shifting more people from public hospitals to private hospitals? Is it dissatisfied with the present occupancy rate of private hospitals? The truth is that between 1976 and 1983 the occupancy rate in private hospitals was 59.5 per cent and in 1986, under Medicare, it was 59.6 per cent. What is the Opposition trying to achieve? At the recent Health Ministers Conference which was held in April, all Australian Health Ministers agreed that the States and Territories have primary responsibility for the administration of public hospital services. That was a unanimous decision. The Ministers identified what they thought were some of the causes of those waiting times. They were: Nursing shortages, resulting in bed closures; undersupply of some specialist services, such as orthopaedic surgeons; advances in technology in allowing some procedures to be more readily performed; and greater public awareness of new and improved technology leading to greater demand.

I would like to outline some of the real benefits that have accrued through increases in technology. For example, if one compares 1980-81 with 1985-86, one finds that there has been a 77 per cent increase in general surgery, a 99 per cent increase in ophthalmic surgery, and a 45 per cent increase in thoracic surgery. Over the same period there has been a 320 per cent increase in lens extraction and replacements; a 30 per cent increase in hip replacements; a 41 per cent increase in open heart surgery, and a 51 per cent increase in pacemaker operations. Of course, the honourable member for Petrie could not help himself. He floated the figure of 100,000 Australians on waiting lists. Let me refer to a hospital brief-the newsletter of the Australian Hospital association. Anyone who has had anything to do with hospitals understands the independence of that organisation. As a former director of a public hospital-the Mount Druitt hospital-which I was very proud to be, I certainly do. The April 1987 issue of the journal said that the figure was 54,000.

To sum up: The Opposition is misleading the public. It will not come clean and say how much its levy would be. The former Government's last levy was 2.5 per cent. The Opposition will not say how much the rebate would be. Pensioners are concerned that their rebates would be cut by 60 per cent. The disadvantaged would be worse off. People would not be covered, including up to a quarter of a million in my electorate. Opposition members do not acknowledge that their colleagues, Territory and State Ministers, have acknowledged that waiting lists are a State responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the House to present the report of the Australian delegation to the Seventy-sixth Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference held in Buenos Aires, Argentina, from 6 to 11 October 1986, and to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the Seventy-sixth Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference held in Buenos Aires, there were three main topics on the agenda: Firstly the contribution of parliaments to the application and progress of humanitarian law, which is a very important issue; secondly, the contribution of parliaments, in the context of the International Year of Peace; and, thirdly, a general political debate and a shorter debate on a supplementary item. I wish very briefly to touch upon the debate in which I as Deputy Leader of the Australian delegation was able to take part. That was the debate on the importance and role of parliaments in the application and progress of humanitarian law. The question is sometimes asked: Is it worthwhile Australia, this Parliament, being represented in the Inter-Parliamentary Union? On balance, I believe that it is. I believe that, with other truly democratic countries, there is a useful role for us to play. I believe that, on balance, there is value to this country in helping to identify important issues of international significance and to draw from the knowledge and information that come forward at such conferences and to put them into application in our own country.

SPEECH.PARA: In this regard, the debate on humanitarian law is a very good illustration. At the Conference, parliaments were urged to do a number of things. They were urged to sign and ratify the conventions and protocols-the Geneva conventions, the Red Cross conventions, as they are sometimes commonly known. They are important conventions because they try to set standards of behaviour in times of international conflict. Australia has signed the conventions but not yet ratified the protocols. I am disappointed that this Parliament is coming to a conclusion in a situation where, in spite of the commitments and promises of the Government that Australia would ratify the protocols and legislate accordingly, the legislation has been given relatively low priority. Yet again, with a concern about the upgrading of the standards of humanitarian law around the world, we as parliamentarians must talk to our electors and the Red Cross and tell them that the legislation has been put off. As members of the Inter-Parliamentary Union taking part in the conferences, we have a responsibility not only to go to the conferences but also to return and put into action useful, sensible and desirable things that are asked of us.

The second issue in respect of the humanitarian law conventions was that it was urged on parliaments that they play their part in the education of the civilian population on the principles of humanitarian law. In this regard, there is a need for the parliaments to start with themselves. I was pleased that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence agreed to invite representatives of the Australian Red Cross to give a seminar on the implications of the protocols yet to be ratified by Australia although, as I said, it has promised to do so. Unfortunately, the early termination of this Parliament has meant that that discussion with the Red Cross and members of this House and of the Senate has had to be postponed until the next Parliament.

Thirdly, the Conference urged that parliamentarians take action through governments and parliaments to ensure that those in our military forces are adequately educated as to the meaning and significance of humanitarian law. Furthermore, it was urged that we should ensure, through parliaments and through governments, that the standing orders and command orders, at whatever level those orders may be given, contain adequate reference to and give appropriate instruction on the codes of conduct that must be complied with by our defence forces if they are to adhere to the standards set in those conventions and protocols.

The fourth matter that was raised at the Conference was the important role that Australia and all countries could play in improving the technology so that there is greater adherence to humanitarian law generally, whether in openly declared war or in those circumstances where war is taking place under the guise of internal revolution. Even in those cases, the protocols require certain standards of behaviour that are designed to protect civilians and also to protect those who were formerly in the defence forces and who, for one reason or another, have withdrawn from the conflict. I hope that we can use the IPU and its conferences to play our part in improving the world, improving our adherence to and understanding of humanitarian law and doing other positive things that a body such as the IPU can achieve.

At the Conference, we in the Australian delegation urged that there be a supplementary debate on the deleterious effect on world trade of the subsidisation of agricultural production. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is important to Australia. That subsidisation is causing some of our economic difficulties today. The proposal was supported but not sufficiently well for it to be debated in Buenos Aires. However, the vote was adequately strong for members of the Australian delegation to come away from the Conference and report to the Parliament that, at the recent Conference held in Nicaragua, an item on the main agenda was the contribution of parliaments to the achievement of fair international trade and all its aspects, including trade in agricultural products, elimination of tariff and other barriers and a better understanding of the socio-economic impact of protectionism, particularly on developing countries. There will be an opportunity to consider the outcome of the more recent Conference when the report of the delegation to the Seventy-seventh Conference is tabled in this Parliament. It was useful for us to recognise that Australia was able to use its influence at the Conference to bring before the parliamentarians of the 80 to 100 parliaments represented in the IPU a matter of discussion that is of importance to us, as it is important to so many other countries around the world.

In concluding, I would like to thank my colleagues on the delegation-Senator Colston, the leader of the delegation, and members of the delegation, Senator Jessop, the honourable member for St George (Mr Dubois), the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who all played an important part in representing Australia at that Conference. I would especially like to thank Mr Peter Murdoch, the secretary to the delegation, and Mr Geoff Crawford, the Department of Foreign Affairs adviser who accompanied the delegation, for their work and effort on behalf of the members of the delegation and on behalf of the delegation as a whole. It was a valuable conference and I am sure I am able to report that on this occasion at least-even if it is not true of some other occasions with regard to the Inter-Parliamentary Union or, indeed, other Australian delegations overseas-we were able to make a useful contribution for and on behalf of this Parliament and on behalf of the people we represent. It now remains for us only to be certain that we play our part in implementing the positive resolutions, the acceptable resolutions, of that inter-parliamentary body in a way that enables future delegations to go to the Conference and say that we have done what earlier conferences have recommended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My statement concerns the guidelines for annual reports. I speak in my capacity as the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. As honourable members are aware, the Commonwealth Government departments are required to prepare annual reports on their operations. These reports are prepared under sub-section 25 (6) of the Public Service Act and must be in accordance with guidelines from time to time presented to Parliament by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) after approval by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. They provide information to the Parliament and to the people of Australia and are one means by which public accountability requirements are fulfilled. The Committee, in its role of watchdog of the public purse, not only examines reports of the Auditor-General but also plays a part in establishing the guidelines by which departments themselves report to the Parliament. The Committee welcomes the opportunity to continue to perform this role.

SPEECH.PARA: On 27 November 1986 the Public Accounts Committee tabled its 262nd report, on guidelines for annual reports. This report was prepared after the Committee received a new set of guidelines from the Prime Minister to replace the 1982 guidelines. The Committee has now received revised draft guidelines in a letter from the Prime Minister to me, in my capacity as Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, requesting that the Committee consider the revised guidelines. I seek leave to table that letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes that until certain amendments are made to the Audit Act 1901 it would not be possible to incorporate some of the Committee's recommendations on financial reporting requirements as set out in its 262nd report. As it is likely that the guidelines will need further modifications during the phasing-in period of the new financial reporting arrangements, the Committee will comment further on those modifications at the appropriate time.

Further, the Committee is strongly of the view that departments and authorities should report in their annual reports on reviews by the Auditor-General and parliamentary committees. These reports should include recommendations made by these bodies and any action taken to address the recommendations. The Committee believes that such a requirement would enhance the public accountability of the administration and would be a particularly valuable and timely follow-up mechanism. The Committee recommends that this requirement be included in the revised guidelines and forwarded to departments prior to the preparation of 1987-88 annual reports. The Committee has approved the revised guidelines as they currently stand and will continue to monitor further amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before lunch, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) raised a number of issues relating to the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987. As I did not have time to canvass one of those issues before lunch, I do so now. The issue refers to the cost involved in the reporting mechanism associated with the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. Under the terms of the legislation, the Agency is to be established at a cost of the order of $2.6m, yet the Australian Taxation Office has estimated that the increased revenue that would accrue to the Government from the development of such an agency would, in fact, total $30m. As the honourable member for Denison said, that seems fairly reasonable budgeting and economics. We spend $2.6m and we make $30m. Therefore, I agree with his assessment that it must be a very worthy feature of this operation. However, I disagree with his observations, gained from his discussions with the Australian Bankers Association and from other purported discussions with representatives of the financial sector, that there are some hidden costs involved in establishing this Agency and in the reporting mechanism that is necessary under the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be pointed out that the Australian Bankers Association, in its estimates, does not give any justification for those estimates or how they are arrived at. That is most important, because it talks about figures such as $80m for the establishment of the system and $75m on a yearly basis to administer it. I think the honourable member for Denison said that what would happen when the cost to building societies and other financial institutions was taken into account was that it would boost the amount to in excess of $100m. The Government has investigated these particular proposals, but no justification has ever been given for the amounts cited. As far as the Government is concerned, they are without substantiation and therefore they are dismissed.

The question of people being asked to verify who they are when opening accounts was also raised. It was said that verification of this kind was something which impinged upon banks' operations, and that they already had in existence a voluntary code whereby when people came in to open an account some form of appropriate identification was already undertaken. The most common form of identification is passports, although other forms of identification may be used. A passport has an address, a number and a photograph. I can recall that during debates in this place on the Australia Card people talked about those very things-the fact that there was an address, a number and a photograph on a plastic card and that that therefore constituted some invasion of privacy.

In the debate on the Australia Card, in the debate on the Proceeds of Crime Bill and in debates on other pieces of legislation introduced in order to fight organised crime, concerns were raised about the appropriateness of things such as passports being used for identification purposes simply because they are capable of being forged. Some people were saying that the biggest growth industry when the Australia Card is introduced will be the forgery of Australia Cards. Obviously, the Australian Bankers Association and other organisations which will be affected by this Bill in the past under their voluntary code have been prepared to use those sorts of identification. We contend that, under the Bill, a voluntary code in place is all well and good; but what happens if that code is not adhered to? That in itself is a fairly cogent argument which goes to the heart of why we should have legislation that makes it important and indeed fixes it in law that certain forms of identification must be made. Again, it goes back to why this legislation is being put in place. It is being put in place to enable the police forces and the Australian Taxation Office to follow the money trail, and because it is another tool in the armoury to fight organised crime in Australia.

The honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), in his contribution this morning, compared the benefits that might accrue to Australia with evidence that came from the United States. The experience in the United States has been summarised in a statement by Francis A. Keating, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury of the United States of America. He talked about a bank secrecy Act which has similar provisions to those we are introducing here. He stated:

This Bank Secrecy Act has proven beyond all doubt its effectiveness as a law enforcement tool against drug trafficking, organised crime and the illicit financial activity that supports it. The investigations that the Departments of Justice and Treasury have conducted, particularly those under the President's organised crime drug enforcement task force program, have relied upon the Bank Secrecy Act data and the analysis of these data the Treasury has prepared. In approximately three years of full operation these task forces have initiated 1,350 cases and resulted in the indictments of 8,649 individuals, 3,678 of which have been convicted.

No further evidence is necessary of how effective the legislation that we are dealing with this afternoon will be in the fight against organised crime. It fulfils the aim of providing a method whereby we will be able to check, and the Australian Taxation Office will be able to check, the money trail. As has already been stated in the debate, the Bill requires cash dealers to report cash transactions involving $10,000 or more, to which the dealer is a party, to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency unless the transaction is exempt. That is provided for in clause 6. The Bill also requires persons transferring foreign currency out of Australia, or transferring Australian or foreign currency into Australia, to report the transfer to the Agency if the amount involved is $5,000 or more.

It is interesting that the amounts of $5,000 and $10,000 seemed to get the honourable member for Denison rather excited this morning when he was discussing this matter. I believe that those specified amounts are fair and reasonable. They provide the opportunity for the Agency to keep tabs on the movement of cash into and out of Australia. Many examples have previously been given of the laundering of money from illicit drug dealings through other forms of crime in Australia. They have clearly demonstrated that there is a need for, and in fact an obligation on the part of the Australian Parliament to put in place, the correct legislative base for having the Taxation Office, police forces and so on follow that money trail.

I return to what I was saying immediately before the suspension of sittings for lunch. I was talking about organised crime in Australia in a general sense. I was responding to some points that had been made by the honourable member for Denison and also some comments that had been made by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). The honourable member for North Sydney said that this legislation should be sent to a joint select committee for further examination. I repeat now what I said earlier: When the telecommunications interception legislation came before the Parliament and it, in turn, was sent to a joint select committee, the honourable member for North Sydney, in his contribution to that debate when the legislation was returned to the House earlier this week, criticised the Government for taking that course of action. So on the one hand he is suggesting that one of the Bills in this package that is useful in the fight against organised crime should be delayed and should be sent to a joint select committee; on the other hand, he argues that when that was done in the case of some Bills that had wider ramifications in terms of telephone tapping, that was not the correct way in which to proceed.

The final matter to which I return is the comment that was made about organised crime and the relationship between crime in New South Wales and the Labor Government in that State. Again, I say that one has only to look at the position in Queensland that has been recently exposed, and at the puny response from that Government to the putting in place of an investigation which merely scratches the surface of organised crime in that State, to see the response that comes from conservative governments in this country. I put to the House that unless we are fair dinkum-unless every government and every member of legislatures in Australia is fair dinkum-organised crime will flourish. It is only through a combination of these sorts of Bills that we can get an effective mechanism to fight this crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are, in my opinion, dealing with a very important piece of legislation-the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987. This is part of the Government's onslaught on organised crime. I was sorry to hear in the debate before lunch that the Opposition proposes to have the legislation deferred so that it can be considered by a joint select committee of the Parliament. The Parliament is about to be dissolved. That means that the legislation would be deferred until 1988 or 1989. Any member who has had dealings with parliamentary select committees knows that they do not often bring down a report promptly. The whole reason for the delay is that the Australian Bankers Association says that it will cost it some money. People who have ever tried to open a bank account for an organisation, a local political party branch, or for themselves, know the difficulties involved in opening such an account. For example, if a person tries to open an account for the Five Dock Progress Association he or she is asked for copies of minutes, signatures and authorisations. There have always been strict procedures. Surely the banks do not just let people come along and open accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Part of the legislation will tighten up the procedures for opening bank accounts in accordance with recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, Mr Justice Stewart and all the different people who have looked at this area of crime and tax evasion. They all say that we have slipshod methods of allowing people to open accounts, even though there are procedures-and I pay tribute to the banks-that are quite rigid. But the Opposition has said that we cannot have this tightening up of procedures for bank accounts because it might cost $180m to set up and then $75m a year to run. Today the Opposition has cited a lower figure of $60m. We must look at this matter in the context of what it is costing Australia and what penalty we are paying for illicit drug traffic, organised crime, corruption and tax evasion. This method of notifying cash transactions involves banks, building societies and credit unions notifying cash transactions in excess of $10,000-that is all it involves-and international dealings in cash in excess of $5,000 in any currency.

The Parliamentary Library has very kindly given me details of the banks' profits. The profits are pre-tax profits. The figure for the Westpac Banking Corporation is $658m; the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, $607m; the Commonwealth Bank, $445m; and the National Australia Bank, $491m. So they are making profits of more than half a billion dollars. The banks will complain if any additional requirement is introduced. Additional record keeping is now required of them. They now have to keep records for seven years. There will be complaints if we make them give any details to government, but this is part of the Government's offensive against organised crime, the drug traffic, and all of those illegal activities which involve large sums of cash.

I pay tribute to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for bringing forward this legislation. I point out that the situation in the United States of America, where such legislation has operated for some years, is very similar. Similarly, the American Bankers also opposed the legislation and fought it tooth and nail. Yet in the United States all independent observers have admitted that it has been successful and it has resulted in a vast number of convictions for organised crime, tax evasion and illicit currency transactions. A wide cross-section of people in the community have been caught including accountants, solicitors, lawyers and people who deal in the money market-under this requirement that banks notify cash transactions, and that is what this legislation does. I think it is a shame that the Opposition has nothing positive to add on this except to suggest that it be referred to a select committee. Having rejected the Australia Card, the Opposition probably had no alternative. This legislation is certainly locked in with this whole notion of identifying taxpayers and people with large sums of cash going in and out of bank accounts or in and out of the country. The Opposition's only contribution is to say: `Well, defer it. Have a select committee look at it. Let us get Bob White and the bankers in here to tell us how bad it is and how much trouble it will be'. Really, the legislation will not affect ordinary Australians.

I was a solicitor in the Government and in private practice for many years and I never handled $10,000 or even $5,000 in cash in that whole time. The ordinary Australian man, woman or business person does not handle large sums of cash unless it is in relation to a payroll or while giving out wages. People taking out money for payrolls go into an exemption register. The legislation does not affect people in retirement. It may affect some ethnic families where there might be a central cash pool where family members borrow $1,000 from one relative and $1,000 from another. It may be that some people do not have cheque accounts, but that would be rare; and it would be rare for someone to have $20,000 or $15,000 in cash. However, they would have an explanation; these people are basically honest and they would have an explanation. If one can explain that the money is for a cash transaction, one has nothing to worry about. The ordinary citizen is not affected by this legislation whatsoever; it is to catch people who deal with large sums of money illegally.

The second aspect, as I have said already, is to tighten up procedures for opening bank accounts. I have found that, unfortunately, old, retired people often open many bank accounts. If anything, it will be a good thing if people are discouraged from having a multiplicity of bank accounts, which can be used by dishonest people for all sorts of illicit transactions. Old people are penalised in the long run because when they pass away the solicitor handling their estate can claim a separate fee for closing every one of those small bank accounts. I always tell old people: `Why don't you put all your savings into one or two accounts instead of having several accounts at the local building society, the credit union and the bank.'. So it may be that there will be some positive good for elderly folk if there are more security procedures and a tightening up in relation to the opening and operating of bank accounts.

Honourable members would well remember some of the disclosures over the years. In fact, the Library drew to my attention today the case of a teller at a branch of the National Bank in York Street who in May 1985 admitted that several accounts had been opened by a well known policeman, but the accounts were not in his name-they were in other fictitious names. It was also alleged that a bank manager in a western Sydney suburb was party to the opening of accounts in false names. I am sure that this does not surprise or shock people, but we do expect savings and trading banks, credit unions and building societies to take action to ensure that people who open accounts are the people they say they are.

The legislation contains very stringent provisions which will require people to identify themselves properly when they are opening a bank account; and banks will have two years in which to verify that their existing accounts are operated by the people named as the account holder. If a bank account is in the name of a natural person, it shall contain the person's identification details. Under the term `identification details' the owner of a bank account can be identified through a prescribed identification number, which will apply when the Australia Card legislation is passed. Tourists, visitors or non-residents-and as far as I know we do permit non-residents to open bank accounts-who will not have an Australia Card and therefore will not have a prescribed identification number will be required to give their full name and address and either of two methods of identification: First, through the tax file number, for non-residents working in Australia on a work visa; or secondly, through a passport, a certified copy of a person's birth certificate, a citizenship certificate or, alternatively, some other form of identification which in the opinion of the financial institution concerned is sufficient to establish the person's identity. It is a bit hard to think of what would apply there but I suppose it could be a travel document apart from a passport or an army discharge document or something else which contains a photograph. However, those things are not always accurate and can be forged.

Great steps are being taken to ensure that banks verify identification details when $10,000 cash is deposited in an account by a citizen, two citizens, a group of people running a company or acting as trustees for a certain company or the treasurer of an organisation. That will apply to everyone. For company accounts the certificate of incorporation will have to be shown. The legislation also applies to institutions. I feel a bit sorry for banks which deal with unincorporated associations, including local progress groups, school organisations and little groups started as unincorporated organisations perhaps for particular campaigns. All of those bodies will have to produce a copy of the instrument or instruments under which the signatories to the account are authorised to sign. The minutes of meetings and evidence to establish identification will be required. Of course, all of that will be made redundant and will be done away with if and when the Australia Card legislation is passed.

The Australia Card will greatly assist in verifying the identity of those opening bank accounts. Of course, as I said, this legislation ties in with the Australia Card. It is clear that the Opposition is not game enough to reject the Cash Transaction Reports Bill and say that it does not want it-it wants a bit each way. The Opposition says that it wants to refer the legislation to a select committee because banks have said that it will cost money. That may be so, but the Australian people want something done to stop the drug dealers, illegal crime and those people who are making an illicit fortune in this society. Members opposite need look only at the 1985-86 annual report of the National Crime Authority, which points out that there is a need to get at people who are making a lot of money out of large scale crime. It is one thing for the Government to do what it has done with its Proceeds of Crime Bill, but it is essential to facilitate the cracking down on crime and on all sorts of illegal activities. This historic piece of legislation is one way that we can crack down on crime and on people who are illicitly operating bank accounts and handling large sums of cash or alternatively taking money out of the country or bringing it in. As I said earlier, all international transactions over $5,000 and all transactions over $10,000 within Australia must be reported. If people have nothing to hide, they have nothing to worry about. The legislation is aimed at those people who are engaging in crime or other activities.

I believe that this legislation will have very far-reaching effects. It establishes the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, which will receive reports that will be available to the Commissioner of Taxation. He will have direct and unrestricted access to the agency to obtain information. Law enforcement groups such as the Australian Customs Service, the National Crime Authority and the State law enforcement agencies will also have access to the agency. Anyone who has followed the debate will understand the usefulness of such a procedure in fighting crime and illicit activities. The very stringent secrecy provisions in the legislation will apply to the staff and to every person dealing with the material and the information that is collated.

The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) said this morning that it might be a good thing to support the proposed authority in principle, but that it would require an army of employees. It will not, because its work will be done by computers. The honourable member said that everything would be processed by hand, but, in fact, that will apply only to the opening of accounts. Naturally, there must be some verification of accounts. Banks and building societies have to stop throwing around bank accounts. All my children, even those under five, have bank accounts and school savings accounts, some with about 20c in them. I find passbooks all over the house. They get them in one school after the other-primary, secondary and so on. I had to declare those accounts in my pecuniary interests, but I could not catalogue them because there were so many of them. I had to note them as `miscellaneous school bank accounts'.

The banks must become more responsible. They cannot simply allow people to open accounts willy-nilly without any verification of identity. Of course, in schools they can verify the identity of pupils and there is no attempt to hoodwink anybody. However, I feel that at times banks have been slack in allowing people to open accounts. As I said earlier, over the past few years blatant incidents have been reported in the Press in New South Wales of bank managers being a party to the deception and the illicit creation of bank accounts in fraudulent names. I wonder what happens to the careers of some of those officers. Surely they must be demoted or left under a cloud. They allowed people to open accounts illegally in a false name. It is a very sad reflection on those involved.

This legislation will do much to strengthen the hand of a bank manager who is leant on by someone who says: `I want to open an account in a false name'. The Bill will be good for bank officers, managers and accountants, who will thank heaven that, because of the Bill, they can tell such a person that the Federal authority is looking at all cash transactions and that there is legislation for the reporting of all large cash transactions and to strengthen the procedures for opening accounts. They can tell the potential customer that they have to verify his name, the name of his company and the incorporation certificate. Under the verification details, they will have to cite the customer's tax and passport numbers. If he does not have a passport, he has to produce his birth certificate, Australian citizenship certificate or some other certificate to verify who he is. Such a person cannot just go into a bank and say that he wants to open an account.

It is a shame that, on the eve of an election, the Opposition has said: `No, let those engaged in illegal activities, organised crime and tax evasion go'. It said that in 1982, when it did nothing about the bottom of the harbour schemes. Mr Costigan revealed some of the appalling scandals in tax evasion. Indeed, the McCabe-Lafranchi report came up with some revelations in the Victorian Parliament, but the Opposition did nothing about it. The Australian people then judged the Opposition as allowing people to rip off the tax system and to get away with organised crime. The Opposition has not even put an argument against the Bill on the ground of privacy; it has put only the argument that the bankers say that it will cost too much money. Well, the bankers in America said the same, but the American law enforcement agencies say that it has been a great success and has resulted in many thousands of convictions for illicit currency dealings, drug offences, crime and tax fraud. I hope that the House will pass the legislation and reject the Opposition's entire fraudulent argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first comment is to praise the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher). I am sure that he will return to this House with an increased majority because of his reputation as one of Parliament's greatest advocates of tougher action against those involved in organised crime and welfare fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: The Cash Transaction Reports Bill will require institutions such as banks to report cash transactions involving $10,000 or more when they take place within Australia. If a transaction of $5,000 or more is made between Australia and another country, whether in dollars or in foreign currency, that transaction must also be reported to the Government. The Government believes that law enforcement authorities should have access to that information because it is well known that those involved in organised crime and major tax scandals use cash transactions to hide and to launder the proceeds of their criminal activities. This legislation is long overdue, and it is a credit to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that it is before the House today.

This is not the only Bill that this Government has introduced in seeking to combat criminal activities. In this session it introduced the Proceeds of Crime Bill that will ensure that if people are involved in the sale and distribution of narcotics and drugs, the assets that they accrue from those illegal activities can be forfeited to the Crown. In addition, at this very minute, legislation that will alter the law that provides for telephone interceptions is before the other chamber. We hope that, in a short time, it will resolve its mind on that legislation. The Government has advocated that the Australian Federal Police be allowed to carry out telephone intercepts in new areas to ensure that those who are committing offences are brought before the courts.
