However, it is nice to have a lady Speaker. You are a very nice person. We wish you well in your role. Of course, the Speaker holds a non-political position; so I will not drag politics into this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to put me back again if you win?

—Madam, your unfailing courtesy restrains me from saying more, but we do wish you well. I join the Prime Minister in thanking the Clerks of the House, Hansard, the attendants, the parliamentary broadcasters--
—The cooks.

—Indeed, I thank the cooks. I thank everybody who makes this boarding school, as many choose to call it, keep going. It will be different in that new and larger building. In some respects, I am not sure that some of the cosiness of this place will not be lost and I am not sure that that is a good thing. But that is a decision that has passed us by. Of my own colleagues, I particularly thank the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) who have been the Opposition Whip and Deputy Whip since September 1985. I thank my colleague and Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Ian Sinclair, not only for his general assistance, advice and counsel, but also for his political partnership. I also thank the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) who has been the Manager of Opposition Business.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, we will be embarking upon a very vigorous political enterprise. I cannot and will not in the spirit of partisan conflict wish the return-and I do not expect it to occur-of all those who sit opposite. At least this week we have resolved that one person will not be coming to the Federal Parliament. But there are many more arrayed in front of me who will not be coming back. Where is Helen? She appears to have gone already. But, in the spirit of the Prime Minister, I do convey personal good wishes to everybody. We on this side of the House look forward with enormous enthusiasm and relish to the convening of the Thirty-fifth Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, which will number within its ranks Australia's twenty-fourth Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In this, the fading hours of the Thirty-fourth Parliament, I would like to join the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in their valedictory remarks. This place is an extraordinary forum. I suspect that on occasions most of us are cynical about the attitudes and views not only of those on the opposite side of the House but also within our own ranks. But, above all, it is a place where we suffer a uniqueness which those who do not serve or have not served in the parliaments of the Commonwealth, either at a Federal or State level, really cannot quite comprehend. It is a separateness from the community which often worries me. It is a product of our isolation or semi-isolation in Canberra. Yet it is a necessary role which all those who serve this House and who have made this, the Thirty-fourth Parliament, work effectively, all appreciate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to join in referring, first, to those who are leaving this House voluntarily-Peter Drummond, Peter Coleman, and Paul Everingham from this side of the House; Ralph Jacobi and Len Keogh from the other side of the House- although Len Keogh with perhaps not quite the same measure of intentional direction as the others. I would like to say to them how in their several ways I have admired and respected their parliamentary contributions. Peter Drummond is one of those who, having originated in New South Wales, saw the light and went west as a young man. He and Lachie have made a significant contribution in their State as farmers. But Peter has been a tremendous contributor, particularly in the formulation of primary industry policy, on the coalition side of the House. To Peter, whom I have known very well for so many years, I would like to say: `Good luck to you and Lachie in your future life'. I say good luck to Peter Coleman, who is a great colleague and a great friend, and also to Paul Everingham who, as both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition have said, made such a notable contribution as Chief Minister of the Northern Territory in those early days when the heady wine of self-government first gave to that part of Australia some of the opportunities that the rest of us have enjoyed for so long.

I would also like to make some reference to those who are leaving the Senate. Three who come particularly to my mind are Senator Sir John Carrick, of whom the Leader of the Opposition made mention, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and the Rt Hon. Reg Withers. I have worked with all three in successive governments. They are all persons of significant capability. While on occasions perhaps some may have achieved a certain amount of notoriety-I guess `the toecutter' more than others-each has been a very remarkable contributor in the Senate and to the processes of parliamentary democracy in Australia. I say to them and to the others who are also retiring from the Senate at this time that I wish them well on behalf of the members of the National Party.

To you, Madam Speaker, and to your deputies I, on behalf of the members of my Party, would like to extend our thanks and say to you, as did the Leader of the Opposition, that, while there have been occasions when we have not always agreed, it is an unenviable task that you, your deputies and those who assist you have to perform. I doubt that there is a more lonely place in the Parliament than sitting in that chair. I know that those of us who sit down here and who are the protagonists of this adversarial atmosphere certainly tend to make it very difficult at times for you to pass judgment in a dispassionate way.

I confess that on occasions I know that I have also tested the patience of the Clerks but I compliment them for the manner, expertise and professionalism with which they undertake their task. They, perhaps more than any of us, are the great inheritors of tradition. Madam Speaker, the one thing that I have regretted as far as you are concerned is that you do not wear a gown or show any signs of those traditions that are important and which, of course, the Clerks still affect. I regard that as an important part of Parliament and I am thankful that at least the Clerks retain it.
The Hansard writers add to both the elegance and the efficiency of this place and we are certainly extraordinarily fortunate that our Hansard maintains such a high standard of recording.

Within the Parliament there are a number of people who certainly make a greater contribution than others. On occasions the Leader of the House (Mr Young) has crossed swords with me. He has amazed me because he has been able to perform quite well for two parliaments. I rather thought that, with his Irish humour, he would have failed on more occasions than he has. He and Fred Daly have been unique in the way in which they have been able to respond in a light-hearted jocular manner but still have a barb hidden within the words they use, and be able to evoke peals of laughter so frequently. The Leader of the House has a touch of humour. I cannot say that I have always appreciated it, but I know that he will go back home and at times regret that he is not still practising that former art in the woolsheds around Australia. I think we would have had more fun with him there than here in the House. But I compliment him on the way in which he has performed his task and I wish him well.

The Parliamentary Liaison Officer, John Engledow, is another of those people whose task we all have to look at in a slightly different way. John has done his task well and efficiently and I compliment him for it.

The other parliamentary members whom we should not forget are the Whips on both sides. To the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), the National Party Whip in particular, but to all the Whips, I say thank you for the job that they each have done. Theirs is a strange role and I know that it is one which at times is difficult when their judgments do not necessarily meet with our behest, particularly when we seek leave from the House. But I compliment the five Whips from both the Government and the Opposition side for the way in which they have made sure that this place operates efficiently.

There are others who I would like to thank, all of whom have been mentioned, but I will briefly run through them. We all feel the same thanks to the parliamentary dining room staff, Carol and Jan and those who serve us at our tables, those who help in the bar and those who make the place tick, particularly the chefs. I thank the attendants who ensure that so many of our needs are attended to. I also thank the security staff and the police who I must confess, when I see them standing out there in the cold on these winter mornings, probably have the worst jobs in this place. I thank the cleaners, the Joint House Department staff and the staff of the Parliamentary Library. I think all of us, on both sides of the House, are extraordinarily fortunate to have the talent that is available in the Library. They serve us all with a remarkable amount of material. I guess it was not until I had been in opposition that I realised the extent to which those facilities are an essential back-up in the preparation of members' material, and I thank them for the way in which they have undertaken their task.

I thank the gardeners. One of the attractions of this Parliament House is the magnificant rose gardens around the building. I would like to say thanks, not only for the way they have maintained them but for the flowers that they give to so many of us. That is a very personal part of this place. It is a bit like home in some sense-although I must admit that there are elements of this place that most of us would want at home-but do make a great contribution. I also thank the the transport staff and John May and all of those who make our bookings and serve to ensure that the cars are nearly always available on time, and the drivers themselves. To all those within this place-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation team, the Parliamentary Press Gallery, the Serjeant-at-Arms, and all those others who have made this place so worth while-on behalf of the National Party I extend our particular thanks.

There are two other groups that I want to mention. The first is our loyal and dedicated personal staff. I think few of us would be able to function without the contribution that they make. They are a unique bunch of people. They work extraordinary hours and most pursue their lot in a way that is quite remarkable. Perhaps that part of their task that we, as parliamentarians, all too often forget is the number of calls they need to answer from distressed and sometimes quite emotional constituents. They on many occasions are perhaps more significant in our electorates than we are ourselves, and they are a very important part of parliamentary democracy. To them, on behalf of us all, I say: Thanks for the job you do.

The other group of people who have also been unsung but who certainly should never be forgotten are our families, our respective spouses and our children, who certainly suffer in so many ways more than most. One of the regrettable parts, to my mind, of the enormous exposure that the media gives us is that our children inevitably suffer from whatever publicity, good or bad, we might attract in our respective roles. I think many in the community, unfortunately, take advantage of that exposure. It is a fate that regrettably is a product of an open society. It is one which in some instances has led to essential protection having to be provided for them, as we learnt yesterday in regard to the motor vehicles of two members of this place. But it is sad because our children and our spouses certainly make an enormous contribution to the roles we play, and I would like to say thanks to them for the job they do.

After the end of this Parliament there will, of course, be only two more occasions when, in the Thirty-fifth Parliament, we would expect to meet in this forum. Both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition have mentioned that fact. However, as one who has been here a little longer than them, although not quite as long as the father of the House, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, Tom Uren, about whom I spoke earlier, I think it will be hard to regain quite the same debating atmosphere that we can achieve in this chamber. I say to those who are finishing off the new chamber that I hope to goodness they achieve the acoustics that I am afraid in some parts of this chamber are missing. It is extraordinarily difficult to hear in parts of this chamber, but speaking here from either side from the dispatch boxes at the table, it is an excellent debating chamber, and one that I hope can at least be repeated in the quality of that forum in the new place. It is essential that Parliament be a place where we speak to each other and a forum where we can speak not just to the community at large but, on occasions, even to persuade those on the other side of the House that perhaps there is another point of view that they need to register and at times, perhaps, even to accept. So in that change I trust that the new Parliament House will enjoy something of the quality of this place.

There are, of course, so many from the Government side who will not be returning after 11 July. I cannot say that I wish them well in the election, but whatever their future life might be, I trust that they at least are able to fulfil to the same measure the satisfaction that I think we all enjoy while we are members of the Parliament.

This is an interesting occasion-a premature election in this winter of discontent. I think we shall all find, at the end of the recognition by the community at large, that that discontent will transport the Prime Minister to this side of the House, and in that translation, I assure him, we shall enjoy that side of the House even more.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a few words to the valedictories tonight. I thank the Prime Minister for his comments, and I thank the House for having conferred on me the great honour of being the Speaker of this House. I assure honourable members that I have enjoyed it enormously.

INTERJECT.PARA: I would also like to thank the right honourable member for New England, Mr Sinclair, for his comments. I think he commented that the office of Speaker was a lonely one, and sometimes that is true. But I am always comforted by the thought that the umpire is always wrong when my team loses. I recognise that that is what happens here, so I do not take it to heart a great deal. To the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, perhaps I should say that if he thinks he has tried my patience in the last 15 months, so has the honourable member for North Sydney, so has the Prime Minister and so has the Treasurer, so you have a lot of things in common there. I am always mindful of the fact that there are 147 of you and only one of me, so I have to look after myself as there is no one else to look after me.

In regard to the wearing of a gown, we had some discussion on this when I first became Speaker. Someone suggested that it would give me dignity. When I put my clothes on in the morning I do not put my dignity on with them; I always have it with me.

I would like to join also in thanking the Clerks and the staff in the Department of the House of Representatives. I think they serve us tremendously and with great professionalism. I would like also to thank Hansard and the Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Joint House Department. I would particularly like to thank the caterers, who work in the most appalling conditions preparing the food. How they get it to us the way they do and serve it as well as they do, I do not know. I think they need a medal for that. I also thank the printers downstairs, who I think are fantastic-a special `thank you' for everything that we take to them that we wanted yesterday. I thank the Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler, Mr Leo McLeay. He has been a great stalwart in more ways than in the House. I thank the deputies for their loyalty and support, and I thank my own staff, without whom I would not manage.

Having said all that, I would now like to say something a bit more serious. It appears to me that there is a steadily declining level of public respect for Parliament and for parliamentarians. I think we should all be concerned at this trend. Anything that lowers respect for the democratic parliamentary system leaves that system more vulnerable. Members, by their behaviour this session, have not shown the level of respect for the institution of parliament and for the Standing Orders that the House should require of them. If members, by their attitude, appear to lack respect for the institution of parliament and the Standing Orders, their attitude will be reflected in the community; and members should not be surprised by that. Parliamentary democracy cannot be taken for granted. It needs to be nurtured and it requires constant attention. If honourable members want proof of that, just look at Fiji. I suggest that we all give this matter considerable attention while the House is not sitting. If the House manages its affairs with appropriate dignity, the public perception of the Parliament will be enhanced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say that it has been a great privilege, as the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has said, to have followed in the steps of Fred Daly, and I now celebrate breaking his record as Labor Leader of the House. We have had only two Labor Leaders of the House-he and I-and I have broken his record. It seems to me that one has to be of Irish descent to do the job. As we were the first ethnics, I think that is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Speaker, I heard your words of advice about the conduct of Parliament. I suppose there have been different levels of conduct in the various parliaments, such as when Sir Robert Menzies, Harold Holt, Eric Harrison and all those fellows were running the state. They might have had quieter parliaments. Our level of appreciation in the public has never varied. We have always been just between second hand car dealers and starting price bookies. Irrespective of how we conduct ourselves in here, we never seem to go up the scale of popularity. I think it is fair to say at the end of this Parliament that we should warn the public, the people of Australia, that a couple of thousand mad people will be running around Australia with grins on their faces for the next six weeks. They had better keep their hands in their pockets, otherwise we will shake the hand of everyone we see; hide their kids, because we will kiss all of them; and bring out their raffle tickets because we will buy all of them. If they happen to have a camera, they will get the biggest smile of all. So the next six weeks will be a rather exciting period.

I would like to join with the earlier speakers in offering my thanks to everybody who has participated in the conduct of this Parliament. To the Opposition business leaders, Ian Sinclair, John Spender and to the Whips on the other side I say: `Thank you very much'. It is very true that a lot of the business of the Parliament is conducted by arrangements between the parties in a very sensible way. Sometimes it will get out of hand but, basically, the business is conducted with the acceptance of a fair go for both sides and that is the only way Parliament can really operate. I would like to thank them for it. I would also like to thank the people on our side-Benny and Barry, the Whip and the Deputy Whip and their staff-for carrying a very large part of the work load in keeping our troops in here. It is no good having the number we have elected unless they are here to put their hands up. The Whip has done a pretty good job for two and a half years. I do not think we have lost a vote. It went close a couple of times and changed a few airline bookings.

Madam Speaker, you have had a most difficult task within the Parliament. The closer we get to an election the more difficult it becomes. Things are said in the Parliament and opportunities are taken to try to score political points and in the middle of sorting all this out is the Speaker. I think you have done the job very well. You have brought a certain respect to the Parliament and your word is listened to outside the Parliament. Many people comment on things you have to say as the Speaker of the House. I think overwhelmingly the people of Australia are very proud that a woman has, at last, been recognised for this top job in the national Parliament. I thank the Clerks for their advice. Again, the Parliament would not operate unless we could rely on the sound advice of the Clerks. They are there, sometimes at very short notice, to give us that sort of advice. Thank God John Spender was not a Clerk.

I thank the Hansard reporters who make us look like such great statesmen. After we have looked at the `greens' we think: `By God, that was a better speech than I thought it was'. When the Hansard staff have rearranged it all and it looks pretty good and we send it out to our constituents they say: `He talks a lot different over there than he does back here in Port Adelaide'. I have been here for the same time as John Howard and a few others. We came in the 1974 election, so Hansard has had to do a fair bit of work on our speeches. After 1975 we did not have many on the Opposition side of the House. Paul Keating, I, Bill Hayden and Lionel Bowen, a few of us, used to make speeches every day. We just pulled one out of the drawer. But with 80 members it does not matter. That is the difference. I can understand why members opposite are going to work so hard to be in government. To those of us who served our first years in opposition, to relish the challenge of being in government and the excitement of the decision- making of government makes politics worth while.

I thank all the other people concerned in the House-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the catering staff. The chef must have a great liking for potato and leek soup. I was thinking that when we come to the end of this Parliament we will have had another thousand bowls each of potato and leek soup. The wife of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) wrote a book on cooking in Canberra, did she not? Perhaps she could send it to the chef. Apart from everything else, he looks pretty fit.

With those few words of thanks to everybody concerned in the Parliament I say, lastly, to John Engledow, the Parliamentary Liaison Officer because I forgot him last time-he is not here; that is not him in the leather coat-that he has done a terrific job. I do not know why the senior people in the Public Service such as John Engledow take those sorts of jobs. They say they like to have it on their curriculum vitae and they like to see the operations of Parliament. I think they have to be some sort of maniac to take these sorts of jobs and live amongst us when they really do not have to. He has been an excellent Parliamentary Liaison Officer for this Parliament for both sides of the House. We appreciate the work that he and his staff have done. The people sitting at the end of the National Party seats will have to shift a little after the next election. We will need a bit more room.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going a bit to the left.
—You are?
—Around that way.

—Don't you worry about that! If you show one sign of going to the left, old Joh will be on you. I think it is a great shame that Joh is not coming. We could have enjoyed the comfort of some new rhetoric. That would have given Hansard something to do. I do not want those opposite to take seriously anything I say during the campaign. If I say there are an incompetent rabble, I will really mean if; if they see it in the papers, it is just part of the speeches we have to make; and if they see that I say the Liberals and National parties threaten the submarine contract in South Australia, it will just be part of the rhetoric for the Parliament. We wish them all the best, with limited success. We hope to see their smiling faces back, especially Roger. A great victory, Roger-the old John Elliott sitting out there in the board room! You have kept him there. He offered you heaps too. I am not sure that I would not have taken it. With those few words, we would like to express our appreciation to everybody who has helped in the running of the Thirty-fourth Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker-

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Point of order!

TALK.START.PARA: —On this occasion I do not rise to make a point of order; I rise to agree with what has been said and to say to you, Madam Speaker, that you have a most difficult job. This is rather like a bear pit, particularly during Question Time. I think there may have been the infrequent occasions when my points of order have stretched your patience a little far. Perhaps we can discuss points of order and parliamentary procedures on another occasion, in different circumstances when we come back here.

SPEECH.PARA: To all those who are leaving the House now from the Government side I simply say that I wish them all the success that their record deserves and, in that event, we will be on that side of the House and they will be on this side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —While endorsing all the remarks about the various people who have helped us in this Parliament, I want to say a few words, on behalf of all South Australian members, about Ralph Jacobi, on his retirement. I am reminded by his very good friend, the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), to include him in those remarks as well. Ralph is my next door neighbour both electorally-our electorates are joined-and here in the Parliament.
—No, he lives in South Australia.
—This is the time for sweet and light.

—He has been an extremely good friend not just to me but particularly to me in the time I have been here. When I first went into Ralph's office I noticed there were two mottos framed on his wall. One was a telegram from Chris Schacht on the occasion of the 1980 election. Chris, who was then the Secretary of the South Australian Labor Party, shortly to be a senator in this place, sent him a telegram saying: `You are the candidate who took least notice of any advice that I gave on how to conduct your election campaign but, nevertheless, best of luck'. The second thing that was on Ralph's wall was a little framed motto which read: `Comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable'. Those two things seemed to me to be motives of Ralph's life in politics. So far as the first motive is concerned, his independence within the Party, he was an extremely loyal and long serving member of the Labor Party but he was not one to be dragooned or to support questions without thinking. He had a very independent cast of mind. I am reminded of the line from Gilbert and Sullivan about the politician who became secretary of the Queen's Navee and who always voted at his party's call and never thought of voting for himself at all. Ralph was not that kind of politician. He was a man who worked things out for himself, who thought things out for himself and often very deeply and in a way that informed the minds of many others within his Party. He was not a member of any of what are called factions in our parliamentary Party. Indeed, he loathed and detested factionalism with a passion, and I am sure he still does-I hope he is listening to this. That was the first thing, Ralph's independence.

SPEECH.PARA: The second motif of his life to which I referred was `Comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable'. He was always a great electorate parliamentarian. He worked extremely hard on behalf of his constituents and put his talents and energies, which were considerable, at the disposal of ordinary people, pensioners, returned servicemen and women, in particular, but indeed anybody who came to see him. That loyalty to his constituents, his hard work on their behalf, was rewarded by their loyalty to him and particularly in a couple of tough elections, 1975 and 1977, when he was opposed by Steele Hall, whom I saw here earlier on. He survived those elections, which were very hard work for Labor members.

In parliament, he had the highest standards of integrity, standards to which any parliamentarian would be proud to aspire. He pursued issues with doggedness, with energy, with conscientiousness, particularly companies legislation, insurance fraud and taxation reform. These were things that I am sure he was led to not by some sort of academic feeling about them but because harm had been done to his constituents by the depredations of companies, insurance companies that went broke and so forth, and he pursued them relentlessly in the interests of ordinary people who had been hurt by their operations. It was very much a case of `Comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable'.

Ralph had no enemies on a personal level in this place. He was what my Scottish ancestors would call a bonny fighter; he fought hard and he fought fair. He had many interests besides those I have named. One, in particular, is his great interest, his passionate interest, in foreign affairs. He is a scholar of an amateur kind in the Middle East, in Arabia, a great reader and somebody who made that part of a very full and varied parliamentary life. Personally, I will miss Ralph Jacobi more than most, not just because he sat next to me and not just because our electorates are next to each other. I will miss his wise advice and the friendship of a great parliamentarian. Ralph, as we all know, has not enjoyed good health in recent years but I am sure everybody in this place would join with me in wishing him a long and happy retirement. We are consoled in our Party only, I think, by the knowledge that he will be succeeded in his electorate of Hawker by a woman, Madam Speaker, as charming and personable as you-Elizabeth Harvey, the Australian Labor Party candidate for that seat. I conclude by saying, perhaps as Ralph would himself say, and I am addressing this directly to him, Madam Speaker: `Keep your head down, old son'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Senate's amendments-
No. 1-Page 34, clause 21, proposed section 64, lines 1 to 23, leave out the proposed section.
No. 2-Page 37, clause 21, proposed section 74, lines 33 and 34, leave out ``64 or''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

Without delaying the chamber, I point out that I have no alternative but to accept the amendments. We debated them fully during the second reading and Committee stages. The Senate disagrees with my view, which I think will mean that there will be some further discussion in the next parliament following High Court discussion and litigation. Section 64 as we had proposed it would have avoided some of the difficulties that might flow, particularly in respect of defective warrants. The Bill remains effective in the sense that we really intended-that is, illegal interceptions will no longer be able to be admitted into evidence and there will be proper procedures for State police and other authorities to intercept telecommunications in a manner that requires judicial warrants, assistance and supervision. To that extent, there will be some safety with the gathering of evidence in a proper manner, with protection of the privacy of people, who have an entitlement to privacy when using the telephone system. I accept the amendments that come to us from the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take up the time of the chamber either. Obviously we have very little time. We did propose that proposed section 64 be omitted and I believe it is an advantage that it has been omitted. That is a view that is shared by a number of organisations outside this House, such as the Law Council of Australia and the New South Wales Bar Association. If there are any problems, I think they must be dealt with as and when they arise, and I look forward to the co-operation of the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the future if I, as Attorney-General, need to propose any changes to the legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Are the ``see and be seen'' visual flight rules procedures being reviewed; if so, when will this review be completed and is it now over 2 years since this was first considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: ``See and avoid'' procedures for aircraft separation are already in use in some circumstances. There have been requests for these procedures to be introduced in primary control zones. However the relative responsibilities of pilots and air traffic control staff for avoiding collisions between aircraft needed to be clarified following court judgments arising out of a mid-air collision between two general aviation aircraft. The High Court recently considered the matter, and its ruling provides a basis for further discussion between interested parties with a view to extending ``see and avoid'' procedures to primary control zone.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 13 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the ``see and be seen'' separation standard be re-introduced.
(2) Which countries use this procedure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) See answer to question 341.

(2) ``See and avoid'' procedures for aircraft separation are used in some countries, but so far as is known there is no commonly accepted standard governing such procedures. Collection of detailed information about particular circumstances in which individual countries employ the procedures would require considerable effort which is not considered warranted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether (a) natural gas is made available in Middle East countries, Indonesia, the U.K. and European countries as a fuel and raw material for steel, ceramic, chemical and fertilizer products which are imported into Australia and which flood many Australian markets and (b) natural gas for such purposes is sold at about one third of the price that domestic gas is sold for in those countries.

(2) Is the Minister also able to say what is the price of natural gas supplied to manufacturing industry in Saudi Arabia, Qatar-Kuwait, Abu Dhabi, Indonesia, the U.K. and the Netherlands in circumstances where it is available as a by-product from oil production.
(3) What is the price of natural gas supplied to State Government purchasing and distribution authorities from each of the producing oil and gas fields in Australia.

(4) Is it a fact that natural gas is (a) available in Australia as cheap and attractive fuel, (b) less expensive than coal at the source and (c) less expensive than indigenous or imported oil or transported liquified natural gas.

(5) If so, what would be the (a) cost of production and (b) price of additional quantities of natural gas at the producing sources necessary to stimulate new economic activities in Australia and provide benefits and employment in export industries that cannot be realised without cheap gas as a fuel or raw material comparably priced to gas in the Middle East, Indonesia, the U.K. and the Netherlands.

(6) What are the presently uncommitted quantities of Bass Strait gas which could be available for industrial use and electricity generation in N.S.W. and S.A. where supplies from the Cooper Basin are limited and excessively priced when compared to Bass Strait prices applying to Victorian Government distribution authorities.

(7) In view of the fact that (a) the delivered price of energy affects the performance of Australian manufacturing industry and the Australian mineral processing industry in competitive world markets and (b) electricity utilities such as those in South Australia (Torrens Island) and Victoria (Newport) rely on natural gas to generate electricity, will the Minister consider the desirability of the Commonwealth building interstate pipeline connections between Victoria, N.S.W. and S.A. to increase the sales volume of gas from Bass Strait, consequent upon a downward movement in gas prices, to reactivate the economy through lower electricity and gas supply tariffs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) No.

(3) and (4) What information the Government has on this matter is provided on the understanding it will be treated as Commercial-in-Confidence and it would therefore be inappropriate for me to discuss it.

(5) (a) and (b) While the cost of production of natural gas from established fields is quite low, it is not practical to provide a representative estimate of the cost of bringing additional discoveries on stream. Similarly, the costs of the natural gas when delivered to the consumer will depend upon a number of factors, such as the cost of bringing the discovery on stream, the location of the discovery and its proximity to the existing natural gas pipeline distribution system. It is not possible therefore to generalise about the prospects for new economic activities based on natural gas. It is known however that State Governments and their authorities do pursue such opportunities actively whenever they arise.

(6) and (7) The essential facts bearing on these matters were reviewed in a recent study commissioned by the Australian Minerals and Energy Council entitled ``Report of the Working Party on Natural Gas''. That report recognised that one of the options that will need to be considered is the interconnection of gas supply pipelines between the States.

The need for, and timing of, any interconnections will depend upon a number of factors including developments in electricity planning related to the role of gas fired power generation and the greater integration of electricity supplies to the south east. It is not apparent that there is a need for such interconnections in the near future, nor is it clear that such interconnections could provide gas at such a cost as to achieve the result suggested in the question.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Word Processing or Computer Equipment and Repetitive Strain Injury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 17 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What wordprocessing or computer equipment has been introduced into the Minister's Department and statutory authorities responsible to the Minister since 1982.
(2) Why was the equipment purchased and were any specific targets set in terms of time or cost savings and improved efficiencies.
(3) What has been the cost of purchasing the equipment.
(4) Has the introduction of the equipment necessitated the purchase of new office equipment; if so, what have been the costs of the additional purchases.
(5) Has the introduction of the equipment led to changes in work practices; if so, what has been the nature of the changes.
(6) What has been the incidence of repetitive strain injury (RSI) in the Minister's Department since 1982.
(7) How many lost working days have been caused by RSI related illnesses since 1982.

(8) How many persons have been forced to retire from the Minnister's Department or statutory authorities responsible to the Minister as a result of RSI and what have been the compensation costs of this early retirement.
(9) Has introduction of the equipment (a) saved money and (b) improved efficiency in the Minister's Department or the statutory authorities responsible to the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Department of Primary Industry has, since 1982, purchased several Wang computers and a Control Data computer.
(b) The Bureau of Agricultural Economics (BAE) has purchased a Natsemi (IBM compatible) computer and a Wang computer.
(c) The various statutory authorities have acquired a range of equipment suitable to the tasks they perform. Major acquisitions included IBM, Prime, Wang and Hewlett Packard equipment.

(2) (a) The Department purchased its Wang equipment to provide comprehensive word processing facilities as well as a basic data processing network to support administrative and operational functions in central and regional offices. The Control Data equipment was acquired to provide a scientific/analytical facility for the processing of fisheries logbooks and similar data. The Department anticipated that the computer systems would provide efficiencies in the preparation and processing of information as well as improving its timeliness and quality. The Control Data acquisition also anticipated savings in the nature of recurrent costs incurred through using CSIRONET services.

(b) The BAE Natsemi acquisition was installed as part of an overall plan to offset increasing usage of CSIRONET charges as well as an opportunity for increasing the productivity of Bureau staff. The Wang equipment was acquired for word processing and integrated office functions to improve overall productivity in carrying out administrative tasks.

(c) The statutory authorities acquired their equipment to support a broad range of administrative functions relating to their roles and objectives. Most rationales included both word and data processing. The latter concentrated on financial, accounting and administrative applications. Two of the larger authorities-The Australian Wool Corporation and The Australian Wheat Board-also use their equipment for marketing applications and to connect their regional offices via a computer/communications network. In most cases these acquisitions were sought to improve administrative efficiency and/or operational effectiveness.

(5) Introduction of equipment in the Department, the BAE and the statutory authorities has resulted in changes to work practices associated with the use of computer workstations for word processing, data entry and information retrieval. This has in turn led to improved timeliness and quality of information analysis and preparation. The emphasis on keyboard work has also necessitated the adoption of preventive measures against occupational overuse syndrome, including regular rest breaks, changes in work flow and the application of ergonomics to the work environment.
(6) Since a statistical record has been kept (ie since 1984), there have been 212 reported incidences of RSI in the Department, including BAE.
The Department is unable to extract information for incidences prior to that date.
Only one statutory authority has had an incidence of RSI involving one person.
(7) Since a statistical record has been kept (ie since 1984) days lost in the Department, including BAE, due to RSI related illnesses total:
4,297 short days (ie worked reduced hours due to RSI).

The one incidence in a statutory authority incurred 23.75 lost working days as at 10.3.87.
(8) There have been 11 retirements in the Department due to RSI, and none in the statutory authorities.
Total compensation costs in respect of these retirees is $175,570.00.

(9) The Department, the BAE and the statutory authorities report that the introduction of such equipment has generally improved efficiency and saved money. Most pointed to increases in output, quality and timeliness in tasks such as the retrieval and analysis of information and preparation and production of reports and correspondence. In both the Department and the BAE, savings have been made on projected charges for the use of CSIRONET services. The Department feels that the productivity gains generated by these systems have helped to contain increases in administrative staff that would have been required by increased workloads during this period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1987:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department has chosen appropriate equipment types to meet the varying specific requirements of its Central Office, State Branch Offices and institutions:
(a) for single user wordprocessing both Systype Model 2 and Canon VP2000 equipment were originally purchased. These are now being superseded by IBM Personal Computers.

(b) for dedicated wordprocessing pools Wordplex and Wang equipment have been used. In some locations the older Wordplex equipment on reaching the end of its economic life is being phased out in favour of IBM Personal Computers.

(c) for centralised computing the Department has operated an IBM compatible network for 17 years. The central computer has been changed a number of times in that period. The model currently in use is an AMDAHL 5880. Terminals connected to the network since 1982 have nearly all been Telex Computer Products models.
(d) for localised computing the Department has purchased:
PRIME Series 250 mini computers;
IBM System 36 mini computers;
Webster Spectrum mini computer;
DEC Mocrocovax mini computer;
IBM, Apple and Zenith personal computers

(2) The word processing equipment was purchased to improve the efficiency of typists in creating, modifying and printing the documentation of the Department. In all cases where the equipment has been introduced the throughput of the typist has increased. The computing equipment was purchased, in general, to improve the efficiency of the Department in carrying out its various functions. Systems were implemented on the equipment that permitted the Department to handle an increasing workload with minimum staff increases. Specific targets were not set.
(3) Expenditure on Computer equipment has been as follows:
86/87 $3,530,000 (Expenditure to 31 March)

Word processing equipment falls into the category of Office Machines for purchasing purposes. The details on cost of the equipment and associated purchases would require a substantial commitment of resources to collect and collate. I am not prepared to commit those resources for the purpose.

(4) The introduction of the equipment has necessitated the purchase of ergonomic furniture to conform with the Department's guidelines for use of such equipment. It would not be possible to isolate expenditure on this type of furniture from expenditure on furniture in general.

(5) The introduction of word processing equipment has had limited effect on work practices; instead of using an electric typewriter the typist is now typing on a wordprocessor. In general the only additional task is to perform normal housekeeping functions for the wordprocessor.
The introduction of computer equipment has permitted the automation of a number of previously manual tasks.

(6) Statistical data on Repetition Strain Injury (RSI) within the Department of Veterans' Affairs are unavailable prior to 1984. Since 1984 RSI statistical data have been maintained on a quarterly basis and a total of 446 cases have been reported, of which 151 are still current.
(7) The total number of lost working days reported up until 31 December 1986 was 37,224 full days and 4,848 part days.

(8) The number of retirements as a result of RSI is available from April 1985 only. Since that time ten officers have retired as a result of contracting RSI. The compensation cost of ten early retirements has been:
Salary cost prior to retirement...$162,325
Salary cost after retirement...$82,234
Other costs (e.g. medical) prior to retirement
Other costs after retirement...$6,934
(9) The introduction of the equipment has improved efficiency by allowing more work to be performed in an efficient and timely manner. It is not possible to quantify cost savings.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 18 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a document entitled ``Marketing and Communication-Guidelines for Acceptance and Usage of Food Irradiation''.
(2) Was this document the product of a task force set up at the second meeting of the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation (ICGFI) held in Vienna in October 1985.

(4) Is the Minister also able to state the composition of the ICGFI and the task force; if so, what are the details.

(5) Are any Australians members of either the ICGFI or the task force; if so, (a) who are they, (b) who authorised their involvement, (c) what are their qualifications and (d) for which Department or authorities do they work.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 18 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Minister's answer to question No. 3821 (Hansard, 16 September 1986, page 685), does the Minister have responsibility under section 31 of the Atomic Energy Act for operations of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC),

(2) Did the AAEC in its annual report for 1984-85, say on page 4 that it played a leading role in the second phase of the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on food irradiation which is being sponsored by the Australian Government; if so, is the statement correct.
(3) Who authorised the sponsorship on behalf of the Government.
(4) Which Minister is or was responsible for the involvement of the AAEC in the second phase of the Asian Regional Co-operative Project.
(5) What information or reports did that Minister receive either from time to time or annually, and what other Ministers or Departments received copies.
(6) Which Minister is responsible for the International Atomic Energy Agency Regional Co-operative Agreement (RCA).
(7) Which provision of the RCA allows or commits the Government to participate in or sponsor the second phase of the Regional Project on Food Irradiation (Phase II RPFI).
(8) Was the Department of Health consulted prior to Australian sponsorship of Phase II RPFI; if so, when was the Department consulted.
(9) If the Department of Health was not consulted, why not.
(10) Did the Australian sponsorship consist of $US260 000 over a 3 year period.
(11) How many employees of AAEC or other Departments, are still working on Phase II RPFI.
(12) Where are AAEC or other departmental employees working on Phase II RPFI located and how many are based in Vienna.
(13) What is the cost of salaries, travelling allowances, and other support for Australian involvement in the project.
(14) To whom do these employees report and how regularly are they required to do so.
(15) Was the payment of $US260 000 for Phase II RPFI Federal Executive Council decision.
(16) Is the Minister able to say whether the payment was made by the Department of Foreign Affairs from development assistance funds.

(17) Is the Minister also able to say whether the Department of Foreign Affairs subsequently assessed Phase II RPFI as more of a commercial operation and unsuited for assistance from its development assistance vote.
(18) Does the Minister agree with this assessment; if not, why not.
(19) If Phase II RPFI was not a commercial operation, why did Australia agree to fund the transfer of food irradiation technology to local industries at the meeting in May 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister for Resources and Energy has the responsibility for the operations of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and its predecessor the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC).
(2) Yes; the statement is correct.

(3) The authority for AAEC and now ANSTO involvement in the second phase of the Asian Regional Cooperative Project on Food Irradiation (RPFI) derives from a decision of the Executive Council agreeing to Australia becoming a party to the Agreement establishing RPFI (see also answer to Question No. 4395 in HOR Hansard of 17 February 1987).
(4) The Minister for Resources and Energy.

(5) The AAEC's Annual Reports to the Minister for Resources and Energy contain information on RPFI. The AAEC has also forwarded to the Department of Foreign Affairs copies of the reports of the two Project Committee Meetings held to date under RPFI Phase II (see answer to Question No. 4395 in HOR Hansard of 17 February 1987).

(6) Relations with the International Atomic Energy Agency come within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Where matters overlap other portfolios, relevant Ministers are consulted.

(7) Under Article 1 of the IAEA's Regional Cooperative Agreement (RCA), Governments party to the RCA `agree, in cooperation with each other and the Agency, to promote and coordinate cooperative research, development and training projects in nuclear science and technology through their appropriate national institutions'.
(8) Yes, during interdepartmental consideration of Australia's involvement in RPFI, prior to Australia becoming a party to the Agreement.

(10) Yes. Australia agreed to sponsor Phase II RPFI to the extent of $US260 000 over a three year period 1985-87. Cash payments and in kind contributions as at 28 May 1987 totalled $US206 453.29. The late commencement of some of the research contracts under the project will lead to research carrying over into 1988, meaning there will be a further Australian contribution in 1987-88. However it is expected that less than $US260 000 will be required in total owing to savings which have been achieved, principally on air travel.

(11) Much of the ongoing research and development work of the Irradiation Research and Technology Section of the ANSTO Isotope Division is of relevance to the aims of RPFI Phase II. This section has a current staff complement of two professional and two technical officers. The Section does however, carry out specific research work under the terms of the Coordinated Research Program (CRP) for RPFI Phase II. Research under the CRP has involved one professional officer at approximately 0.1 of a staff year and one technical officer at approximately 0.2 of a staff year for the period May 1986 to April 1987.

(12) ANSTO technical specialists working on Phase II of RPFI are located at the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories. The Counsellor (Atomic Energy) Vienna provides direct contact with the IAEA as required as part of his duties.

(13) As indicated in answer to (11), it is impractical to artificially divide the salaries and support effort between the ongoing research and development work of the Irradiation Research and Technology Section of the ANSTO Isotope Division and ANSTO work specifically in support of RPFI Phase II. No travelling expenses in relation to RPFI were incurred by ANSTO during the period May 1986 to April 1987.

(14) The ANSTO staff involved are responsible to the Chief, Isotope Division in ANSTO. Under the terms of the Coordinated Research Program referred to in (11), ANSTO staff report annually to the IAEA.
(15) No. It was the decision of the then Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs based on the Executive Council decision.

(17) The Department of Foreign Affairs has advised that it is satisfied that payment of Australia's contribution to RPFI Phase II from development assistance funds is an appropriate use of those funds.
(18) Yes. The Minister agrees with the Department of Foreign Affairs' decision as indicated in para 17 above.

(19) The first Phase II RPFI Project Committee Meeting held on 13-15 May 1985 drew up the work program for Phase II. The meeting agreed that the work to be carried out would emphasise technology transfer of food irradiation to relevant industries. Australia's willingness to fund Phase II was based on an assessment of the interest shown by countries in the region and the potential utility of food irradiation to their economies. Australian involvement was not based on any commercial interest.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say what is the assessed opium and heroin production for the Laotian section of the Golden Triangle for each year since 1980.

(2) Is he able to say whether the Lao Government has altered its policies and activities in the Golden Triangle section of Laos to facilitate a renewal of opium and heroin production to help support the Lao communist economy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. There is no reliable official estimate of opium and heroin production in Laos for the period since 1980. The relevant United Nations bodies, the Division of Narcotic Drugs in the UN Secretariat and the International Narcotics Control Board (the INCB) have no official estimates for narcotics production for Laos in this period. The INCB report for 1986 comments that:

``In the past, illicit opium production has taken place in the Lao People's Democratic Republic. There is no information as to the present situation. The authorities have supplied to the Board some of the information required under the 1961 and 1971 Conventions. The Board hopes to develop its dialogue with the Government and for that purpose to send a mission to the country at the earliest possible opportunity.''

In accordance with Article 19 of the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, to which Laos is a party, Laos has provided the INCB with estimates of narcotic drugs in 1986. Laos has not, however, supplied information concerning the production and cultivation of illicit narcotic drugs within its territory.

There are unconfirmed reports from other sources which variously estimate the annual production of opium in Laos in 1985 and 1986 at between 50 to 100 metric tonnes. Annual output in years before 1985 has been estimated at approximately 30-50 tonnes, although once again no reliable figures are available. The US State Department in testimony to Congress stated recently that production of opium in 1986 was between 100 and 290 tonnes.
2. I am aware of reports that the Lao Government may be facilitating or tolerating production and export of narcotic drugs. My Department is seeking to clarify these allegations.

In view of the importance the Government attaches to curbing abuse and illicit traffic in narcotic drugs, the Australian Ambassador in Vientiane has expressed concern, at a senior level, to the Lao Government about reports of increased production of narcotic drugs, suggestions that the Lao Government is involved in the production and export of illicit opiates and marijuana and the alleged use of Lao territory by Burmese and Thai traffickers. The Lao Government has denied involvement in narcotics production or trafficking but acknowledges that the growing of opium poppy and marijuana is traditional among certain Lao groups.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 23 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funding has been made available to Queensland in each year since 1977 through the Rural Adjustment Scheme and the Rural Reconstruction Scheme.

(2) Is he able to say what proportion of these funds has (a) been made available by the Queensland Government to primary producers, (b) been transferred to Consolidated Revenue or (c) not been lent to primary producers as agreed.
(3) Is it a fact that the Government makes these funds available to the Queensland Government at an 8 per cent interest rate.
(4) Is it a fact that the Queensland Government is only required to repay 85 per cent of loans, with the remaining 15 per cent being for alleged bad debts.
(5) Is it a fact that the Queensland Government is not required to pay interest during the first 3 years of the loan period.

(6) Has his attention been drawn to claims that the Queensland Government is receiving Federal funds, not at 8 per cent, but because of the special conditions, at closer to 4 1/2 per cent, and is lending that money to primary producers at approximately 15 per cent.

(7) What powers does the Government have to (a) provide loans direct to primary producers and (b) require the Queensland Government to use the money for the purposes stated in the original Rural Reconstruction and Rural Adjustment Scheme agreements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1977 there have been changes to the schemes which have provided funds for rural adjustment. The following reply to the honourable member's question is provided in two parts. The first covers the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) which was in place from 1 January 1977 to 30 June 1985. That Scheme replaced the Rural Reconstruction Scheme and was based on the Commonwealth providing funds to the States for on-lending to primary producers. From 1 July 1985 a new RAS was introduced under which the Commonwealth provided a 50 per cent subsidy on interest rates for loans taken out by either State rural adjustment authorities or farmers.
(1) Under the 1977-1985 RAS funds could be used for the following purposes:
Part A: debt reconstruction, farm build-up, farm improvement, rehabilitation.
Part B: carry on finance (jointly funded with the States), and
Part C: household support.
Between 1 January 1977 and 30 June 1985 the Commonwealth provided the following funds to Queensland.
Year
Payment
$m
1977 (January to June)...
Total...
From 1 January 1977 to 30 June 1985 Queensland provided $19.8m to the RAS for Part B assistance to the sugar and beef industries.

According to its 1984-85 Annual Report the Queensland Rural Reconstruction Board which administered the RAS, had made payments to primary producers of $77.6m under the Scheme to 30 June 1985. Two million dollars had been credited to State Consolidated Revenue.

The Queensland Rural Reconstruction Board operated a Rural Reconstruction fund for the purposes of the Rural Reconstruction Scheme and a Rural Adjustment Fund for the purpose of the Rural Adjustment Scheme and similar schemes. The balance in the Rural Adjustment Fund stood at $19.6m and the balance in the Rural Reconstruction Fund stood at $19.2m on 30 June 1985.

Part A funding was provided by Commonwealth loans (85 per cent) and grants (15 per cent). Before 1982 the loans were made at 7 per cent interest for 20 years. From 1982 interest on Commonwealth loans and outstanding balances was raised to 8 per cent. The States were not required to make any repayments for the first four years of a loan. The grant component was provided to cover losses on loans to farmers, asset write-offs and the conversion of loans to grants.

Part B carry-on finance was jointly funded by the Commonwealth and the State on a dollar for dollar basis. The Commonwealth generally made funds available at 4 per cent, repayable over 7 years with a 12 month repayment holiday. Funds lent to Queensland at 4 per cent were provided to Queensland beef producers at 4 per cent.

The agreement allowed the States to determine the interest rate which they charged farmers and obliged them to return recipients to commercial interest rates as soon as possible. Thus older borrowers who were judged commercially viable would have been paying commercial interest rates. Funding for household support (Part C) was provided to the States as a loan but only those loans repaid by household support recipients were repayable to the Commonwealth. Household support payments could have been converted from loans to grants as the State decided.

(2) The funding arrangements changed from 1 July 1985 and since then the Commonwealth has provided grants under Part A to subsidise loans taken out by the State or farmers for debt reconstruction, farm build-up and farm improvement. The subsidy is equivalent to 50 per cent of the interest rate of a nominated commercial lender on the amount of borrowing the Commonwealth decides is appropriate after consultation with the States. The nominated lender for 1986-87 is the Primary Industry Bank of Australia and the nominated interest rate is 17.5 per cent.

Part B funding for carry-on finance is jointly subsidised by the Commonwealth and States with the Commonwealth providing a 25 per cent interest subsidy. Household support and rehabilitation are funded on the same basis as in the previous scheme.

The Commonwealth provided $1.03m RAS funding to Queensland in 1985-86 ($0.54m for Part A, $0.44m for Part C and $0.05m for administration costs) and Queensland approved $8.4m of assistance. In 1986-87 the Commonwealth will provide an estimated $5.06m of RAS funding to Queensland comprising $4.02m for Part A, $0.75m for Part C and $0.29m for administration costs.

Because of these new arrangements the Queensland Government is currently receiving Part A RAS funding as grants rather than loans. It is, in general, applying these funds so as to reduce an applicant's interest rate by around six per cent.
The Commonwealth has the power to provide loans directly to primary producers but it is more efficient and less costly to use established State organisations to administer the RAS.

The Rural Reconstruction Scheme and 1977-85 RAS agreements allow the States to retain any surpluses generated by the operation of the schemes and do not require these funds to be used for rural adjustment purposes. Queensland has operated the schemes in accordance with the agreements.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Convention for the Protection of Performers, Producers of Phonograms and Broadcasting Organisations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to part (4) of my question no. 1936 (Hansard, 21 November 1985, page 2595), has the Copyright Law Review Committee completed its report; if not, when does it hope to complete it.
(2) Which countries have become parties to the Convention since he gave his answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Copyright Law Review Committee completed its report on performers' protection in early May. Adoption of the Committee's recommendations for new legislative protection for performers would enable Australia to comply with the performers' protection provisions of the Rome Convention. I have asked my Department to consult with relevant interests concerning the necessary minor amendments to the broadcasting provisions of the Copyright Act 1968 which would enable Australia to accede to the Convention. Copies of the Committee's report will shortly be available to the public.
(2) Since giving my answer the Dominican Republic and Monaco have become parties to the Convention.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Availability of Australian Products at Australian Overseas Posts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No 4763 (Hansard, 17 February 1987, page 31) is it a fact that the Australian Embassy in Washington obtains Australian wine and beer, meat pies and sausages for its staff, but uses NZ butter and cheese; if so, why is not Australian butter and cheese provided.
(2) Which other Australian Embassies make available Australian products and what products are made available.
(3) Do any Australian Embassies offer Australian dairy products.
(4) Which Australian Embassies do not offer Australian dairy products and why not.
(5) Does this situation help our export and Australian-made campaigns.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Embassy Washington is not officially responsible for import and distribution of any food products for staff. Such purchases are made by a Staff Social Club based on normal commercial criteria for sale to members.

New Zealand dairy products are purchased through a private US commercial organisation which specialises in supply to diplomatic missions. It is understood there is not a comparable supply source for Australian dairy products, nor does the Australian Dairy Corporation provide such a service.
Australian beer, meat pies and sausages are however available through commercial organisations and are purchased by staff members.
(2), (3) and (4) Australian missions do not import or purchase foodstuffs on behalf of staff. Such purchases are properly considered the responsibility of individuals.
(5) Notwithstanding this, Australian Embassy officials overseas use Australian products, subject to normal commercial criteria, when they are available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 17 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a joint publication, issued in 1981, by the FAO, WHO, and the International Atomic Energy Agency entitled Wholesomeness of Irradiated Food.
(2) Was Australia represented on the expert committee which drew up this document; if so, by whom.
(3) Has the document been accepted by IAEA; if so, when, and was Australia represented at the IAEA meeting when it was accepted.
(4) If it has been accepted by IAEA, was the Minister's Department asked to comment on it before it was accepted; if so, when.
(5) Is the Minister able to say whether any further documents have been issued by the joint expert committee; if so, (a) when, (b) what are they and (c) what action has been taken on them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Expert Committee, which convened in 1980, comprised experts who were selected by FAO/IAEA/WHO because of their specialised knowledge and experience in the field of food irradiation. They served in a personal capacity, rather than as representatives of governments or other bodies. The publication lists Professor M.J. Rand, University of Melbourne, as the Committee Chairman.

(3) The disclaimer on page 1 of the document advises that the report ``contains the collective views of an international group of experts and does not necessarily represent the decision or the stated policy of the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations, the International Atomic Energy Agency, or the World Health Organisation''. It is the practice of the IAEA to note the views of such expert committees, but not to formally adopt them. For instance, the Expert Committee's findings as in the above document were noted in the IAEA's 1980 Annual Report.
(4) Not applicable.

(5) I am not aware of any subsequent documents being issued by the Expert Committee. Previous joint expert committee meetings of the IAO/IAEA/WHO to consider aspects of food irradiation were held in 1964, 1969 and 1976. The documents produced by these meetings have been published as WHO Technical Report Series Nos 316, 451 and 604. These three documents have similarly not been formally adopted by the FAO, IAEA or WHO.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: What substantive achievements of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation justify Australia's continued financial contribution to that organisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: UNESCO activities are based on programs encompassing education, natural sciences, social sciences, cultural identity and exchanges between cultures, and free and balanced circulation of information. In these fields, UNESCO encourages international intellectual co-operation, provides a world forum for the discussion of global problems, provides operational assistance to member states and provides funds for development projects, research and training programs. UNESCO also acts as the executing agency for many development projects funded by agencies such as the United Nations Development Program (UNDP), the World Bank and numerous foundations. Practical examples of UNESCO programs include the development and application of new methods of literacy teaching, the identification and protection of World Heritage sites, the timely preservation of ancient monuments and improved management of world water resources.

Australia gains from its membership of UNESCO by the participation of Australians in international and regional conferences and meetings and through involvement in international and regional program activities involving consultancy and technical field engagements. Membership of UNESCO is also valuable in pursuing Australia's regional interests and in complementing bilateral development assistance objectives and activities. Participation at UNESCO expense by more than 100 Australians each year in UNESCO activities overseas promotes Australia as a source of expert knowledge. Delegations and individual specialists have contributed to a distinctive Australian image in the international community. In dollar terms, Australia also benefits from UNESCO sponsored activities held in Australia or involving Australians. In the 12 month period commencing December 1986 UNESCO will provide over $600,000 for such activities.
Selected areas of UNESCO programs from which Australia benefits include:
INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS

Thirty UNESCO Conventions set international standards. In some cases, as with the World Heritage Convention, the UNESCO instrument has been the precursor to the enactment of Commonwealth legislation to preserve Australia's own unique natural heritage sites and cultural property.
TRAINING

Australia has a major role as a provider of skilled human resources for UNESCO in its Asia and Pacific regional programs. UNESCO is increasingly seeking to use Australian expertise and educational institutions to provide, at full cost, specialist training to students from developing countries. This participation in training and also in consultancies sponsored by UNESCO bring additional benefits in new opportunities for trade with regional countries, involving such exports as textbooks and technology.

The involvement of Australian experts in operational activities sponsored by UNESCO constitutes a significant contribution to Australia's relations with developing countries, particularly those in our region, at little or no financial cost to the Australian Government.
EDUCATION

UNESCO is the primary international agency operating in education at the school level. Australia is a leading participant in the UNESCO Asian Pacific Program of Educational Innovation for Development (APPEID), a regional cooperation activity through which member states pool and exchange knowledge and techniques in this area.
SCIENTIFIC COOPERATION

International collaboration is an essential part of progress in science. Australia makes a major contribution to and benefits from all UNESCO's programs in this area, particularly the internationally highly regarded programs in water resources, earth sciences, marine and environmental science. Australia was recently contracted by UNESCO to begin a new program dealing with the science and technology needs of the Pacific.

As a founding member and supporter of the ideals of UNESCO, Australia will continue to participate in the work of the organisation, with the object of encouraging good management, efficient and effective program delivery, clear priorities and budgetary restraint.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Statement by United States Navy Secretary

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 4685 (Hansard, 18 November 1986, page 3365), has his attention been drawn to a recent statement by the U.S. Navy Secretary saying that the U.S. Navy was proceeding with plans to shift its Antarctic support operations from Christchurch to Hobart.

(2) Have there been any discussions between U.S. and Australian officials about this transfer; if so, is he able to say when such a transfer might be implemented and whether the U.S. facilities will be located at Hobart or an alternative location.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I believe the statement referred to in the first part of the honourable member's question was made by retiring U.S. Navy Secretary, John Lehman, on 2 April 1987. The statement appears to have been made in a private interview with a Radio New Zealand journalist, following an appearance by Mr Lehman before the National Press Club in Washington. Mr Lehman's personal views on this issue are well known, but do not reflect official U.S. Policy.

The United States Government has denied any suggestion that plans are being made to transfer the National Science Foundation's Polar Program logistical support activity from Christchurch to Hobart (or to any other location for that matter). Following the ANZUS talks in San Francisco last August, U.S. Secretary of State Shultz stated that he did not foresee a shift of the Antarctic facility away from Christchurch. The Government has not been advised of any change in the position of the United States Administration since that date.

(2) Former Navy Secretary Lehman and officials of his Department visited Australia in November and December last year. During that time a range of issues was discussed, including with Australian officials.

Operation Deep Freeze was discussed only informally and at no stage have United States officials requested Australia to consider hosting their Antarctic support facilities. The position of the United States Administration on this matter is as enunciated above by Secretary of State Shultz.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.
