ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. (a) There is no scheduled passenger transport service. Cargo vessels travelling between New Zealand and Panama provide an approximately tri-monthly (northbound) service to Pitcairn. Although this service is under review, we understand that a proposal exists for a regular Cook Islands-Tahiti-Pitcairn cargo/passenger service to be established. Other vessels and yachts make unscheduled stops. During 1985, 30 ships and 11 yachts visited Pitcairn.

(4) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 30 April 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that (a) section 135te of the Social Security Act provides that a pensioner must advise any change in circumstances and (b) failure to inform his Department of increased earnings may result in an overpayment which can be recovered retrospectively.

(2) Does the same recourse to retrospectivity apply when the change in circumstances would have resulted in an increase in the rate of pension applicable; if not is reference manual section 16.620 the appropriate policy interpretation in these cases.

(3) Is any discretion exercised in these cases referred to in part (2) where the change in circumstances can be fully substantiated; if not, is it a long standing policy which has been applied consistently without discrimination.
(4) Will all cases involving a failure to advise a change in circumstances be treated equitably, especially in the area of retrospectivity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes-Where the event might affect the payment of a pension, benefit or allowance.
(b) Consistent with (a) above, failure to notify of increased earnings within the allowable period results in an overpayment commencing from the payday after the increase in earnings occurred.

(2) A decline in income giving rise to a potential increase in pension is generally notified promptly. It is normal practice to increase the rate of pension as from the first pension pay-day on or after receipt of advice from the pensioner. The relevant manual references are 16.620 and 19.200.
(3) Discretion does exist to increase the rate of pension from an earlier date. Officers are instructed that this may be appropriate where:
the department is aware that a pensioner's circumstances will change from a future date, and the case was not noted for review; or
the pensioner alleges that an earlier application for increase was made at or about the time the circumstances changed; or

the request for payment had been delayed through circumstances beyond the pensioner's control and is attributable to causes other than mere ignorance of entitlement or failure to inquire on his or her part (eg. ill health or where incorrect advice has been provided to the pensioner by a person or authority upon whose advice it was reasonable for them to rely).
(4) The Social Security Act specified the date from which an overpayment exists where a change in circumstances leading to reduction or termination of entitlement is involved.

The Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1987 contains an amendment which will promote uniformity of treatment where a change in circumstances leading to an increase in entitlement is involved by specifying that the date of change is the pension payday on or after the day of notification.

Background: Although it is the department's policy to pay an increase from the next pension pay-day at present the legislation does not preclude payment of arrears where a person advises of a change of circumstances that took place some time ago. However, on the basis that a person entitled to an increase in pension will normally notify promptly, the discretion is generally only applied in limited circumstances as outlined in the answer.

The proposed amendment arising from the May measures will give full legal support to this long standing policy of no arrears and will ensure that review activity is not made more complex and costly by the necessity to review entitlement over a lengthy past period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 1 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he investigating the Maranoa Housing Company over allegations of misappropriation and mismanagement.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to allegations that the company has not had an annual general meeting, nor audit reports, for 3 years.

(3) Is he investigating the Downs Aboriginal Housing Company for alleged misappropriation of funds and is the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and his Department still funding this organisation.

(4) Has the Redfern Housing Company received $200,000 in funds from the ADC to purchase a hotel on the corner of Everleigh Street; if so, for what purpose will this site be used and what will happen to the liquor licence.

(5) What compensation will be paid to the owners of property in Redfern whose buildings have been destroyed and the sites subsequently cleared following court orders for construction of new homes by the Redfern Housing Company.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Maranoa Aboriginal Housing Company Limited was incorporated under the Queensland Companies Act on 13 April 1976.

It is not the responsibility of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to investigate allegations that a company is in breach of the legislation under which it was incorporated or the manner in which it conducts its affairs.
However, agencies of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio do require acceptable standards of accountability and conduct on the part of those organisations they fund.

I am informed by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) that it is aware of these allegations and has received complaints from members of the Company, who were advised to pursue their concerns with the Corporate Affairs Office in Brisbane.

The ADC is also aware that the Company has not held Annual General Meetings or provided Audit Reports for the past 3 years. Because of this, and the unsatisfactory way in which the Company has conducted its affairs, the Commisison ceased funding it in March 1986.
No ADC funding has been provided over the last 14 months, nor does the Commission intend to resume funding until it is satisfied with the conduct of Company affairs.
However, it should be noted that Maranoa has satisfactorily acquitted all monies provided to it by the ADC in 1985-86 and previous financial years.

(3) No. My Department provides funds to the Downs Housing Company through an accountant's trust account and therefore such funds are properly accounted for. My reply to part (12) of Question No. 5329 is also relevant.
(4) No. The Company is currently negotiating to purchase the Railway View Hotel and if these negotiations are concluded satisfactorily, funds will be provided by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

The site will probably be used for office space and the supermarket run by the Aboriginal Housing Company. The Liquor Licence is to be sold and proceeds allocated to the costs of redevelopment of West Redfern.

Both the Aboriginal community and the Government agencies involved, Local, State and Commonwealth, consider the closure of the Hotel essential to the success of any attempts to address the problems of the area.
(5) None. The buildings have been demolished. The Sydney City Countil issued demolition orders on derelict properties.

(17) Has his attention been drawn to the refusal of the ADC to sign over a property of the Community Centre in Charleville to the Charleville Aboriginal Housing Company, and that the company has spent approximately $60,000 in renovations and rates for approximately 4 years.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The restructuring of the QEB Legal Service was approved by the Queensland State Director of my Department after discussion with other senior Departmental staff. The restructuring responded to widespread community demands expressed over a lengthy period of time.

(3) On 15 December 1986, solicitors for Mr R. Robinson wrote to several Commonwealth authorities alleging improper actions by the Director of the Queensland Office and the Regional manager of the Roma Office of my Department. (11) I am informed that the ADC has undertaken normal examination of audited financial statements for the Downs Aboriginal and Islander Company Limited in respect of the financial years 1983/84, 1984/85 and 1985/86 as well as such financial statements (unaudited) as are available for 1986/87. None of these disclosed theft or misappropriation of the kind alleged by Mr Robinson.

Although the auditors have been consistently critical of the Company's standards of accounting, they have not made any suggestions of misappropriation. Company standards of accounting are of concern and the Company has been informed of ADC expectations for improvement in this area.

The ADC also informed the Company of allegations made by Mr Robinson and asked that it undertake an inquiry and advise of any improper use of its funds. The Company is understood to be undertaking this inquiry with the assistance of their accountants.

The ADC has also written to the Company advising that any matters involving misappropriation of monies ought to be referred to the Police for detailed investigation. The Company has also been advised to have a separate, independent audit of its books of account conducted.

The Company has also been informed that the ADC, as a principal funding body, would expect to be fully informed of the results of such investigations and that future funding by the ADC will be heavily dependent on their outcome.
My Department would likewise expect such action to be taken and such standards to be observed.

Robinson, Chairman of the Company. Personal loans appear to have been made, interest-free, for unspecified periods and without approval of the Company's Board at the time they were made.
In December 1986, the ADC asked the Company for explanations concerning some 105 irregularities and qualifications raised by the auditor. To date, the Company has not provided satisfactory replies.

(16) No. Immediately following the closing of the 46th Commission Meeting (19 February 1987), Mr Robinson met with the Deputy Chairman and three of the Commissioners to whom he made representations seeking their support for the provision and release of ADC grant funds to the Charleville Aboriginal Housing Company.

The Deputy Chairman did seek advice from Commission staff as to the reasons why no offer of funding had been made to the Company and was provided with the reasons and concerns in relation to Company performance.

(17) The ADC has never been asked to sign over property to which it holds title and which is currently used as a Community Centre in Charleville. In the absence of a request for transfer of title, the Commission has neither agreed to nor rejected such transfer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to media reports concerning the relocation of large numbers of refugees under Khmer Rouge control in inaccessible Thai-Kampuchean border camps and the barring of access by relief agencies to the refugees.
(2) What action has the Government taken in relation to this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) According to the latest reports some of those relocated have told relief workers that their move to Na Trao and other camps was voluntary and that they are happy to be there. Access to the camps is unavailable to Australian officials.

Following the Vietnamese offensive against Khmer resistance bases along the Thai/Cambodian border in early 1985, about 250,000 Cambodian civilians were evacuated to Thailand. The evacuees have been provided with temporary sanctuary in camps administered by the Thai Supreme Command in co-operation with the United Nations Border Relief Organisation (UNBRO). UNBRO co-ordinates relief measures for the evacuees while the International committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has prime responsibility for their protection. Australia has provided $705,000 in cash grants and food supplies during 1986/87 to UNBRO.

It is, of course, the prerogative of the Thai Government to decide how to give effect to its responsibilities towards refugees and evacuees on Thai territory. As one of the UNBRO donor countries Australia is in regular contact with the Thai authorities and with the United Nations personnel co-ordinating Kampuchean assistance programs. The Government attached a high priority to the welfare and safety of evacuees and continues to express its concerns to both the Thai authorities and International Agencies as the opportunities arise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 5 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a security quarantine station established on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands despite the presence there of rare and, in some cases, endangered migratory birds.
(2) How has the Government ensured that the quarantine station is not a risk to the local population, their domestic animals and the island's native fauna.
(3) If the quarantine station is safe, why was it not placed on some isolated point on the Australian mainland.
(4) What consultations have taken place between successive Governments and the local population regarding the establishment of the quarantine station and its continued operation.
(5) Has the local population been informed of the value of the station to the Australian cattle industry.
(6) Does the local population receive any royalty or payment for any risk to which they are subject.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. A livestock quarantine station was established in 1981. However, the disease concerns relating to the livestock imported through the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Animal Quarantine Station (cattle, sheep, goats etc) were extensively considered in advance and are such that they pose no risk to native or migratory bird life. It is not planned to import live birds or avian genetic material through this station.

(2) Prior to the quarantine station being opened, an extensive epidemiological survey was undertaken by experts from Departments of Primary Industry, Health and CSIRO to establish the potential for disease transmission to and retention in native fauna on the islands. The islands' native fauna is limited to birds, lizards and crustaceans, none of which is potentially threatened by any disease that may be introduced by the livestock imported into the quarantine station.
The local population's domestic animals (currently confined to cats and chickens) are not considered to be at risk in the unlikely event of a disease being encountered at the quarantine station.

A small goat herd is owned by the Clunies-Ross family on Home Island. This herd consists entirely of goats which were extensively tested prior to introduction from Australia. Serum samples from these goats are regularly collected to permit retrospective disease surveys should this be warranted. These goats are on Home Island on the opposite side of the lagoon to the island containing the quarantine station.

Operational procedures at the quarantine station are specifically designed to minimise the spread of any disease from the station. Casual visitors are not permitted while a livestock quarantine is in operation.

A quarantine service was established at Cocos Islands at the time of establishment of the quarantine station. This involves normal quarantine controls over arrivals of aircraft, ships and itinerant yachts. It ensures that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have the same quarantine controls over arrivals of people, animals, plants and goods, including controls over quarantine waste disposal, as are in place on the Australian mainland.

On establishment of the station, the Department of Health, which then had the responsibility for Quarantine, undertook to provide animal health services to the local population. This continues to be part of the ongoing program, utilising the expertise of the staff employed on the station and providing regular health checks on local domestic animals.
The controls and programs outlined above are designed to enhance the health status of the local animal population.

It must be noted that, prior to shipment to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Animal Quarantine Station, imported livestock are subject to isolation and extensive health testing. Australian conditions for importation of livestock are comprehensive and require exhaustive testing regimes to be met. This reduces to a minimum the possibility of introduction of an infected animal into the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

(3) The answer to the Honourable Member's question can best be summarised by quoting from the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works' fifth report of 1973 in relation to the construction of an offshore high security animal quarantine station:

``If the quarantine station is on an island sufficiently removed from the mainland and Tasmania, in the unlikely event of an outbreak of exotic disease in the quarantine station it would not be considered as implicating the mainland and for purpose of trade Australia would be considered free of that disease. An off-shore island location presents the most satisfactory solution to the interacting requirements of security, maintenance of normal trade, safety and convenience. In addition, an island location presents enormous capital cost savings in that expensive works to make animal accommodation virus proof will not be required.

The selected site should be at least 100 miles from the mainland to obviate the risk of infected insects travelling to or from the island and the possibility of droplet transmission by wind of virus particles such as foot-and-mouth disease. It was noted that foot-and-mouth disease virus has been suspected of carrying 40-60 miles downwind in Europe. Insect vectors of certain diseases could be expected to carry approximately 100 miles in favourable weather conditions.''

(4) Again, the honourable member's question can best be answered by quoting from a report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. The following is from the Committee's second report of 1978 in relation to the construction of the quarantine station:

``Land acquisition. Following agreement with the Clunies-Ross Estate, the Government has now purchased the land on Cocos Island on which it is proposed to locate the quarantine station. At various times the Islanders have indicated their support for the Station. Late in 1977 the Department of Health was advised that the Islanders and Mr J. Clunies-Ross had no objection to the Commonwealth constructing and operating the station with its own resources.''

``Committee's conclusion. The committee notes that arrangements have now been made about the purchase of the land on which the station is to be built and that the local people have indicated their support''.

Cocos Malays have been employed on the quarantine station since it opened in 1981 and offers of work experience programs have frequently been extended to the Cocos Malay community. Discussions have also been held regarding the possibility of Cocos Malays being trained in animal quarantine procedures on the mainland for future employment on the Cocos Islands as Quarantine Officers. To date none have accepted this government offer.

There has been ongoing liaison with the Cocos Malay community regarding animal and plant health on the islands and any activities on the station which may affect their community. This has included discussions with the Cocos Malay Council on the possible importation of pigs through the station.

(5) Yes. The local population has over several years been informed of the value of the station. Local people are aware of the value of the animals being imported through the station and the reasons for the extensive quarantine procedures being followed. Following the health clearance of consignments for export to the mainland, an open day is often held permitting the local population to view the animals and to have any questions answered by the station staff.

(6) No. Due to the design and operational procedures of the quarantine station, it is not considered to constitute any risk to the local population. The Cocos Malay community, as Australian citizens, benefit indirectly from the operations of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Animal Quarantine Station which is regarded as being a national asset.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1987:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In January 1986, during IFAD's 9th Governing Council meeting, the Australian Government made known its intention to participate in the second replenishment of IFAD (IFAD-2) which covers the years 1985/87. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 7 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. Has his Department held discussions with Aboriginal artists and arts organisations over their boycott of Aboriginal Arts Australia's attempts to centralise promotion and sale.
2. On what basis was this move taken by his Department.
3. What are the artists' objections to this move.
4. Under what body are these functions to be co-ordinated.
5. What is the annual budget and staffing of this organisation and will these be increased to cover the new arrangements.
6. Is this organisation profitable.
7. For what reasons has his Department taken over this function from successful private organisations and placed them under a Government body.
8. What attempts has his Department made to meet the demands of Aboriginal artists who have placed a boycott on dealing with the Government agency since 2 April 1987.
9. Are buyers for Inada Holdings still operating and entering Aboriginal land without permits at Yirrkala.
10. Will his Department establish a review of these matters before proceeding any further with this move.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 7 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funding has the Kintore Health Service received from the Government in every year of its operation.
(2) Which communities and how many persons are serviced by this organisation.
(3) What vehicles have been purchased by the health service and what has been the cost of purchasing the vehicles.
(4) Are the vehicles ever used for private purposes and are they always available to transport patients.
(5) How many staff operate the service.
(6) On what basis are appointments and dismissals made by the health service.
(7) What is the management structure of the service, how often are meetings held and how many members attend the meetings.
(8) How many persons have had to be evacuated to Alice Springs Hospital by Royal Flying Doctor Service or chartered aircraft in the past year.
(9) How many persons from communities serviced by the health service have died in the past year.

(10) What is the incidence of (a) gastroenteritis, (b) childhood deaths and malnutrition, (c) enteric disease, (d) chronic ear infections, (e) eye disease, (f) leprosy, (g) sexually transmitted diseases and (h) deaths from external causes in the communities serviced by the organisation.
(11) How many cases referred to in part (10) are treated each week.
(12) What costs are incurred through delivery of drugs, treatments and transport and what are the costs of salaries and administration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Funding for the Pintubi Homelands Health Service (PHHS) in every year of its operations is as follows:
1982/83 Establishment grant ... $30,000
1983/84 Capital and Recurrent ... $455,500
1984/85 Capital and Recurrent ... $536,000
1985/86 Capital and Recurrent ... $460,857
1986/87 Capital and Recurrent ... $492,070
1987/88 Estimated, Capital and Recurrent $548,100

(2) The communities serviced by PHHS are as follows: Kintore, Kiwikurra, Ininti, Moyin, Montarti, Tjinki, Tjalpiratjara, Pinpirinya, Neugelna, Neunman, Yuwalki, Kalipimpa. The total population served fluctuates between 700-1200, depending on traditional and seasonal influences.

(3) PHHS maintain a fleet of four Toyota Landcruiser Station Wagons, two of which are replaced each year. Replacement costs to the Department for two vehicles was $44,000 in 1986/87, including trade-ins. Estimated costs of replacements in 1987/88, including trade-ins is $46,000.

(4) Until recently, intense pressure had been put on PHHS staff by community Aboriginals for private use of these vehicles. This matter was investigated by Departmental staff, discussed with community members, and corrected; future funding has been made strictly dependent on correct use of PHHS vehicles. Two recent instances of vehicles not being available to transport patients contributed to this DAA intervention. DAA are now satisfied that vehicles are available to transport patients and are not used for private purposes.
(5) Staffing positions of PHHS are as follows: one doctor, two sisters, one Administrator (all non-Aboriginal); one Administrative understudy and seven health workers (all Aboriginal).

(6) Non-Aboriginal appointments are made by the Executive of PHHS. Advertising, assessing of applications and interviews are undertaken by the Executive with DAA assistance. There have been no dismissals to date, but these, too, would be finalised by the Executive.

(7) Meetings of the PHHS Health Committee are held approximately monthly, with other meetings as necessary to deal with crises. Attendance at these meetings varies between 6 and 15. The committee is not a formal western model, being structured along traditional lines. The whole of the Wallangura Council, and other interested community members are on the Committee.

The operational and management structures of PHHS were most recently revised in April 1987. Patients see the health workers first for any treatment, then, as necessary, the sister, and the doctor. The Administrative understudy does the budgets and ordering, under the Administrator's supervision. The Doctor controls the use of vehicles. The Doctor and the Administrator (together with the TAFE Adult Educator) undertake community health education programs and Aboriginal Health Worker training programs.

(g) Sexually Transmitted Diseases-figures not available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 7 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Aboriginal Health Services are funded by his Department.
(2) What is the annual allocation to these services.
(3) How many services jointly receive funding from State Government.
(4) Which services are under review by his Department.
(5) What measures are being taken by his Department to ensure that Aboriginals are receiving medical attention equivalent to other Australians through State run health organisations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 to 3) There are 54 independent Aboriginal community controlled organisations being funded by the Department throughout Australia this financial year at a total projected cost of $18,547,996 to provide health services to Aboriginal communities. Of these, four jointly receive funding from State or Territory Governments.
(4) All Aboriginal Health Services are regularly reviewed in accordance with Program Performance Budgetting requirements.

(5) Department of Aboriginal Affairs programs operate to overcome Aboriginal disadvantage but are not intended to replace those programs administered by a Commonwealth, State or Territory authority which provide services to the general community. In the Aboriginal health field DAA funding should be directed to overcoming the additional disadvantage experienced by Aboriginal people while also ensuring that other Commonwealth, State and Territory programs provide appropriate services which are accessible to Aboriginals.
The Government's broad objective in Aboriginal health is to raise the standard of Aboriginal health to that enjoyed by the Australian community overall.
To this end, the strategy of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is to:
(a) Give greater priority to, and place greater emphasis on, improving the physical environment in which Aboriginal people live, especially in regard to housing and essential services.
(b) Subject all major policy and project proposals to an assessment of their impact on the environment, lifestyle and well-being of Aboriginal people.
(c) Ensure that all programs reflect this total approach, that they are developed in the context of such an assessment and that they are accompanied by appropriate education and training initiatives.
(d) Facilitate the development of integrated programs through joint State/Federal and Aboriginal consultative mechanisms.
(e) Include educative and training programs to assist Aboriginal people to obtain the maximum benefit from programs.

All programs are planned and implemented in close consultation with both State/Territory authorities and the Aboriginal community, to seek to ensure that Aboriginal citizens have full access to health services. The Department will provide a total of some $13.67m in grants to the States in 1986-87 to supplement their health programs for Aborigines in recognition of their special disadvantage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 14 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the guidelines for granting enrolment to those voters who do not wish to have their address shown on the roll under section 104 of the Act.
(2) How does this section apply in Queensland where there is a joint electoral card but a separate electoral roll.
(3) What criteria are the Commonwealth Commission adopting in accepting or rejecting applications in Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The guidelines for granting silent enrolment status to electors on application are laid down in s. 104 (1)-(6) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.
An applicant must lodge with the appropriate Divisional Returning Officer (DRO) a request in the approved form that his address be deleted from the roll.
The request must give particulars of the relevant risk and must be verified by statutory declaration by the applicant or some other person.

Where the DRO is satisfied that having the applicant's address shown on the roll places or would place the personal safety of the person or members of the person's family at risk, the applicant's address is removed from the roll.

(2) Applications for silent enrolment in Queensland where a joint claim card exists but separate rolls are maintained are referred to the State Electoral Office in an attempt to reach agreement in regard to the acceptance or rejection of the application.
(3) The criteria adopted by the Electoral Commission in evaluating claims for silent enrolment are as follows:
All applications for silent enrolment must comply with the provisions laid down in s. 104 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

The DRO has the authority to evaluate each case and to accept a claim only in those cases where the applicant has a genuine fear of violence and concern for personal safety should the address appear on the roll.

The applicant's occupation alone is insufficient justification for the approval of silent enrolment. Each applicant must provide details of specific threats to personal safety which would result from the publication of the address.

In cases where one member of a family has been granted silent enrolment, other members can apply by stating on their application their relationship with the person who has been approved as a silent elector.
One supporting statutory declaration is acceptable where it covers the necessary separate but concurrent applications from both husband and wife.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the U.S. moved to condemn the treatment of political dissidents in Cuba at a United Nations forum held in Geneva during April 1987.
(2) Is he able to say whether these moves by the U.S. delegation were prevented by procedural means initiated by the Indian delegation.
(3) Was there a vote taken on the Indian procedural initiative; if so, how did the Australian delegation vote.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The United States tabled a draft resolution condemning human rights abuses in Cuba during the 43rd Session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights which was held in Geneva from 2 February to 13 March 1987. The draft resolution drew attention to Cuban treatment of political prisoners.
(2) The United States move was blocked when a motion, proposed by the Indian delegation, to take no action on the United States draft resolution was narrowly passed.
(3) The Indian procedural motion was voted on at the meeting. The Australian delegation voted against it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any officers of the Minister's department or statutory authorities under his responsibility visited Libya since March 1983; if so, (a) when did each visit take place, (b) what was the purpose of the visit, and (c) who incurred the expense of the visit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the right honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs have visited Libya on official business since March 1983. Records are not available of private visits undertaken by officers.
(a) Records available to the Department indicate the official visits were undertaken in May 1983 and June 1986 by officers of the Australian Embassy at Rome.
(b) The purpose of the visits was to provide consular assistance to Australians in Libya.
(c) Costs were met by the Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 28 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Have any officers of the Minister's Department or statutory authorities under his responsibility visited Libya since March 1983; if so, (a) when did each visit take place, (b) what was the purpose of the visit, and (c) who incurred the expense of the visit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the right honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: One officer from the Department of Primary Industry visited Libya in 1985. The details of this trip are:
(a) Visit was from 15 April 1985 to 20 April 1985.
(b) The officer was a Veterinarian accompanying a live shipment of sheep.
(c) The cost of the trip was met on a shared basis between the exporter and the Department.

Two similar trips were undertaken by officers from the Western Australian Department of Primary Production on behalf of the Department of Primary Industry. These were in May and June 1986 and the purpose and funding arrangements were the same.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 29 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What assistance has been provided by the Government to overcome problems in the Aboriginal and Islander Communities in Australia in relation to (a) alcoholism, (b) unemployment, (c) sub standard housing, (d) upgrading employment skills, (e) education disadvantages and (f) other welfare needs.
(2) What has been the value of this assistance since 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the honourable member to a recent publication by my Department entitled ``Achievements in Aboriginal Affairs 1983-1987''.

This document, which is available in the Parliamentary Library, sets out activities in Aboriginal affairs since the Government came to power in 1983 and includes the levels of assistance made available as well as the outcomes arising from that assistance in all areas including those mentioned by the honourable member.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the members of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) responsible for all the recommendations made by that body.
(2) Who were the members on 1 June 1986 of (a) the NHMRC and (b) the following NHMRC committees (i) Public Health, (ii) Food Standards and (iii) Food Science and Technology sub-committee.

(3) In respect of these members (a) what are (i) their academic qualifications, (ii) their professional qualifications and (iii) the organisations they represent and (b) what is their specific medical and scientific expertise.
(4) Does his Department provide the secretariat and administrative support for the NHMRC.
(5) During 1985-86 how many departmental officers were employed on NHMRC work (a) full-time and (b) part-time.
(6) What was the expenditure on the NHMRC for 1985-86 and how much of this was for research grants.
(7) What was his Department's expenditure on NHMRC activities for 1985-86.

(8) Will he supply a list of all committees, sub-committees and working parties of the NHMRC, together with the names and affiliations of the members of each, as at 1 June 1986, indicating those members who were paid a sitting fee and the amount of any such fee.
(9) Are NHMRC chairpersons required to sign a declaration on possible conflicts of interest.
(10) if so, (a) have any declarations been signed, (b) what chairpersons have signed up to 31 July 1986 and (c) are such declarations available for public inspection; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Pursuant to the Order-in-Council under which the National Health and Medical Research Council is constituted, the Council is required to assess the recommendations of committees established under the Order-in-Council. The process adopted by the Council for this purpose is one of ratification of committee recommendations by the Council.

(2) Membership details are provided in Attachment A which has been collated for the honouable member, but which is too lengthy to be published in Hansard. A copy of Attachment A is filed in the Table Office of the House of Representatives where it may be read or a copy of it obtained.
(3) See Attachement A.
(4) Yes.
(5) Full-time: 46, Part-time 102.
(6) Total NHMRC Expenditure: $55.025 million. Expenditure on Research Grants: $51.236 million.

(8) I refer the honourable member to the `National Health and Medical Research Council General Information Document' and the `National Health and Medical Research Council Working Parties Information Document'. These documents contain the names of all NHMRC committees, sub-committees and working parties, together with their memberships. Copies have been forwarded to the honourable member.

Daily sitting fees set by the Remuneration Tribunal are paid to Council and Committee (including sub-committee and working party) members other than those who are officers or employees of the Public Service of the Commonwealth or of a State or of the Northern Territory.
The rates are $173 a day (Chairperson) and $139 a day (Members).
In applying the exclusion `Public Service' is interpreted to include statutory authorities of the Commonwealth (e.g. CSIRO) or of a State.
(9) and (10) No. Oral assurances have been obtained and recorded in respect of Ministerial appointments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the cost of implementing Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) programs in the Minister's Department, including all costs associated with the recruitment of EEO officers, advertising, office facilities, training and development programs.
(2) How many (a) full-time and (b) part-time EEO officers are employed in the Department and what salaries do they receive.
(3) What is the estimated annual recurrent expenditure to maintain the EEO unit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A figure is not available on the cost of implementing the Department's EEO (Equal Employment Opportunity) Program. Costs are included within the Department's salaries and administrative costs, which are not itemised on a unit staffing cost basis.

Recruitment for EEO staff is carried out in the same way as for other staff, i.e. through advertisement in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, and office facilities and training are available to EEO staff under the same conditions and arrangements as for other staff.
(2) (a) Full time EEO Co-ordinators are employed within the Department as follows:
Central Office
One CLAD 11-Salary $40,686
One CLAD 8-Salary $32,326
NSW Branch Office
One CLAD 7-Salary $29,269
NSW RGH (Concord)
One CLAD 7-Salary $29,269
Victorian Branch Office
One CLAD 7-Salary $29,269
Victorian-RGH (Heidelberg)
One CLAD 7-Salary $29,269
Queensland Branch Office
One CLAD 7-Salary $29,269
South Australia
One CLAD 6-Salary $26,640
Western Australia
One CLAD 6-Salary $26,640
(b) One part-time position-i.e. half of this officer's duties are devoted to EEO-has been established in Tasmania:
Tasmania
Half of one CLAD 6-Salary $26,640
(3) As with question (1), no figure is available for recurrent costs for EEO implementation.
